number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												Owlboy is a game that traditional platforming fans might find lacking,  as there is not much in the way of challenging platforming sections in the game's ~6 hour runtime. Most of the challenging platforming is concentrated in the last hour. The mechanics of the game (infinite flight for the protagonist) naturally make it difficult for the developer to create platforming sections that test the player's mastery of the game's physics. The platforming is not what I would call the game's strong suit, but it doesn't have to be- everything else is top notch.The pixel art is jaw dropping and backgrounds are frequently gorgeously animated. The music is a standard orchestral affair, and there are plenty of strong tracks within the soundtrack. The characters of the world are great- Otus, the main player character, is established early on as a sympathetic failure of an owl whom most characters brush off as useless or disappointing, especially so Otus' teacher, Asio. Otus starts out almost friendless, but the band of buddies Otus meets along his journey keep him in high spirits. My favorite surprise of the game was how expressive Otus was- despite being mute, he has a litany of facial expressions that keep him from just being a stonefaced protagonist. Every character in the game has great dialogue, especially so for Geddy, Otus' best bro. Geddy is the star character of the game scriptwise. He says the right stuff at the right times.The game does not last any longer than it needs to. It establishes the main conflict well within the first 20 minutes of the game and solves the conflict within a reasonable time period- should the game have lasted an hour longer, I imagine I would've started to feel the tedium of traversal in the game through the same areas weigh on me. The level design is about what you would expect it to be for a game featuring a flying protagonist- many floating islands in the hub-like areas and frequent linear sections limiting flight possibilities in the areas related to plot progression (though these flight limiting sections are often not as interesting as I would like them to be personally, but again it's not a dealbreaker). To that end, if you're expecting a hardcore or extremely difficult platforming experience with Owlboy, this game is simply not for you. Look elsewhere.However, if you want a nice 6 hour experience with amazing presentation that tells an engaging story with a great cast of characters....this is the right game for you. Is the game worth the 25 dollar price point? I'd say the value I would put it at is closer to 20 dollars.... Though of course, if your game is in development for 9 years, I suppose you really want to get your investment back sooner rather than later, so I can understand why the devs put the price point where they did.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												2 hours in and I found myself struggling to take a break. Almost a decade ago we were introduced to this promising classic take on a pixel 2d platformer(ish?) game and despite them working behind closed curtains I can honestly say it was worth the wait. I honestly only caught wind of the game's progress because a friend of mine mentioned it was well along development a few months back and could release in a matter of months. What do I have to say about the game itself? - Well, the protagonist is pretty nice. I genuinely felt a little bad for the fella in the beginning but he's currently off to make things right in the world of Owlboy. - The first few (mini?) boss fights I've encountered were kinda mindless. I literally stumbled into them, steamrolled the bosses and kept it moving without much thinking power.- The puzzles so far are somewhat interesting but a little straightforward. I'll save judgment for that for now though since I don't think I've even made it halfway through the game yet.- The soundtrack is oddly interesting with its differences. Some parts of the game are like chiptune-ish while others are like modern-day soundtracks. The inconsistency kinda throws me off sometimes in terms of immersion.I don't really like writing stupid long reviews so I just want to keep it short and simple as possible. 9 years of work right right here and it's visually appealing and plays well.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												This game is beautiful.The controls are tight and responsive, even in flight where you'd expect them to be floaty. The story is great, even though some specific parts can be a little predictable (One specific part follows an overused action movie cliché that can be seen coming from miles away.) The soundtrack and pixel art is absolutely gorgeous and doesn't try for a nostalgia grab at all. The music isn't chiptune, and the color palette isn't restricted to a short, specific range of colors to emulate the NES, SNES, or SEGA Genesis art/sound styles. The music sounds like a full orchestra, and the art is about as detailed as pixel art can get. The game also runs at a constant frame rate of 60fps with little to no frame drops.The gameplay is really unique, and there's really only one thing that I can compare it to.Remember when you were really young and wanted to play "Sonic 3" with your older brother, but got stuck playing as Tails because that's who player 2 controls? Remember how Tails was actually really useful to control because he can fly and carry Sonic around to hard to reach areas? That's right, you're pretty much playing as Tails carrying your friends around, but this time you're player one, you make the decisions now. When you're carrying any one of three companions, the game goes from a scrolling platformer to a twin-stick shooter with puzzle-platformer aspects. It really is a lot more fun than just being able to ferry the real protagonist around.The characters are all very diverse, and though the trope of "silent protagonist" is there, its part of the character. Most games that follow that trope do so to help the player put their own personality onto the character they are controlling. In this game, Otus (playable character) is mute, and other characters comment on this. Instead of Otus' personality being expressed through dialogue, it is shown through his expressions and animations. Throughout the game, Otus will show his reactions to getting bullied with a saddened expression. He'll react to his teacher and father figure downright hating him for being such a disappointment at everything by crouching a little and covering his ear-slits (because he's an owl) with his hands to try to block out what's being said. When he drinks something that raises his max HP, he'll stand stock-still, stiff as a board with a wide eyed, surprised expression. At the end of the game is the only time we ever see him take on an angry/determined expression, but its easily identifiable.The only gripe I have with this game is the price. I mean, I would have spent $25-$30 anyways so I could get the soundtrack, but $25 for the base game is a little steep. I don't regret spending the money at all, though. I'm not trying to justify the price by saying "I enjoyed it, so the price is worth it to everyone, anyone who disagrees can go to Hell." The price is a bit too high, and that will be a turn-off for some people.

number of helpful: 15 of 28 people (54%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24
For a game with such a strong and whimsical start, it all falls into a mash of uninteresting mecahanics, frustrating gameplay rife with enemies and situations that seem unfair, and a fairly standard story.I had high hopes for Owlboy and right from the opening title screen I found myself enjoying the inspiring music and getting transfixed with the world it was building with just those two elements. I even lost myself to apparent metroidvania style of level design and the little bits of flying I got to do. The dialogue was fairly witty and making Otus mute was an interesting take on the silent protagonist trope that I adored right off the bat.Then I had to go to the first dungeon and found myself enjoying the game less. The flying had quickly become far too slow and I "fixed" this by air dodging everywhere instead. That was forgivable because, "hey, it's like Ocarina of Time! You just roll everywhere anyway, right?" But man does flying feel like the worst thing after having to traverse open areas with it. I found myself wanting to not explore anything because it meant I have to fly everywhere, and I'm the kind of person who 100% goes left when the game points me toward the right. The combat in this game, in no respect, ever wowwed me. When I learned that it was a twin-stick shooter, I was on-board but skeptical. I figured there would be some fairly immediate upgrades to make Geddy's blaster feel less slow and crappy, so I was immediately excited when I got Alphonse! Until, that is, it turned out that his blunderbuss took what felt like a year and a half to fill up. The idea, of course, is to blast away with Geddy then switch to Alphonse and do a chunk of damage, so I get it, but it's bad. Nothing you do feels quick and powerful, but boy howdy do the enemies have the reverse issue!I was having a good time with the game during the second dungeon area, which is a bit of a stealth mission done simply and elegantly, and I was ready to go on to the next big level! And then that level threw you into so much frustration that after I was done SMASHING into it with my beaten and bloody head, I immediately quit the game feeling cheated. I respect games that take a tough-but-fair approach. Part of that approach is to make sure your players feel like they're getting stronger with the characters. I was ready for a game, priding itself on its SNES/Genesis style, to be difficult-yet-rewarding, but part of that is giving your player ample rewards in the game to keep them going. I don't need much. A simple blaster upgrade for Geddy, a timer reduction for Alphonse's shotgun; anything that would make you feel just a little more powerful would be great. Instead, you take your thousand coins, go to a shop with a shopkeeper who's punchline is that she beats her employees, and then buy a health upgrade and a freakin' hat or two.At the very least, this game is pretty. With artwork this fantastic, I can tell Owlboy's look took nine years of tweaking and changing and reworking and deconstructing and rebuilding to get it just right. I can give nothing but a massive kudos to the artists and musicians of this game. The presentation is lively. This game truly gave me that nostalgic feeling of a late SNES title like Super Castlevania or Demon's Crest, or even Chrono Trigger but with a lot more polish and the power of a PC to back it up. Even the story I found myself enjoying despite it being a fairly on par experience.But beauty is only skin deep. When you get down to the skeleton of a game, the gameplay, it's all rather feeble and dusty.

number of helpful: 17 of 32 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												Alright, I just beat Owlboy after 7 hours of play (too much of which was cutscenes for my taste). I did not 100% it, though I did do some of the extra content. It was alright, but highly disappointing. Not a bad game, but only excellent in its use of pixel art. Wait for a sale. George Weidman (Super Bunnyhop on Youtube) described this game best: "I love you, but sometimes you're a piece of ****"TECHNICAL PERFORMANCE: I believe the game at one point exited to desktop suddenly without warning. However, I can't replicate this. What I'm certain it did was minimize itself at points without warning, despite me only using a 360 controller. This happened a couple of times, and may have something to do with using a second monitor. There were a couple of framerate hiccups that frankly shouldn't have been there considering the style of game, but it wasn't anything harmful to the experience. You have some options for graphical settings, though not many. Understandable for the style of game. PRESENTATION: Lots of wonderful, stunning pixel art that I appreciate thoroughly. Animations are also nice, though there are unfortunately not many of them to see. Characters can emote, and Otus is a precious cinnamon bun, but after the 50th time he gets spooked or looks dead-eyed you kinda wish there were more things they could do. However, what's there is very nice. Menus worked alright, UI was fairly minimal and unintrusive. You have options to change parts of the UI, which is appreciated. There was a surprising amount of the screen going a single colour (white or red) due to shooting an enemy or something, and I found that pretty jarring. GAMEPLAY: This is where Owlboy just tanked for me. The first couple of hours were enjoyable, even if largely scripted. The ability to fly is nice, though it ultimately may have done the game more harm than good. In Owlboy you can fly indefinitely without consequence, which must have posed many problems for level designers trying to make a challenging 2D "platformer". It is more of an exploration-based game like Zelda or Metroid, but the only real exploration is done in the game's dungeons. There's some rudimentary puzzle solving, stealth sections, and shooting enemies, standard stuff. However, I never got into a flow like you might in a Zelda dungeon, where you start being unable to do very little to progress and by the end, can do everything in it. It didn't feel like Metroid either; I never felt lost, I never felt I had to explore much more than one or two screens over to find my next path to progress. The level design isn't particularly complex or elegant. Case-in-point, there was a section where you pass some deadly moving blocks into a room with a giant screw blocking your path. I'd never seen anything like it prior, and couldn't figure out the solution. There was a terminal window in the room, but all it said was a bunch of vague stuff about the story. I tried to leave the area, but found the deadly moving blocks would kill you no matter what timing you used, so all I could do was try the screw again. I did end up progressing, but from what I could tell, nothing prior taught you how to do it, and the solution was not even slightly in-line with anything shown before. That's poor level design, even if I'm just bad at puzzles. The real boss fights, while good when present, were far too scarce. Several "boss fights" were nothing more than waves of common enemies thrown at you, which was disappointing. This also exacerbated what I feel was the absolute biggest problem: the shooting. It's laid out like a twin-stick shooter, but the weapons at your disposal either don't feel remotely satisfying to use, taking far too many shots to kill, or are just impractical for combat. A shotgun you get halfway through has a preposterous cooldown, which is awful when it's used for several repetitive puzzles. Most of the game you'll be mashing a single button to shoot, just because they found it necessary to give your gun a 3-shot burst if you don't do that. Combat isn't just repetitive and time-consuming, it's also frustrating. When you get hit, the whole screen stops moving for a fraction of a second and you get flung in a seemingly random direction. If you hit a wall or an enemy, you also slide along that wall for a period of time. This looks good to a viewer, but when you're playing, it just feels like the controls are being yanked from your hand. CLOSING: I'm sure you can get something like double the time I spent out of this game, but I'd never want to do so. The game works fundamentally, but it's just not very fun after a while. The art is beautiful, but the game lags behind, trying to compensate by shoving story beats in your face. If you want pretty art and a bland game that might have you dying more than you expected, but not because it's difficult, go for it. I'd wait for a sale.Gave this a 5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												Owlboy is simply one of the most impressive indie games I've seen the last years, and I'd say the overall experience makes it equally worth playing as the likes of Shovel Knight, Braid, Cave Story, Undertale and Hyper Light Drifter (not to say that these other games don't have strengths this game doesn't have). The pixel art is stunningly good, perhaps the best I've seen in any hi-bit game. Especially the multiple layered backgrounds look amazing. It contains a very charming cast of characters, who are well-written and highly likable. The OST fits the game perfectly, and some of the tracks will hit you right in the feels. The gameplay is fairly simple, but with an intersting blend of mechanics for the combat. You fly around freely, though you can only stun enemies with Owlboy; for dealing damage you need to use other characters you encounter in the game, and their respective attacks are effective against different set of mobs. The combat works as a twin stick shooter where you can freely aim and fire in all directions irrespective of movement or the direction Owlboy is facing. The gist of it is dashing to dodge mobs while aiming and firing with correct timing, as well as swapping efficiently between your different characters depending on the specific weakness of the mob(s). Your are pointed to the main dungeons in a mostly linear fashion, interspersed with cutscenes and dialogue that drives the story. But there's also metroidvania-like exploration for collectibles (coins and golden disks) and simple puzzles, and the game handles the dungeons well by keeping them fresh and unique, often revolving around gimmicks specific to the abilities of the most recently acquired character. Owlboy doesn't have the same replayability as Shovel Knight with its speedrun achievement or Undertale with its multiple endings, and it's not a hard game to beat. But as an aesthetic experience it's superior to both. This is a masterly handicrafted game, a labor of love, and the most comfy 10 hours you're likely to spend this year.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												Owlboy is a very charming and beautiful game that definitely proves how games can be art. The game was made by D-Pad Studio, a team of only 5 people, during the period of 9 years and it was well worth the wait. Every pixel in this game shows how much of a labor of love this game is. The first thing you’ll notice when you launch Owlboy is the amazingly fitting and atmospheric soundtrack right from the menu screen. Second thing you’ll notice is the most beautiful and detailed pixel art I’ve seen  in a video game since Castlevania: Symphony of the Night. From characters and animations to the game world itself everything looks gorgeous, stylish and unique. The gameplay is simple, but very well made. It’s a mix of flying, dashing, jumping and shooting. You’re Otus, an owl from the village Vellie, and you fly around the world while carrying your friends to help you on your adventures with their unique abilities. The story is charming, filled with humor, but sad at times and characters are very believable and relatable. The only thing that left me kind of underwhelmed and disappointed is the ending. I really hope that D-Pad Studio will release some kind of DLC to explain the ending and the lore more because me, and I’m sure many other people, would like to know more about the characters and the world at the end. Other than that Owlboy is a phenomenal game that I can’t recommend enough. It’s easily a new indie classic and one of my favorite games of all time. Go buy it, it’s worth every cent.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Pros:-Story-Art-Soundtrack-Original MechanicsCons:-A few wonky controls    Owlboy is one of my favorite games of the year. This game features some of the most beautiful artwork of any game I have played in recent memory. The soundtrack is awe-inspiring and it hasn't been been since I was a young boy playing Chrono Trigger on the SNES that a band of pixelated heroes had felt so... real. There are times in the game that you will be reminded of the classics from yesteryear; there are hints of Zelda, Rayman, Metroid, Castlevania but Owlboy always feels distinctively it's own thing. There are a few questionable mechanics in the game. One of your companions has a recharge rate on their weapons that can be absolutely maddening. Though I'm not quite sure whether this is a bug or a feature as it lends to every single one of your companions being indespensible, never being able to rely completely on one single companion. The story remains the single best thing about this game. It covers themes of loss, failure, inadequacy, and learning to have hope in hopeless times in ways that no other medium could. If you enjoy SNES era games or story-rich indie titles Owlboy is a must play. 9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												Oh boy, I was blinded sided by Owlboy.  Over the 8 or so years this game had been in development I somehow managed to avoid hearing a single thing about it until I saw it on the front page of steam. I bought it on a lark and have had a hooting good time. The first thing you notice is that the game is pretty, every aspect of the game looks great and is a joy to look at, from backgrounds to enemies, and most of all the main characters, especially our mute avian hero Otus. His small sprite is highly expressive and very cute that instantly endears you to him. The writing is also top-notch. The story is interesting and all the characters involved make you want to learn more about what is going on. The game is a touch ruthless on hammering home the fact that our hero is a low bird on the totem pole, many characters in power are dismissive of you and actively blame the little owl for things way beyond his control. From this arises one of my problems with the game, and fair warning this paragraph will contain some slight spoliery things. The problem with the writing I have is that come the last leg of the game you get the feeling that you in fact have just made things worse than if you stayed home. The first few missions of the game you get beaten down for failures that Otus had no control over and this instills in the player a feeling of proving that you are right and can save the world so we cheer on Otus and the gang through their hardships.  This falls apart in the last segment of the game, it’s revealed that you have in fact been getting in the way of the character really trying to save the world and almost blow it completely and doom all of creation. That is to say you get a feeling that had you just stayed home then things would have played out similarly in the grand scheme of things. This could be a damning ending for a game but the rest of the experience was so wonderful and the characters you get to interacts with make it more of an annoyance than ruining the whole thing. The game is also very good as, well, a game. The controls are tight and flying with Otus feels great as you traverse the world around you. Once you can pick up your friend Geddy (and a few others later) the game becomes a two stick shooter, you move with one hand and, aim and shot with the other which feels great. The game feels fun and rewarding to play though it is admittedly not that difficult. I don’t mind the casual feeling of the game though for some it is a valid strike against it. The game ramps up the difficulty at a fair pace though it never gets too hard that one should be stuck because of combat for too long. The puzzles also aren’t that hard but I feel that it helps the casual pace of the game where focus is more on having fun with the good controls and keeping the narrative flowing at a decent clip. .  The one point of contention I have seen many bring up is the price and I understand it, I feel that 25$ for the 9-10 hours you get from beating the game is worth it to me, I feel that each of those hours is so jam-packed with lovely visuals and fun gameplay that the quality makes up for the quantity. Some people evaluate the price of their own time differently than I do so may not feel that it is worth it for the amount of game play so I would keep how highly you value hours per dollar in mind before buying the game. Overall I feel Owlboy is worth a play, it’s a delight to control as well as look at and the characters are fun and interesting as is the writing, for the most part. The game left me happy with the time I spent with it though a bit hungry for more content. I also want to pay kudos to the Devs who are active on the discussion board and even helped me when I did encounter a (now patched) game breaking bug within the game. I say take wing with Owlboy and friends and explore this colourful world!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												I'm still progressing through my first playthrough but I can definitely recommend this game to anyone who might had an interest. It's got some strange gameplay which takes a little getting used to, but it's fun, beautiful, and the story is surprisingly dark but still has an amazing charm to it that'll make you smile.My only real 'issue' so far is how easy it can be to lose your character in even mildly tense moments. Especially because often times when being hit, you're sent flying in a seemingly random direction and you lose track of where you're at. Toss in the fact that being toss into a wall will play the same sound as being hit and you quickly start panicing because you think you're being hit multiple times but you're not. This is especially problematic in boss battles with a lot of moving pieces and projectiles.Overall though, that's a very minor issue. I'd still whole heartedly recommend it.[Update]Having beaten the game, I've got to say... the story genuinely impressed me. I felt engaged from start to finish. My only real 'issue' so to speak is that with the game starting off with such a beautiful hook, the final resolve to that conflict seems underwhelming.Spoiler Alert:A mentor which was disappointed in you throughout the entire game seems to have a sudden change of heart with no real explaination before ending off his time in the game with the cliche "I always knew you could do it." I would have liked to see a more complex development of his character since it really seemed to be a major motivation on your part to earn.The overall story exposes some fantastic potential for lore that seems untouched. But taken at face value, what you've got is an adventure spinkled with developing friendship, dark consequences, realistic optimism, touching moments of sadness, and genuine charm.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												This is game is a complete masterpiece. I had never heard about it until a few days ago, and I instantly fell in love with the artwork. I had no idea what the game was supposed to be like, I bought it purely because it LOOKED nice. I was very pleasantly surprised to find that it also has a great story, unique and loveable characters, amazing music and sound design, superb animation, and of course fun and interesting gameplay.I've played for about 3 hours so far, and am just now feeling like the adventure is really getting started, though I've enjoyed every minute of it. I was a little worried that it might be short with not a whole lot to it, as these visually impressive 2D games sometimes tend to be, but every once in a while you get a true masterpiece like this, where everything from design to gameplay is spot on, and isn't too short and gives you a lot to do.This is not a multiplayer or open world sandbox with endless replayability game which seems to be the strange requirement for a lot of people in games these days. It is fairly linear with some exploration in areas, finding coins to unlock upgrades, with secret rooms and hidden chests. I honestly miss games like this, that aren't overly complex with upgrade trees and skill sets. It's quite simple, but does a really good job at being simple, fun, and intriguing. I can definitely see myself being satisfied with a sense of completion when I manage to finish it.With all that being said, I think the price is completely justified. This isn't a short random indie game with nothing much to it, it's a full blown story and adventure with puzzles, boss fights, numerous and unique creatures and characters, secrets to uncover, and has amazing artwork. You can definitely tell that a lot of skill, hardwork, and time went into making this. I want more games like this, so I'm willing to help fund the cause of bringing back games with the magic and creativity that we just don't see so much anymore.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Simon Andersen, aka. Snake, is one of the few kings of pixel art. Visually, Owlboy is a masterpiece. It's a monument that tells pixel art is not only for retro.On top of this, the atmosphere is so original that it's on par with say, Fez. It tells a great story, not one with too many surprises but it will drag you in.Sounds... well, I didn't know a platformer could have music of this quality.The game play is also original, you don't get to control an inherently flying character everyday in a platformer. The game is much like a metroidvania but with a few twists and RP elements. It isn't hard, isn't a walk in the park either but it's not for who looks for finger breakers such as Ori. Actually I like this better, as I'm not a player with too much time.Controls are quite good. Which is very important because I hate clumsy platformers, and it's unfortuately too common in metroidvanias these days.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												Brilliant so far.I wouldn't consider myself a fan of 'old school pixel art' but I still think this game looks gorgeous.Especially the character sprites with their detailed animations and cute facial reactions are a joy to behold.Story sofar has been very entertaining with characters I immediately cared about and the number of well implemented little twists on the gameplay have made it very hard to put the game down.There were a few intances of background looking like foreground and vice versa, but since you can just fly into it to check (or do a 'faceplant-check' by throwing one of your companions against it : P) and don't loose any 'progress' like you might do in a J&R it didn't feel frustrating at all, just a little bit confusing at times.I think this game is worth a try even if you do not consider yourself a fan of the genre (like myself).-totally not an owl *hoot hoot*

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												The most beautiful and touching side scroller I've played in years. Had me emotionally invested in the first 5 minutes.Incredibly solid controls.Beautiful graphics.Amazing Soundtrack.Absolutely perfect writing.*Final view on the game after completion*Owlboy is an instant classic in this generation of pixel games and platformers. The art is by far the best work I have ever seen in a game of this stature. It is lush, beautiful, and masterfully crafted. I looked forward to every new environment as each one told a part of the story. Embedding the story into the art itself made it all the more enjoyable.Apart from the art, the soundtrack is absolute perfection. A series of wind and string instruments form a masterful composition that captures the immense imagery of flight and wonder that the story takes hold of. From fights to story, the music captures the moment perfectly. Even the lack of music in certain parts of the game build tension or allow the excellent sound design take the reigns for a few minutes.The controls are incredibly tight, and the gameplay follows suite. Everything ran together very naturally, from combat to exploration. It reminded me vividly of rolling around in Zelda games to get places faster. But also provided a unique flying combat that I found thoroughly enjoyable all throughout the game. The platforming, especially in late game, is extremely well executed. This being said, a lot of the game is spent flying, but the parts in between are incredibly well done.The story had me from the first 5 minutes. And by the end had me crying more than I care to admit. It's incredibly well written to the point where I missed twists that were completely unexpected, but made perfect sense. Even the art hinted at these twists and story elements, it was amazing to make the connection between these things. I adore the characters, all of them are fleshed out as much as they need to be and not too much. They have aspirations and goals as well as fantastic and lovable personalities. Even the way they handled Otus as a character was perfection. His body language and personality shined through, making him just as lovable as all the characters around him.If you are looking for a solid 5-8 hours of gameplay, 10 if you plan on collecting everything and finding all the secrets. Which I recommend. Owlboy delivers, with incredible grace. It's worth the price in it's entirety. You get an amazing piece of art and the amazing journey it provides.Easily this game gets a 10/10 from me. I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
Product received for free
												Visuals: Lots of effort and love was put into the animation and level of detail in objects, environments, etc. The "cut scenes" are put together really well, there's no guessing as to what's-what. EASILY some of the best sprite-work I've ever seen.Music: Solid. It helps create the atmosphere the developers were going for.Story: Characters are mostly forgettable, save for Otus (he is the protagonist after all). Story has some weight to it, but often times there's a difference in what I feel (eh) and what the game wants me to feel (despair).Controls: Twin-stick, though it supports WASD+Mouse. Standard 2D Platforming fare otherwise, with flying being really easy to use. Overall, pretty solid, but it took me some getting used to using the LT/RT buttons for the picking-up/throwing mechanics.Gameplay: A bit lacking for my tastes. Not a whole lot to explore except for finding hidden chests and what-not. I didn't find the puzzles challenging. The Boss Fights: some may find challenging but not in a way that tests your reflexes as one would expect from this kind of game. It's more of a "what the hell do I do" kind of thing. Most players should have no issue figuring out what to do, which doesn't leave much in terms of an actual challenge.Overall: Good game, but the drawbacks mentioned above keep it from greatness.A soft 7/10

												This game is BEAUTIFUL visually, and has unique and unforgettable characters. The story is a little short for my tastes but is full of twists and turns. I'd only give it real gripe for some of the actual gameplay where the controls are either hypersensitive or when input isnt recognized right so you take extra damage from dumb stuff.I also wish there was some sort of newgame+ where the game is harder, there are more minigames and the bosses maybe have new mechanics. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												I absolutely can't recommend this game enough.  Beautiful pixel art, gorgeous soundtrack, platformer-style collectables and secrets, loveable characters, and some heartwarming moments for those willing to learn about the inhabitants of the world.The gameplay is its weakest point by far, but by no means is it bad.  Part DKC2, part Zelda, part Metroidvania.  The difficulty is never very taxing, which may be a negative for some, but I felt like it was appropriately done for maintaining a relaxed atmosphere while still pushing against you enough so that you can feel accomplishment with your character.  Some of the dungeon design was a bit annoying.  I frequently would try to go the "wrong" way to grab secrets before progressing only to take the correct route and be locked out of part of the dungeon for an extended period, making it difficult to remember what routes I had and hadn't looted.  Ultimately, getting 100% of the collectibles was pretty painless, though.  The cannon minigame and the (spoiler) snake riding felt pretty awkward, but I guess it might just be another trait (accidentally) adopted from DKC since they feel similarly out-of-place like DKC3's rocket levels.Ultimately, it was an excellent game, and I'd say it's worth anyone's time that likes any of the above-mentioned games or just wants a "pretty" experience.  My playtime logged is a bit over what it actually was.  I idled for a handful of hours while taking breaks and also extended the time a bit while revisiting a bunch of areas to get 100% completion.  Most of my Steam friends logged about 8-9 hours to complete the game.It was worth the 9-year wait.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												This is a game everyone should play. The controls are tight, the soundtrack is my favourite this year, and the pixel art is possibly the best of any game ever released. The difficulty curve is great and there was only one fight that I felt was too difficult. Every single character in this game is lovable and well thought out, from their dialogue to their animation, everything about them is charming. Also I would like to commend the team on how they are taking on speedrunning and bugs. Based on emails with them they have seem to understand that a speedrun community exists that uses OOB glitches while also making sure that these glitches are currently to easy to trigger and are causing problems for casual players. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												One of the best games I've played in years. You can easily tell that a lot of thought and polish was put into every little detail over many years. The artwork alone makes this game worth it. It tries to be a "jack of all trade" kind of game with a little bit of platforming, shooting, stealth, and puzzles - all nicely intertwined with a perfect balance but it's not meant to be any of those things specifically. Although it's not an easy game, it's fairly straightforward and typically after death you'll be able to nail it on the next attempt or two. The story is simple, but feels very real and immersed me somehow more than most games I've played. There was never a time something in the game didn't work right or felt awkward with controls/menus/gamepads/etc... everything just worked perfectly as you'd expect every single time without fail which seems to be sadly uncommon these days. This game is worth every penny.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												This is an amazing game! Probably the biggest thing I like is authentic atmosphere. But really, all aspects of the game are good or great.Overall score: 9/10.Difficulty: Medium.Graphics: 10/10. It's the best pixel graphics I ever seen. Music: 10/10. The soundtracks are nice and original. Story: 8/10. Interesting beginning and middle part, nice plot twist in the middle, but somewhat boring ending.Gameplay: 10/10. Game has interesting mechanics, when most of your abilities are provided by your companions, which you can carry and switch between. Each companion has unique set of abilities, and the game often requires you to choose the right companion for the situation.Level design: 9/10. Each level introduces new gimmicks and enemies, which made levels interesting to play and not getting boring. There are few segments that are slightly repetitive though. Darkness gimmick was quite tedious. Also, I expected final fight to be harder.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												Fantastic game. This is going to be a brief review because I simply dont have the words to describe how good this game is. StoryControlsLevel designArtworkUnderlying lessons and themesRewarding explorationEverything is top notch.And at every bit it leaves you wanting for more.And that is my only complaint. I believe there was some missed chances to explore the beautiful lore and backstory to this game. There is so much more I wanted to know about the characters in this game and the little bits of back story they feed you. I was hoping there would be a greater resolution by the end or that as you explored the game more that you could learn more at your own pace. But the information wasnt offered. And while I loved every minute of what I did get. By the time the game was over I came away feeling a little unfulfilled.Now that being said, maybe it was the intention of the creators to have the game this way. It makes the game have its own niche. In that its one of those stories that gives you just enough to drive you crazy with longing to know more. In a bitter sweet sort of way. And I also kind of got the feeling that as a part of the underlying theme of the game, we arent supposed to know everything. Either way. This is a beautiful game, and I would recommend it to anyone.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												So, let's talk about Owlboy for a bit. I'm sure everyone has seen the stories about how this game took nine years to make by a very small team. It's quite amazing it even made it out, much less that it is receiving all the praise it's getting. Kudos to the team for sticking to their guns.You play an owl boy named Otus. He can't speak at all. He also has a mentor named Asio, who is generally a jerk to Otus. The game ends up centering on many oddball characters, and their unlikely friendships. Two of your companions are actually partially responsible for the bad things that happen to the main owl city, and Otus' hometown. I don't want to spoil the story, but despite a simple tale everything is written very well, and ends up being enjoyable, if quite a bit melancholy.But really, the story isn't even likely the first thing you're going to notice. No, it's those lush visuals. I've seen some "good-looking" games back in the day, but something still felt off artistically with them. That's not an issue here. This is peak 32-bit Capcom era stuff. They've dubbed it "hi-bit", and that's probably a good enough description, because it fits within the rubric of the best 2D Saturn/PSX/N64 visuals. On top of that, the game looks splendid in motion. Everyone has neat unique animations, it's all smooth while being very responsive, the whole game is just a joy to behold. Really, the level of polish across the board is consistent with a Nintendo release, which is high praise indeed.That also extends to the soundtrack. It doesn't use the usual retro-styled chiptune music, it uses orchestral tracks that are excellent, although I have to admit that I don't really have any of them stuck in my head. But it is quality stuff in a filmic way.With all I've said above, you'd think this was one of the greatest games of all time! Not to be the bearer of bad news, but it's not. It's competent, decent, sometimes good, but never really feels like it fulfills its promise mechanically.Otus has full-flight capabilities, except for in a few story-based areas (and water). It doesn't even matter who he's carrying. The sense of freedom is awfully nice, but the world tends to lack for lots of interesting things to do. You can find scattered treasure chests along the way, either through exploration or killing groups of enemies to make it appear. These chests, however, do not contain interesting upgrades, though, but "Buccanary Coins", which can be traded in at Buccanary's shop. You will get a few upgrades out of these, but none of them are strictly necessary. Gated progression is limited to acquiring your three companions. The other collectibles are three Owl Medals that can be used to unlock a hidden area after you've finished the game, which fleshes out more of the story.Geddy is the first, and your default attacker. He fires a fairly weak pistol while carrying him about. You aim his, and your other companions', attacks via dual-stick controls, although there is also some auto-aiming involved here. He can destroy a few barriers, but nothing too impressive. It should be noted that you don't have to constantly pick up and drop characters. The plot gives you a relic that lets you teleport someone straight into your mitts, making what could have been very tedious rather simple.Alphonse, your second character, has a massively-powerful shotgun, but it takes serious time to reload. It will blast/burn down plants and such from your path. The last companion is spider-like, and shoots webs to bind enemies as well as lets you grapple to far away places, which will get you through some waterfalls you can't pass otherwise. That's pretty much the extent of your abilities. Combat never gets very frenetic, with a very limited number of enemy types, and the game tends to be forgiving enough that you'll slide through a battle on your second or third try pretty easily. It just feels like there was so much more interesting they could have done to make combat more engaging from moment to moment.There are also stealth segments. Oh no. Well, actually, I thought these were pretty solid. They're not mind-blowing, but they end up working pretty well, and also reinforce the sorts of odds that this ragtag crew are up against. Plus, there are a few cinematic segments as well, and the last area sees fit to rob you of your infinite flight. This is where the game finally starts to take advantage of some rudimentary platforming puzzles, but it's sadly far too little of it.I can't help but compare the game and its free-flight to two other games, Demon's Crest and Child of Light. Demon's Crest doesn't give you the sort of freedom that this game does in terms of flight, but has much more interesting exploration and combat. Child of Light gives you freedom, and it also rewards the player much more significantly for exploring, always doling out new items and weapons to utilize. In this game, things are a little too straightforward and sparse. There are a few switch puzzles here and there, but they're the usual sort of video game logic we've seen many times before.If I'm going to trot out a comparison to a game, there's actually another one that works, maybe not from a mechanical level, but from a ambition level, and that's Solatorobo: Red the Hunter on Nintendo DS. This was a sort of spiritual successor to Tail Concerto on PlayStation, one in which you got to ride around in a mech amidst a startlingly well-realized world, with lots of polish and charm all the way around. Yet the gameplay proper boiled down to a simple pick-up-and-throw-things. The core just wasn't enough to sustain the experience, no matter how compelling the world-building was. It's a game I wanted to like, but I ended up just thinking it was a'ight. I have the same feelings about Owlboy. It's a spectacular game for content voyeurism. If you want to see amazing and consistent art design in pixel form, this is your game. If you want a polished story, a compelling world, it's here. But the gameplay rarely rises above "okay". And that's a shame. 7.5/10.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												Undoubtedly one of the best games of 2016 and another example as to why the indie scene is so much more imaginative, inspiring, and brilliant than the majority of AAA mainstream releaseas. Owlboy evokes memories of Studio Ghibli films such as Howl's Moving Castle and SNES era classics, but it's very much its own game. The story is fantastic, the challenge perfectly pitched; it's inventive, fun, charming, and a complete masterpiece. My favourite game of the year.

It's quite amazing it even made it out, much less that it is receiving all the praise it's getting. Kudos to the team for sticking to their guns.You play an owl boy named Otus. He can't speak at all. He also has a mentor named Asio, who is generally a jerk to Otus. The game ends up centering on many oddball characters, and their unlikely friendships. Two of your companions are actually partially responsible for the bad things that happen to the main owl city, and Otus' hometown. I don't want to spoil the story, but despite a simple tale everything is written very well, and ends up being enjoyable, if quite a bit melancholy.But really, the story isn't even likely the first thing you're going to notice. No, it's those lush visuals. I've seen some "good-looking" games back in the day, but something still felt off artistically with them. That's not an issue here. This is peak 32-bit Capcom era stuff. They've dubbed it "hi-bit", and that's probably a good enough description, because it fits within the rubric of the best 2D Saturn/PSX/N64 visuals. On top of that, the game looks splendid in motion. Everyone has neat unique animations, it's all smooth while being very responsive, the whole game is just a joy to behold. Really, the level of polish across the board is consistent with a Nintendo release, which is high praise indeed.That also extends to the soundtrack. It doesn't use the usual retro-styled chiptune music, it uses orchestral tracks that are excellent, although I have to admit that I don't really have any of them stuck in my head. But it is quality stuff in a filmic way.With all I've said above, you'd think this was one of the greatest games of all time! Not to be the bearer of bad news, but it's not. It's competent, decent, sometimes good, but never really feels like it fulfills its promise mechanically.Otus has full-flight capabilities, except for in a few story-based areas (and water). It doesn't even matter who he's carrying. The sense of freedom is awfully nice, but the world tends to lack for lots of interesting things to do. You can find scattered treasure chests along the way, either through exploration or killing groups of enemies to make it appear. These chests, however, do not contain interesting upgrades, though, but "Buccanary Coins", which can be traded in at Buccanary's shop. You will get a few upgrades out of these, but none of them are strictly necessary. Gated progression is limited to acquiring your three companions. The other collectibles are three Owl Medals that can be used to unlock a hidden area after you've finished the game, which fleshes out more of the story.Geddy is the first, and your default attacker. He fires a fairly weak pistol while carrying him about. You aim his, and your other companions', attacks via dual-stick controls, although there is also some auto-aiming involved here. He can destroy a few barriers, but nothing too impressive. It should be noted that you don't have to constantly pick up and drop characters. The plot gives you a relic that lets you teleport someone straight into your mitts, making what could have been very tedious rather simple.Alphonse, your second character, has a massively-powerful shotgun, but it takes serious time to reload. It will blast/burn down plants and such from your path. The last companion is spider-like, and shoots webs to bind enemies as well as lets you grapple to far away places, which will get you through some waterfalls you can't pass otherwise. That's pretty much the extent of your abilities. Combat never gets very frenetic, with a very limited number of enemy types, and the game tends to be forgiving enough that you'll slide through a battle on your second or third try pretty easily. It just feels like there was so much more interesting they could have done to make combat more engaging from moment to moment.There are also stealth segments. Oh no. Well, actually, I thought these were pretty solid. They're not mind-blowing, but they end up working pretty well, and also reinforce the sorts of odds that this ragtag crew are up against. Plus, there are a few cinematic segments as well, and the last area sees fit to rob you of your infinite flight. This is where the game finally starts to take advantage of some rudimentary platforming puzzles, but it's sadly far too little of it.I can't help but compare the game and its free-flight to two other games, Demon's Crest and Child of Light. Demon's Crest doesn't give you the sort of freedom that this game does in terms of flight, but has much more interesting exploration and combat. Child of Light gives you freedom, and it also rewards the player much more significantly for exploring, always doling out new items and weapons to utilize. In this game, things are a little too straightforward and sparse. There are a few switch puzzles here and there, but they're the usual sort of video game logic we've seen many times before.If I'm going to trot out a comparison to a game, there's actually another one that works, maybe not from a mechanical level, but from a ambition level, and that's Solatorobo: Red the Hunter on Nintendo DS. This was a sort of spiritual successor to Tail Concerto on PlayStation, one in which you got to ride around in a mech amidst a startlingly well-realized world, with lots of polish and charm all the way around. Yet the gameplay proper boiled down to a simple pick-up-and-throw-things. The core just wasn't enough to sustain the experience, no matter how compelling the world-building was. It's a game I wanted to like, but I ended up just thinking it was a'ight. I have the same feelings about Owlboy. It's a spectacular game for content voyeurism. If you want to see amazing and consistent art design in pixel form, this is your game. If you want a polished story, a compelling world, it's here. But the gameplay rarely rises above "okay". And that's a shame. 7.5/10.

content:
Posted: January 31
												This is one of my best games i've ever played! It is a beautiful and gorgeous pixel art with brilliant sky and the music is a masterpiece for this game, it's all about experiencing the sky layers of heaven and space! Let me talk for a bit! So, when you start the game it's actually very basic and crappy beginning as all games do. You start in a village/town like you just woke up ready to start another crappy day of work then it becomes a relaxing experience of adventuring, like you are finally in freedom, but you also encounter danger! This game felt almost like a movie for me! A masterful experience and a journey into the Unknown. Lore/Story:You're an owl named Otus exploring the vast and immense world of places, puzzles and dangers, with your best friend Geddy also the mechanic of Veille, meeting new friends, encountering bosses and passing various obstacles. It's all about adventuring here, the Adventure era has evolved so you're exploring the future of this world, also, it teaches you to get outside and explore places with your friends, i mean you have plenty places to explore in real life rather than just staying home. Like in this game rather than just staying in Veille and Snapchat or Facetime your friends lol! So, be ready for adventure, pack your bags, get your favourite things and let's go!I wanna say thank you for D-Pad Studio for making such a grateful game and for how long did he take to make this game! Very good lad! This is a Hard-worker! ;)

content:
Posted: April 10
												Worth the decade wait!Pros:Awesome soundtrack - Each piece of orchestral music complements the mood of the scene really well and just sounds real good!General Art Direction- The neo-pixelated art may be somewhat overused at this point but really serves the game well, everything is detailed and quite prettyInteresting and unique characters (Take this with a grain of salt as I tend to be bad at assessing characters and their development)Meh:The story - Not too shabby, by my own standards anyway (Whatever they may be)100% Completion - All achievements and 100% can technically be unlocked within 1 game, but to fully witness everything, you'll need to continue your finished game as you are stuck in the final area which you get the final collectibleEnding - A bit rushed, difficult to understand until you find the sanctuary and even then it's rather vagueCons:Difficulty - I didn't find it too hard at all, quite easy in fact. My only deaths involved running into enemies while trying to complete 100%Length -  Even after mucking around collecting everything, I finished the game clocking in at 12 hours (If I had just went straight for the ending, This would be a 6 hour game)Mother♥♥♥♥ing Boguin Challenge - Controls are reversed such that clockwise is left on the analog stick (or A on the Keyboard) and anticlockwise is Right. Took me more then 30 minutes to collect all the rings even after turning the controller upside-down. It wasn't satisfying at all.All in all, this is a game very much worth the 9 years of development even if there were a few hiccups in between. So, buy it and get a free (not really) Boguin Plush!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												Owlboy is an amazing game. I can't recommend it more highly. I would describe it as a mixture of Contra, Super Mario, and that it has story telling elements that remind me of the Legend of Zelda (ancient lore behind the story, relics, and such). The overworld feels very alive, and you get a good idea of the personalities of many of the NPCs. The gameplay is stellar, and may be on the challenging end for some people. This game will likely, in my view, go down as an indie classic much like Undertale.I would be critical of anyone stating that this game is currently 10/10. This game is nothing short of incredible. The artwork, the characters, and the gameplay is so much fun. That said, some aspects feel unrewarding and some levels are going to feel more like memory based platforming as opposed to reflex based. Some people may prefer that, but I get tired of repeating the same scenes over and over again. Some things happen with so little warning that you have to replay from the checkpoint and remember that it is going to happen. This isn't to discredit the game, but just one of my few critiques. When I die in a platformer/shooter/whatever box you want to put this game into; I want to feel like it happened because I made a mistake and not because I just wasn't given any sort of heads up to respond in time.The only other aspect I would knock is the price range. If this were a $10 game; it would be on the longer end and a huge bargain. $20+ seems a tad steep for how long the game is. I think $15 or so would be far more reasonable. If money is an issue, then I would just keep that in mind. I finished the game in about 8 hours.I would give this game a solid 8/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												This game is an emotional rollercoaster of gorgeous pixels with memorable characters and unique shooter/platformer gameplay.It's an incredible adventure with an intriguing story and setting, there's lots to explore and secrets to find.The writing is charming and had me grinning, laughing, and even crying.The only real downside is that it ends.If you enjoyed games like Cave Story, Metroid, Castlevania, and Zelda, Owlboy is gonna be your jam.Sometimes I forget how good video games can be, but games like Owlboy come along and slap me in the face to remind me, thanks D-Pad studio.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												This is game is a complete masterpiece. I had never heard about it until a few days ago, and I instantly fell in love with the artwork. I had no idea what the game was supposed to be like, I bought it purely because it LOOKED nice. I was very pleasantly surprised to find that it also has a great story, unique and loveable characters, amazing music and sound design, superb animation, and of course fun and interesting gameplay.I've played for about 3 hours so far, and am just now feeling like the adventure is really getting started, though I've enjoyed every minute of it. I was a little worried that it might be short with not a whole lot to it, as these visually impressive 2D games sometimes tend to be, but every once in a while you get a true masterpiece like this, where everything from design to gameplay is spot on, and isn't too short and gives you a lot to do.This is not a multiplayer or open world sandbox with endless replayability game which seems to be the strange requirement for a lot of people in games these days. It is fairly linear with some exploration in areas, finding coins to unlock upgrades, with secret rooms and hidden chests. I honestly miss games like this, that aren't overly complex with upgrade trees and skill sets. It's quite simple, but does a really good job at being simple, fun, and intriguing. I can definitely see myself being satisfied with a sense of completion when I manage to finish it.With all that being said, I think the price is completely justified. This isn't a short random indie game with nothing much to it, it's a full blown story and adventure with puzzles, boss fights, numerous and unique creatures and characters, secrets to uncover, and has amazing artwork. You can definitely tell that a lot of skill, hardwork, and time went into making this. I want more games like this, so I'm willing to help fund the cause of bringing back games with the magic and creativity that we just don't see so much anymore.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												I absolutely can't recommend this game enough.  Beautiful pixel art, gorgeous soundtrack, platformer-style collectables and secrets, loveable characters, and some heartwarming moments for those willing to learn about the inhabitants of the world.The gameplay is its weakest point by far, but by no means is it bad.  Part DKC2, part Zelda, part Metroidvania.  The difficulty is never very taxing, which may be a negative for some, but I felt like it was appropriately done for maintaining a relaxed atmosphere while still pushing against you enough so that you can feel accomplishment with your character.  Some of the dungeon design was a bit annoying.  I frequently would try to go the "wrong" way to grab secrets before progressing only to take the correct route and be locked out of part of the dungeon for an extended period, making it difficult to remember what routes I had and hadn't looted.  Ultimately, getting 100% of the collectibles was pretty painless, though.  The cannon minigame and the (spoiler) snake riding felt pretty awkward, but I guess it might just be another trait (accidentally) adopted from DKC since they feel similarly out-of-place like DKC3's rocket levels.Ultimately, it was an excellent game, and I'd say it's worth anyone's time that likes any of the above-mentioned games or just wants a "pretty" experience.  My playtime logged is a bit over what it actually was.  I idled for a handful of hours while taking breaks and also extended the time a bit while revisiting a bunch of areas to get 100% completion.  Most of my Steam friends logged about 8-9 hours to complete the game.It was worth the 9-year wait.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												One of my favorites from 2016. I can see why some may not like it as it isn't much of an action packed or challenging of a game, but being an artist myself I pretty much just enjoyed the creative visuals and environments rather than the gameplay mechanics. To me a game is fun if the story is good and the visuals are good, not if it was challenging or made me work to complete it. The characters were charming and creative and the attention to detail made my jaw drop throughout each location I explored. I did end up getting 100% completion in the game in around 12 hours or so, which may seem like a short game for some to be 25$, but I got more enjoyment out of it than some games I have paid upwards of 60$ for. I definately reccomend to anyone looking for a visual masterpiece to experience, and for those who are on the fence, it's worth picking up during a sale.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												This is the best game I've played in at least 2 years. The animation is beautiful right off the bat and continues to amaze me throughout the game. The Musical score... Oh my god the musical score for this game is incredible, the music really drives the tone of the game and helps the player feel invested. The story is also good, the characters are loveable and I became emotionally invested in the them 15 minutes in. Game play wise, the movement is satisfying and crisp. It feels so good to just woosh around the overworld. I love puzzles and this game does them well for the most part with new innovative ideas that make you think. Although some of the puzzles get a little repetitive, this game still does a great job at keeping the game fresh and fun the whole way through. This game is fantastic, and I hope it get's the love it deserves.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												The most beautiful and touching side scroller I've played in years. Had me emotionally invested in the first 5 minutes.Incredibly solid controls.Beautiful graphics.Amazing Soundtrack.Absolutely perfect writing.*Final view on the game after completion*Owlboy is an instant classic in this generation of pixel games and platformers. The art is by far the best work I have ever seen in a game of this stature. It is lush, beautiful, and masterfully crafted. I looked forward to every new environment as each one told a part of the story. Embedding the story into the art itself made it all the more enjoyable.Apart from the art, the soundtrack is absolute perfection. A series of wind and string instruments form a masterful composition that captures the immense imagery of flight and wonder that the story takes hold of. From fights to story, the music captures the moment perfectly. Even the lack of music in certain parts of the game build tension or allow the excellent sound design take the reigns for a few minutes.The controls are incredibly tight, and the gameplay follows suite. Everything ran together very naturally, from combat to exploration. It reminded me vividly of rolling around in Zelda games to get places faster. But also provided a unique flying combat that I found thoroughly enjoyable all throughout the game. The platforming, especially in late game, is extremely well executed. This being said, a lot of the game is spent flying, but the parts in between are incredibly well done.The story had me from the first 5 minutes. And by the end had me crying more than I care to admit. It's incredibly well written to the point where I missed twists that were completely unexpected, but made perfect sense. Even the art hinted at these twists and story elements, it was amazing to make the connection between these things. I adore the characters, all of them are fleshed out as much as they need to be and not too much. They have aspirations and goals as well as fantastic and lovable personalities. Even the way they handled Otus as a character was perfection. His body language and personality shined through, making him just as lovable as all the characters around him.If you are looking for a solid 5-8 hours of gameplay, 10 if you plan on collecting everything and finding all the secrets. Which I recommend. Owlboy delivers, with incredible grace. It's worth the price in it's entirety. You get an amazing piece of art and the amazing journey it provides.Easily this game gets a 10/10 from me. I highly recommend it.

												While short, this was one of the best game I've played in a while.  It was shockingly brilliant in both gameplay and writing, and was an unexpected goldmine. Its gameplay is intuitive, lending to little repition, its enemy and character designs are drop dead gorgeous, and its story is a touching tale of pushing past the low points of life. This game deserves the recognition and love that Undertale got, and then some. I reccomend you, yes you reading this, if you have even the slightest ounce of inquisitive interest to play this game, do it. And then share it with your friends. Pros: -- Great musical score-- Great story writing-- Engaging Gameplay-- Lovely graphical style-- Unique through and throughCons:-- Just a bit on the short side, but you'll be playing this game again in time, I assure you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												I don't take the time to write reviews often, but this game hit some heartstrings for me. If you grew up in my era and the SNES is what you remember being the best part of being a kid, you need to get this game. I know the price tag is a bit much, but this isn't some cheap SNES clone that you'll mindlessly play through and forget about. Everything from the gameplay, story, graphics, music, and feel of the game will be sending chills down your spine. It's Zelda. It's Final Fantasy. It's Metroid. It's all of those placed into a neat little package that tells a completely new and amazing story that will grab your by your heart and yank it out of your chest. The best part about it all is how it is presented to you. It's not a lot, and it's not a little. It's the perfect amount of detail to keep you wanting more. I also should mention that they get the feels down SO HARD. It's all about little moments that make you teary eyed, or yell, or smile, or cheer. Everything about this game is what I thought it wasn't going to be and it is hands down one of the best games I have played this year. Do yourself a favor and buy it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												Well, Owlboy has made its way into my top 10 favorite games of all time. After completing the game, I was left feeling a slew of emotions from the result of an amazing story.PROS:Atmosphere: This game's soundtrack along with amazing polished visuals help create some of the most beautiful atmospheres I could ever experience. No detail was left out.Mechanics: The gameplay and its mechanics I found were very easy to grasp and are fun to use. The controls are smooth and very responsive. The game mechanics vary in interesting ways that always gave me something new or challenging to play with.Story: Owlboy is a highly story-driven game, and it is done well. There are a few little side missions and collectibles here and there, but the story takes grasp of most things the player will do. It is beautifully told, and I highly recommend paying attention to it, as it will push you to play more and more.CONS:Game Length: When I play games, I like to explore every nook and cranny. Even with the way I play games, Owlboy only took me 9.1 hours to complete. I wish there was a bit more content to keep me busy as I feel like I blasted through this game, even though I explored it thoroughly.Final Boss Fight:  I did enjoy having to use all 3 of my followers to help me defeat the final boss, however, I felt it was a bit too easy compared to previous boss fights. The fact that I didn't have to fight Mostrom was a bit disappointing as well.

Posted: January 12
												The short of it: Technical issues, pacing issues and a very short run time for price mar a hybrid platformer that controls uniquely and absolutely oozes charm, still probably worth it.The long of it: Despite the long development process, the game is short.  According to steam, it took about 2.5 hours to complete, and a good amount of that was faffing around.  The pacing is very odd even for an indie game- the way scenes cut into one another is more like an animated movie than a traditional game, and you barely have time to get used to your last party member before the game abruptly prevents you from using them and ends.  The characters all have great chemistry and unlike many games really feel like they're all along for the ride, but for the most part there isn't time for much development, especially for the secondary and tertiary characters.  Some of the main character's major conflict never gets resolved, and I feel maybe the ending was rushed due to that.The game itself is a halfway between a twinstick shooter and a platformer, with an emphasis on flying and lifting objects.  In terms of difficulty, there are a few bosses and enemy setups that might make you retry, but for the most part it's a walk in the park and the final boss can easily be beaten on your first attempt.  The flight feels good, the basic abilities feel alright and the teammates are fun to work with, but unfortunately the platforming without them is much weaker.  In particular when you aren't supposed to open your wings, it's quite difficult to avoid doing so due to having to hold the jump and the floaty mechanics.  I also experienced a fair number of bugs- characters teleporting from offscreen to odd places, one strange screen change, and a few times where I collided with nothing after being thrown by spikes.  My friend was also unable to play the game in general, only having a black screen on startup and still hasn't found a fix.  Given the time spent making the game this is somewhat surprising.The art and music are very good, the former being mostly oodles of pixel porn of clouds and pirate ships, the latter incorporating a lot of woodwinds and being very atmospheric.  Outside of the startup theme, I didn't find the music very memorable, but the characters pick up the slack on that front, including the supporting cast and main character.  They don't really have the time for the characters they do have, and a lot of them get more or less forgotten in the last third of the game.So, is it worth it?  Yeah, probably.  The high price tag and short run time is a bit much, but at a lower price this game will offer a unique and satisfying, if brief, experience.

Posted: January 24
												Owlboy is a joy to play and a pleasure to experience. There is nothing quite like soaring through beautiful locales and getting to know a game world through its vivid characters. While the game itself is a little bit on the short end, what is there is a smart and creative 2D adventure game that is every bit as charming as you imagine it to be. And with so many things to collect and places to explore, there is much to do in Owlboy, even if the adventure ends just a tad bit too soon.

content:
Posted: February 24
												It is a nice game. Definitely not a masterpiece like ori and the blind forest, but a nice litte game. Neat art style with attention to detail, a wonderful soundtrack (but unfortunately there are parts of the game without any backgroundmusic) and overal a good platform-adventure. For my taste a bit too much backtracking and most of the time i did not immediately know where to go, not even a rough direction. Admittedly it was my fault, because i fast skipped over great parts of the text dialogs, where i suppose the charactes where roughly telling, what to do next. But i could not really bond with Oti`s (player character) allies in the game / couldn`t care less what they have to say. Also the repeating of dialoge/text scenes, when restarting at some checkpoints (Boss fights) was a bit annoying. Don`t get me wrong, it is a good game, but -in my opinion-  not a phantastic one. At least it motivated me to play it through (roughly 14hours), which nowadays is not common at all (i guess we all know the first world problem of having houndrets of games here in steam and maybe finishing less than 10%)I do not regret buying the game, as it did overall entertaine me for a couple of days.

There's still a bunch of ingame content left like collecting special coins for that glimmer cloak or finding the informational relics. It's a big game for how small the world is!

content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												"A love letter to pixel art..."A love letter it truly is, and I can't find the vocabulary to better articulate how good this game is.It had me laughing.It had my crying.It had me frustrated with those silly Boguins and their stinkin' cannon. I swear I'll beat their challenge one day...Every inch in the game has been lovingly handcrafted and the characters are well-rounded and full-bodied. Some more than others... *cough cough* Alphonse... If one takes a moment to look at the world around them, the area they will find themselves will captivate them; the music that accompanies every beautiful backdrop will seduce them; the story they are a part of will keep them attentive to the end.I've always felt like the games of the past: PS1/2 Spyro, Crash Bandicoot, and Sly Cooper--just to name a few--have always been in a higher tier of quality than many of those in the present and deserve to be preserved and passed down...And I feel like Owlboy is one such game. It doesn't last for very long if you breeze through it, as with any game, ...but if you just take the time to look around and take it all in, even if it's on a second playthrough, you'll notice that the game is perfect in every way.0/11 Would play again.No but for real this game deserves no scale... It's like a blast from the past with the tech of the future. Get the game and enjoy it to the fullest, because you'll never forget it.
