Product received for free
Review of : Owlboy SumarryAfter over 5 long years D-pad Studios finally gifted us with their jewel, and I must admit , it was worth all the waiting^^.Owlboy brought back some nostalgic feelings I never thought I could ever feel again. The game is beautiful, challenging, colorful , fun and a lot of other good things you can think of^^.You play as a mute owlboy called Otus, which due to his deficiency and some lack of confidence isn't as talented as the others, but it starts changing as you visit ancient tamples and get ancient relics that grants him special powers that joined with Otus's friends become amazing!Graphics:The Graphics of Owlboy , despite following the patterns of pixel graphics, feels totally different: bright , colorful, alive. It reminded me of a great game I played in my childhood : Metal Slug. So you can Imagine how good it feels playing Owlboy^^.


Beautiful environment 
A Screenshot of Owlboy
By: [Org.XIII]Chuck Norris




Soundtrack: Here the game pleases me one more time. Playing owlboy is a favor to my ears, it doesn't matter how many times you play the game you don't get enough of the calm, relaxing, beautiful and encouraging songs they composed. Below you can check one of the songs.


YouTube™ Video: Owlboy Soundtrack - Mesos 

			Views: 10,188		

			Official Owlboy Soundtrack: https://jonathangeer.bandcamp.com/album/owlboy-soundtrack-sampler Theme: Mesos Artist: Jonathan Geer Owlboy releases 1st November 2016.		

Gameplay:This category satisfied me a lot as well, the gameplay is fluid, sof, without any delays or fps issues. As mentioned before , the gameplay has an interesting feature that always make you want to progress on the game , because each time you clear a dungeon and find a relic , you get new powers, abilities and companions to help you and increase your power.Owlboy + Companion fighting boss:


Facing my 1st challenge 
A Screenshot of Owlboy
By: [Org.XIII]Chuck Norris




Also each dungeon has a certain amount of coins you need to get in order to receive upgrades to your character as a reward for getting themCoins system:http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=798388860Receiving my reward for collecting coins:http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=798388352Owlboy is a Super cool game, I might not be the most recommended person to talk about it because I have followed it since its announcement in 2010, but I strongly recommend this game. You won't regret I promise , I liked it so much that I felt like sharing my will that you feel the same  through this review. Give it a try , it's worthy !Graphics: 9/10Soundtrack: 9/10Gameplay: 9/10Game: 9/10.D-pad Studio team support: 10/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												Owlboy... Here's some first impressions. It's like if metal slug was an adventure game... But with owls. The art and animation style is very reminiscent of the metal slug series which I've always been fond of. Even the boss battles are flashy, action packed, and quick paced.So far the story line seems enjoyable minus an instance or two where the story line advanced abruptly and dose so in a way that doesn't offer much explanation. Or at least that's what I've noticed. The engagement with characters in the game is very pleasant, and immersive, you'll laugh when they laugh and you'll cry when they cry, so to speak.. The characters are just so likable.Okay the controls are well done, you can tell they've had plenty of time to polish everything out, including the interaction with the world, you can tell that the game was meant to be played with a controller so if you have one, I'd use it. All I can say is that the game controls great and super satisfying to use. The combat is enjoyable however takes a bit of time to get used to.The soundtrack is great, it's diverse yet it fits the theme of the game very well, every moment, every plot twist, the ambient sounds, movement, and combat sounds are also very pleasing to the ears. Most modern pixel games put a lot of effort into creating a decent soundtrack and Owlboy is no exception.I'll probably update this later but those are my thoughts on the game so far.. So far I really enjoy it and I think a lot of other people will, as well.EDIT: Okay I finished it, the game was an emotional rollercoaster but it was fantastic, I'm stunned. The story really smoothed out in the end and I need more of this game in my life.

												Owlboy is a really good game, and for its price, definitely worth a buy if you're into metroidvania-esque games, great characters and generally high-quality games.There are some problems here and there, and even though they are very small, I will list the ones that were most prominent to me:- The percentage of the game during which you're blocked from going back to the main map to explore is quite high, for my tastes too high regarding it's a metroidvania-style game.- Camera zones are annoying and twitchy relatively often.- The controls aren't as intuitive, I suggest trying to reassign button assignments around when you enter the first dungeonI highly recommend Owlboy.

												I love this game so much. It's beautiful, it has an amazing story, the music is phenomenal and so much more. The adventure was just an amazing experience to go through, and I loved every second. The ending leaves many questions, and possibly a teaser to a sequel? There most likely probably won't be a second game following Otus, but if there was it would probably be even better than the one we have now. All the characters are so charming in their own unique ways. Buccanary with her Boguins, all the friends you team up with, even small ones like Mandolyn and such are just simply adorable and a fun time to be around. I'm so glad that I discovered this game, not even knowing it existed until I saw the Game Grumps play it, and then I went ahead and bought it while it was on sale. And man, was it way better to play through this on my own instead of watching some YouTubers play it. You are amazing people D-Pad, I hope you achieve even more greater heights than this one, and I hope your next game goes as well as this one. Hoot hoot.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												When I was younger, I used to adore the old Mario games for their simple comlpexity. The way a younger person like myself could play the game and enjoy it on a simple level, but once I was older I could return to the game and find new secrets and techniques to play the game. Even as an adult I was able to enjoy those games, and it has been nearly a decade since a game has proved to me that a kid could enjoy and appreciate it just as much as an adult could. Then comes OwlboyI had little to no knowledge of this game going in, only that I loved what I saw in the trailer and the promise of "9 years of work" being put into this. I picked it up on day one and I cannot tell you how glad I am that I did so. Merely opening the game and seeing the intro screen made me feel the first sense of childlike wonder I'd felt in years. The art style was stunning even for a pixel game of our day and age. AND THE MUSIC. If the gameplay, story and art didn't steal my heart right off the bat I guarantee you the soundtrack did. When I first flapped my way into the Tropos area of the game and the triumphant violins began their chant I was brought to tears by the sheer beauty of what I was playing. In fact, I don't believe I was crying for reason that the game was gorgeous, but that it reminded me why I started playing games in the first place: Because it made me feel something. Something special. I hadn't felt a sense of wonder like it since I'd played Super Mario Galaxy on the Wii. TL;DR Game made me cry 100/10

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												+++ GraphicsIncredible work on graphics. Varied environments make for exciting exploration.++ MusicWould be 3+, but I feel some of the transitions in music can be a little awkward at times.++ StoryVery good story with likeable characters. I won't spoil anything though.+ GameplayIt's fun, but feels slow at times. Somewhat easy. I find myself mashing the roll button to get around quicker. I enjoy the collection aspect for money, as it gives the player motivation to explore more, as well as giving a clear goal to completionists.- Level DesignNot a big fan of some of the levels. They feel a little maze-like in some situations. I think a simple map may help, but I feel that might take away from some of the exploration aspect. There is a dark section in the game which really made this score drop.Overall ++ Incredible graphics and great music, very immersive, with a good story. Gameplay is pretty fun, really enjoyable if you enjoy casual exploration. The levels sometimes feel bland (just the way you progress through them, the art on them is amazing), and sometimes a little repetetive.I'd say for $25 it's worth it for a player who loves exploration and story.

												Absolutely incredible visuals, and a nice soundtrack. However, the gameplay is weak at best.The bosses are cheap and random, and it feels almost impossible to dodge attacks - the monkey boss in particular just felt horrible. Perhaps I should have been using a controller, but I just found the gameplay really frustrating - not fun at all. They flying felt boring, the attacks were boring, and the recharge time on the shotgun - the only useful attack, is so long that it's impossible to use effectively.The story is sort of interesting, I kind of liked the lore presented, but the characters were weak.It's probably my bad, feeling the way I do. I know the game has got tremendous praise, but the gameplay just leaves me feeling angry and hard done by. This is particularly aggrivating as I would have really enjoyed to explore the world more.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												I just finished playing through the story a few minutes ago and I figured I should share what I thought about this game while its still fresh in my head.POSITIVES:The art and animation is top notch, top tier, top shelf, top gun, top everything.  I can't stop looking at it, there's just so much detail in every little pixelated inch and I can't get enough of it.  All the characters are animated amazingly well and I love Otus' range of emotions despite being mute. The characters themselves are also fun, distinctive and you can latch onto them immediately.Basically the visuals are 11/10, 12/2 even.NEGATIVES:You can really see when this game got to the point where the developers were like "Ok, we really need to finish this."  For those of you who have played the game already, I'm talking about the 5-6 hour mark where there's just a lull in the gameplay and story.  Its servicable, but lacking heavily in comparison to the rest of the game.The collectables are a mix of vanity items and two things that can't imagine going without.  Once you get roughly 2000+ coins, there's no reason to collect the rest unless you want that shiny cloak thing that I bet gets knocked off after you get hit once*.  Seriously, why give you the options of wearing things if they're just going to fly off the moment you make a dumb move and get hit?  I wanted to fly around the entire game with a pirate hat on, dammit!I suppose if you really want that 100% completion, I say go for it as there isn't a lot you need to do, but I don't feel the rewards are satisfying enough.  Unless there's a secret mystery ending I'm unaware of.There's one or two bosses that I felt were a little ridiculous and I found that the only way to do it was to tank what I could and pray that I live.  The other bosses were well designed and you could figure out after a mistake or two what you needed to do.OVERALL OPINION:I really wish there was a "Maybe" button for the recommended, but to reflect what I've said in this review, I would not recommend this game.I would not buy this game for full price.  I honeslty bought it on impulse after trying it on my brother's steam account since I found it enjoyable, but looking back now I really should have waited instead of buying into his hype.  Its fun, if not entirely polished in terms of story and gameplay, and I can guarantee you will be amazed at the visuals presented to you.*EDIT: After being informed and finding out what the cloak actually does, yeah, its kind of worth it, I had just assumed it was a vanity item.  However, I don't believe its necessary, as the item just makes the game easier when its already not that difficult to begin with.

content:
Posted: February 3
												PLAY WITH A CONTROLLER ONLY!I've played the game, found it a pretty game with some intersting level but frustrating and unpolished mechnics.Only afterwards when comparing experiances with another player who played with a controller we realised there are massive diffrences created by the diffrent control schemes.With mouse and keyboard you can't shoot and spin at the same time as they are both bound to mouse left-click , having to drop your 'weapon' to spin, additionally once you drop a 'weapon' you have to choose a new one to activate it where on a controller you just fire and it instantly pick one. Spining and firing in quick sucession is vital to many enemies and having to 'reload' every time after you are hit also makes many fights much more frustrating.This creates a vastly inferior experiance on mouse and no binding options are avialble to the mouse to fix this. The experiance is so diffrent I would not hesitate to call the mouse version of the game out right broken.

												I felt obligated to the developers of this wonderful game to write this. This was one of the few great experiences I have had in my many years of gaming. That being said I don't write reviews for games because I don't think my thoughts on a game should be a selling point for it. But this, to me, isn't just a game. This is a god damn work of art. And I from the bottom of my heart am grateful for being able to experience this.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												This is the first game I ever purchased on Steam and boy, was it worth it.Owlboy is a beautifully animated, atmospheric game with rich, detail-filled story, deep and lovable characters, and music that will absolutely knock your socks off. The mechanics are smooth as well, and boss battles are never so difficult that you'll get stuck forever. If you're a fan of platforming, owls, friendship, exploration, or just gaming in general, you should buy this game!In Owlboy, you play as a mute owl, Otus, who is shunned and belittled by most members of his floating-in-the-sky village. However, when sky pirates invade, it's up to Otus and the friends he meets along the way to stop the invaders and find out the truth behind the relics that the ancient owls have left behind.Pros:-Cute characters-Stunning animation-Gorgeous soundtrack-Captivating story-Large areas and exploration-focused objectives give it an open-world feel-Good length-Plot twists-This is a lighthearted, fun game, but it also delves deeply into some emotional situations. Each character has a rich backstory and a lot of feelings. You'll laugh, but you might also cry! (I did and I'm not ashamed)-Really diverse gameplay. I'm serious. You will never get stuck in a rut with this game. New mechanics, tools, and abilities are constantly being introduced, and every boss encounter is unique. Also, there is at least one fun side quest/minigame!Cons-If you want a super hard game where you have to grind for hours to achieve anything, this is probably not the game for you. But honestly, I can't really think of any cons!Overall, I wholeheartedly recommend this game. I just finished it at 10.1 hours of gameplay and I already want to go back! Owlboy is a delightful tale with a unique narrative and...just go buy it already!

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												Owlboy is cute. The protagonist, Otus, (Otis?) endears himself to you easily. The stylized "Super Duper Ninendo" graphics look great. The game looks amazing in motion, and when you watch it, you're impressed by the world's potential. But it's just not fun to play. You're given too much mobility and firepower for combat to be a challenge. The puzzles are a joke, and you can just rush out of danger even if you get spotted in a stealth section. The boss battles are either rotations of simple concepts only made difficult by the fact that you get thrown around like a rag doll if you get hit, or they're scripted, unfair sequences you just have to memorize through repetition.The soundtrack has nice production values, but it isn't particularly catchy. The level design either has simple, linear progression, or needlessly large areas that aren't impressive in this day and age regardless of the nice art style. This is a sale purchase at best. Just watch someone stream it and you'll probably have a better time.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												It pains me to say that I can't really recommend this game.  It is the best-looking retro-pixel game I have ever played. Every pixel has been painstaking placed, every animation brilliantly detailed and expressive.  But somewhere in those 10 years of development they forgot to check if their game was fun.Maybe its because we've had 10 years of innovation in this market, or maybe I'm just spoiled; owlboy can't really compare to Shovel Knight or Axiom Verge.  Switching out friends to change weapons is gimmicky, moving across the map is trivial.  Controls aren't particularly tight.  Once you start there is not much depth or ramp-up in difficultly as you proceed.  It seems like there is a good story hiding in here but you can only really guess at it even after gathering all the lore collectables and such.Worth picking up if on sale, but as a whole, I'm pretty disappointed in this.  If you're looking for a light-hearted easy game to breeze through, this is a good choice.  Was a good length for this kind of game, but by the end I was bored enough with the main game loop that I was ready for it to be over.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Owlboy is a game developed and published by D-Pad Studios. Owlboy is an adventure in the truest sense of the word. You'll explore, fight baddies, gain power-ups, and make friends all throughout a wonderful world and story. The art direction is gorgeous, the animations of the characters and enemies are fun to watch, the music is a treat to listen to, and the story is a great mix of silly fun, abject terror, and heartwrenching moments. When I say that Owlboy is a great game, I really mean itThat being said, the game is not without it's faults, by far the biggest being it's difficulty, which is all over the place. You'll breeze through some sections of the game only to be utterly crushed by others. While checkpoints are liberal, you'll be tearing your hair out through some sections of the game trying to figure out what to do, and the lack of difficulty options certainly doesn't help. Exacerbating the issue is that while cutscenes are skippable, some mid boss fight conversations are not, and the aforementioned emotional scenes rapidly lose their luster as your forced to watch them over and over again as you die repeatedly to the more difficult bossesAlso, don't be fooled into thinking this is a metroidvania game. While it is heavily exploration focused, and you can be rewarded for revisiting previously visited areas, the game is actually quite linear, and there isn't much reason to play it multiple times if you aren't going for 100% fully finished gameOwlboy is a modern day classic, and other indie developers need to loot to it as a gold standard for what can be done with both the platforming genre and pixel art. Owlboy is an indie classic! RECOMMENDED :)  THEPCGAMER'S BEST GAME IN STEAM LIBRARY! (What's this? :- Like some games get "Best Game of 2014" or "Best Indie Game", etc... So I have decided to make my own!)

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
OverviewYou play as Otus a mute owl as he embarks on an owl-hood defining adventure that will involve navigating through treacherous dungeons. Otus himself has no true combat abilities as he can only stun enemies. This is where his companions come into play. As you progress, you will gain new allies that Otus can carry along with him. Each ally has a unique type of ammunition which has it's own attributes. You can only have one active companion at any given time but you can switch between them on the fly.Take note that, your companions cannot be hurt and any damage you take from enemies / hazards will be reflected on Otus' health bar. You also drop your companion if you get hit. The only way to regain health is by getting 'health pickups' which usually appear as fruit / vegetables? OR by resting. To my knowledge you can only rest at 2 places in the game - your home and a camp fire nearby the town. The game also has no concept of lives. When your health is reduced to zero, you just respawn at the last checkpoint. Yes, this is an auto-saving game. No manual saves here. You can however manually load from the last checkpoint - sometimes useful if you accidentally entered a new area (e.g. boss area).Right from the get go, you are introduced to the game's collectible Buccanary coins. This is not in-game currency as there is nothing you can buy in the game. However, at preset coin thresholds you can visit a shop to unlock trinkets which are upgrades for yourself - increase your max health or for your companions - longer range, improved shot. These coins are littered around the Owlboy universe usually cleverly hidden in the dungeons but also sometimes hidden in plain sight.Issues There is no in-game map. When they said the game features large dungeons they weren’t kidding. When you’re playing through a dungeon for the first time the progress is usually linear because they lock sections off but when you revisit a dungeon to look for any Buccanary coins you missed, it’s very easy to get lost so much so that you might find it difficult just to exit the dungeon.The game doesn’t exactly tell you where you are. Yes, the game displays the area name at the bottom of the screen when you transition between major areas but it does not do this for all areas which quite frankly puzzles me.The boss battles aren’t challenging. The attack patterns are simple and it’s usually obvious what you need to do. The fact that you respawn with full health when you die adds to this problem. The exception to this was the final boss fight (reminds me a lot of Savant – Ascent).Quite a lot of things are left to the player to deduce / observe. On many occasions there were things which didn’t quite make sense or just aren’t explained. For example, in the pirate ship there are switches which are actually for turning off the poison gas. The catch here is the poison gas only activates if you are spotted so you will be left wondering what those switches are for if you were never spotted.The story packs a little too much towards the end. The story became really interesting as the game drew to an end but it would have been really nice if there was more happening in the beginning. Apart from your companions, the side characters like Strix, Fib, Bonacci,etc don’t have much of a role in the game. Missed opportunity: Hiding coins in people’s houses?Art & Music / SFXI think the 'hi-bit' art and music needs no introduction. Feel free to take a look at the videos / screenshots that are available. You can also find some bits and pieces of the soundtrack publicly available on the developer's YouTube / the artist's (Jonathan Geer) Bandcamp[jonathangeer.bandcamp.com] pages. I will only add that the sound effects are really good and many sections / mini-cutscenes have their own music, all of which are really good and help to set the tone with the story.MiscellaneousI’d say 10 hours is a good estimate of the length of the game. It took me 14 hours to complete everything – mostly backtracking through all dungeons to get all the coins. You can skip cutscenes.There are some options controlling the UI (show HUD, show control prompts) so you can tweak some things to your liking.Basic audio volume controls are there for the in-game music and sound.The video options available are - Fullscreen, VSync and Letterboxing.You can remap the key bindings for the keyboard / controller. Note on the keyboard support: Qwerty, Azerty and Left-handed key bindings are available. For controller support you should probably read the Common Questions thread by the dev.Special note: Windows Media Player is required for the game which may or may not be an issue for you. More details here and here. ConclusionIt pains me to say this but Owlboy is not the great game that I hoped for. The weight of expectation after having waited more than 5 years probably has something to do with it. Having said that I agree with what most of the other reviewers have said about the game.The art is absolutely amazing and so too are the music and sound effects. This is where the 9 years of development truly shows.The gameplay and level design could use some tweaks. There something about it in general which leaves me more dissatisfied than satisfied in most if not all situations. It’s especially telling that I enjoyed playing the Boguins’ Cannon Challenge more than the game itself.Long story short : Owlboy is another good game that could have been great.

												I've been trying to think of something to write here since my first hour of playing it, but I haven't been able to come up with something to say. but I'll try anyways.  It's around 10 hours or so (it took me 12 hours to beat), but each minute of it is fantastic.  The gameplay is smooth and fun, the music is so well done, the characters are great, and the art is on a level not really ever seen before in a game.  The levels are really varied, and the game gets so much done in the time it takes to beat.  It feels far more like an adventure than most games that can boast about their length.  I'll admit, I tend to enjoy most games I play, but Owlboy really is something else.  It's worth the money and more.  This really is something special.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												Yes, there are indeed tons of people who have given this game positive reviews. And yes, the few negative reviews probably won't do much impact, and fans will not like this review one bit. But I am alright with being one of the black sheep. Below are my very own personal observations and I stand by them:Just like every platformer lover who also has a soft spot for pixel art, I pounced onto this game. But I am not really happy about what I received.I really wanted to like this work, which took a whopping 9 years in the making, but I found that not so easy. Without further ado, here is a brief pros and cons list:Pros:+Beautiful art indeed+Smooth controls+Enjoyable story+... Nothing else really.Cons:-Very little exploration in a vacant world which could have been detailed a lot more than its current state-Although you get a bunch of allies and abilities, character development is redundant-No sense of progress-Too linear-Upgrades are apparently useless and not even worth pursuing-No obvious replay value. I don't see any reason to complete this game and ever want to play it again.-Too many times the game stops you for a long cutscene or unnecessary effects (was it really necessary to halt the game everytime a robot pirate spots you?)Finally, if I had played this on my 8bit console back in the day, I would have surely fallen in love with it. For a PC game though, I find its sheer lack of depth disappointing. It might be just my nostalgia addiction that led me to the purchase decision. I had been following Owlboy ever since I first stumbled upon the news of its development on some indie website years ago. It stuck in my mind. When it finally came out, I didn't even think twice. Probably I shouldn't have snatched this game so soon. In that regard, the blame is partly mine.In the end, this game taught me one very valuable lesson that I seemed not to get for such a long while: Don't be hasty about a new game. Wait for reviews to come up. And even if the game has received overwhelmingly positive reviews, go ahead and check whatever negative reviews are out there. Word to the wise. Hopefully you are doing just that yourself right now.P.S.: I respect long and hard work, and it pains me to write a negative review for this game, but that is just my unpopular personal opinion right here. Take it or leave it.

content:
Posted: January 27
Product received for free
												My God...Just...Just yes. So...SO much yes. Do yourself a favor and PLAY THIS GAME. It's...it's something else. The Story is all about mistakes. Making them, making up for them, and learning to deal with the concquences of said mistakes. Every memeber of your team has made/makes a mistake in this game and only wish to better themselves by helping you, Otus, the Self-thought, Mute, Town screw up, save everyone and prove to the world, and to themselves they aren't failures. The Characters are very well written, funny when it can be, serious and emotional when it needs to be. There wasn't a single character that I hated, and even ones I did redeemed themselves by the end, relating back to everyone making mistakes. It's nothing Ocsar worthy, but it's something I think everyone would enjoy. I surely did. The Gameplay is somewhat innovative, yet simple. It's a Metroidvania...but you can fly...anywhere. There's platforming sections here and there, but nothing mind-blowing. From the start of the game, with the help of an Owl Cloak, Otus is able to fly around in ALL THEM BOOtYFUL DIRECTIONS. It is a skill you will MASTER by game's end. Problem is, by himself Otus is fairly vulerable. But with the help of his allies, he's capable of shooting, blasting, burning, and zipping through the few dungeons (Yes, DUNGEONS for ya Zelda Kids drooling over BotW) of the game, each with their own neat little gimmiks. The world is fairly small, and well connected, you'll soon get where everywhere is placed. The graphics makes me cream. The detail in the backgrounds, the character sprites, the JUST AMAZING SOUNDTRACK MAKES ME...Feel things. A single screenshot of this game does NOOT give it's beauty justice...It has a Night and Day cycle. Doesn't do anything, there's no special scenes, or different dialouge...It's just there. AND IT'S SO PRETTY. Is it pricey?...Well, Yes...Get it on a deal or something, I dunno, but please, PLEASE, give this game a shot, it's something that needs to be known, in the indie hall of fame.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												I've been following Owlboy's development for at least this past year, and was incredibly eager to give it a try for the art and animation alone.As it turns out, Owlboy is an excellent game in its own right. It seems best described as a side-view Zelda-esque game without a lot of extra padding and unnecessary fluff, but it certainly has an identity of its own. Aesthetics:As anyone can see even from the trailer and screenshots, it has a gorgous, incredibly detailed style of pixel art with some impressive animation. It also has some amazing moments of visual spectacle, especially in certain boss fights. The soundtrack also works very well with the game, and has enough standout tracks to warrant listening to on its own.Story:Owlboy's story is engaging, well-written, fairly unique, and even surprisingly somber at times.There are even several hidden pieces of interesting story and lore to find across the world.Also, robot sky pirates are a critical piece of it. Just saying.Puzzles:The game's puzzles, while not exactly mind-bending, are still interesting and make good use of your party's abilities and the theme of the area in which they are found.The Gunners:The Gunners, which function as Owlboy's equivalent of upgrades or "dungeon items," all feel unique and are useful in both combat and puzzles, not to mention being interesting and enjoyable characters themselves.Difficulty:Owlboy's difficulty isn't especially punishing. I died a fair number of times, but the final boss only defeated me twice. Honestly, the hardest challenge was the Cannon minigame, which is completely optional (if you don't want to be completionist).Immersion:Owlboy also does a remarkable job of keeping the player's immersion, both through avoiding breaking the fourth wall entirely and giving contextual reasons for abilities and decisions that in other games often seem arbitrary. For instance, rather than simply being a typical arbitrarily silent protagonist, Otus intead does not speak because he is actually a mute, a trait which the other characters are well aware of.My one complaint was that the game doesn't convey much of the world outside the little slice of sky you are given to explore. The story is very much contained in this relatively small area, with practically no references to the world outside. And while the characters populating the game's few settlements are interesting, the places seem oddly barren. Even your home village, the biggest explorable populated area, has a grand total of only about 10 houses, 6 of which are only seen way off in the distance, and even fewer NPCs. Don't get me wrong, the area you are given has plenty of interesting details, but the sense of scale of the world is portrayed inconsistently at best.Overall, Owlboy is well-worth the price. Between its incredible art, interesting dungeons and challenges, solid mechanics, and good characters and story, it's an adventure well worth taking.NOTE: In my play time I cleared the game 100%, so at least a few hours of it were spent searching through areas for hidden secrets. I also spent at least an hour or two trying to clear the optional Cannon minigame.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												Owlboy does many things right. The most obvious are the GORGEOUS visuals. I do not think the was a background or character I saw that did not scream how much time, effort, and love must have been put into its spritework. The next noteworthy thing is the gameplay. Simple enough to quickly grasp, but engaging enough to keep you involved with only a few breaks in the fun. The last thing I will note are the characters; developed enough to be more than one dimensional, but not developed enough to feel like there is a deep deep deep lore you can find out just by playing the game. The in game lore is there, but it is vague enough so that it doesn't feel like it is pushing itself on you; which leads into what I feel are some of the games weak points.The first gripe I have with the game; it leaves you wanting more. The game felt short for all it tried to introduce you to, but not quite finish. I found myself wanting more when I would be introduced to a new area or new character. Sadly, very few things are tied up when the story ends. The second and biggest gripe I have with the game; the ending. Without giving away spoilers; the ending feels half full. You never quite resolve a few of the major story points you deal with; some still happening right as the finale is about to begin. I can understand artistic endings, but some people would rather have a full story as oppossed to an artistic ending. I am one of those people. The last gripe is very minor, but still one I feel should be addressed. While I mentioned the gameplay is simple and easily engaging; there are some points, especially late game, where it feels a change or two in mechanics would be appreciatted. Such as including a map to help with exploration, a faster mode of travel (Note, you do get a small form of it, but the distance said mode has isn't particularly long), and the ability to fast travel in the "hub" areas.Overall; despite the gripes mentioned above, Owlboy does an outstanding job of just being a fun game that is nice to look at, though it is not perfect, it is definitely a good game.

												It was decent but definitely not worth the current price of $25 that I paid for it. Wait till a sale and even then there are much better games out there like Ori and the Blind Forest. People have compared it to Ori and in my opinion Ori blows Owlboy out of the water in every aspect.I'm befuddled by the rave reviews this game is getting. It was way too easy, the story wasn't great, the aiming controls can get wonky, etc. It's just not nearly as good as people are making it out to be and was left feeling disappointed.For those who haven't played it yet, beware of the bandwagon effect here. Wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: February 4
												I really, REALLY wanted to enjoy this game, but I just can't. It's probably one of the most beautifully crafted pixel art games I've ever seen, the music is good to great and I like characters as well as the humour.But the problem I have with Owlboy is its battle system. It's simple and annoyingly exhausting at the same time, because the controls are so clunky. And even though you can fly, it never feels like you can actually move fast. After Ori and the Blind Forest showed me how smooth a platformer can be, this game seems like the complete opposite. It's a shame, but I can't recommend it at all.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												Owlboy's not a bad game and honestly it's difficult to give it a thumbs down, but I just found myself really underwhelmed by the game, especially after reading so many great reviews from both critics and players. It's not that I'm saying you shouldn't try it, but I feel like expectations should be tapered a bit.To start with the good, there's a lot of heart in Owlboy. The art direction is great, some of the best pixel art I've ever seen in a game, and the soundtrack really gives the feeling of a grand adventure. The characters have a lot of charm and the game balances humorous moments and emotional moments really well. The gameplay is a pretty standard twin-stick shooter, albeit framed in a fun way where Owlboy carries his friends who are in charge of the gunning. The controls are pretty simple and tight as well, so any failures felt like they were my fault. The gameplay is fun at first, but gets old as the game doesn't really have any "upgrades" to add another element of gameplay past what's initially there. After a while, I just couldn't get myself to keep playing.Unfortunately, I just feel like Owlboy doesn't do anything that some of the top indie games in the past couple of years haven't done better. It sucks, and I'm sure the 8-year journey to develop the game was definitely not due to choice, but I can't help but feel like Owlboy would've seemed so much better were it released years ago like it was planned. It just seems like it was a bit late to the party and the trophies it was going for have already been snatched up by bigger and better games.Again, not a bad game but just not what I was looking for.7.0/10

content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												Owlboy is the best game I've played this year. Every element of it: story, art, music, mechanics, dynamics and aesthetics, is filled with the heart and soul of 9 years of development by some hugely talented people.It is not a game without its flaws, and players who struggle with 2D action-adventure/platformer elements in games will have a frustrating moment or two here and there, but every flaw and frustration is paid off in beautiful scenery, a mystifying soundtrack, gameplay that felt as smooth and natural as it did challenging and fulfilling, and a masterfully paced story that always left me wanting to play on, even after hours of play.Finishing Owlboy was an experience that left me with tears in my eyes and shivers down my spine.Edit: The achievements are fixed! Hurrah!

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												Otus says: ...(He's mute but his expression says a lot)-----------------------The first time I launched the game, I went "Wow! That intro animation." It don't stop there. The attention to details are everywhere. The idle animations, when you run pass a bush or hit it, those animation are very detail. There are so many hidden passages and treasures. The cut scenes are full of flavours. And there is an artwork on a wall that looked like a pe_nis but it's not. I laughed so hard when I first saw it. The pixel arts are just gorgeous. Even a plane wall has so much details. Control is awesome. I tested both keyboard + mouse and gamepad control, for me keyboard and mouse are the easiest to control. Boguins' Cannon challenge is very hard to control though.Music is awesome, blends in and out with the time; music also changed when you are flying or grounded. Gameplay: 9/10 (might be too easy for hardcore platformer)Controls: 7/10 (Boguins' Cannon challenge too hard to control)Story: 7/10 (Story very loose, but sweet moments are nice)Music: 9/10 (dynamic music in boss battles)Artwork: 10/10 (Awesome parallax tricks)-----------------------Overall: 8/10If you are reading this review, don't watch more review videos, don't read more reviews, don't spoilt it for yourself, buy it and experience the surprises. You can thank me later. :D

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												In Owlboy you play as Otus, a mute young owl who ventures off in a heart-tugging emotional adventure about friendship and trust.Here is the video review (or see below for the full written review):


YouTube™ Video: Owlboy Review 

			Views: 3,442		

			Here is our review of Owlboy, one of the most anticipated adventure platformers of 2016. ➥Join our community: www.youtube.com/downwardthrust Owlboy is a side scrolling adventure platformer developed...		

Full Written Review:The story of owlboy is a simple yet warming coming of age tale.  Otus’s Owl homeland gets besieged by airborne pirates and Otus, along with his soldier buddy Geddy and a few other trusty friends, must set out to put a stop to their dastardly deeds.  Along the way you’ll team up with rebellious pirate   tand misbehaving spider Twig, using their abilities in conjunction with Geddy’s to foil the plans of those invading pirates.StoryThe story of owlboy is a simple yet warming coming of age tale.  Otus’s Owl homeland gets besieged by airborne pirates and Otus, along with his soldier buddy Geddy and a few other trusty friends, must set out to put a stop to their dastardly deeds.  Along the way you’ll team up with rebellious pirate   tand misbehaving spider Twig, using their abilities in conjunction with Geddy’s to foil the plans of those invading pirates.Animation & ArtThe first thing that will take you aback in this game will most likely be its refined pixel art.  This isn’t pixel art like we saw it back in the Super Nintendo era, nor is it a contemporary mashup of what most developers consider ‘throwback or retro style pixel art.’  This is sophisticated and tastefully crafted pixel art with all the dressings of high resolution graphics.  GameplayOwlboy’s gameplay is a melange of adventure platforming, aerial navigation and twin stick companion shoot-emup.  With the tap of a button, you can fly freely without any recharge mechanic, as an owl should, and on your own, you may dodge, perform a spin-attack that stuns enemies, and drag select objects around after picking them from the ground. But the meat of the game rests when you pick up your companions.  The game then ventures into the twin stick realm, you’ll be flying with one stick and free arming with the other depending on the abilities of your counterpart.   As such, this is how ability progression plays out in Owlboy - not by purchasing new abilities or unlocking them, but by finding companions and utilizing their skill sets to add to your own.FlawsFaults are hard to find in Owlboy, save for some tweaking that needs to be done to make the controls more responsive. It’s just a tad unresponsive, it’s a downfall yet not a catastrophic one.  Like getting an ice cream sundae and finding you didn’t get enough extra chocolate sauce.  No big deal in the end really. The only other notable thing would be that the navigation can be tricky from time to time as you fly around the hub worlds, discover new areas and unlock barricades on past screens with special abilities.  It’s all a little bit hard to keep track off.  But nothing to mare the overall experience.   VerdictThe presentation, story and character arcs are Owlboys strongest weapons.  You’ll find Twigs story arc particurlly poignant and you may find yourself open to the idea of exploring the deep character archetypes that each character is instilled with.  You’ll make friends, you’ll feel the nostalgia from the obvious Zelda influences and may gush a little when the story all comes together.  And it doesn’t hurt that the gameplay is also refreshing, diverse and satisfying.

content:
Posted: February 4
Product received for free
												Owlboy:~~~~~~ Despite the long, hard training given by his mentor, the famous Owl Asio, Owl-hood has not been very easy for a small, mute owl named Otus. His first flight was not one to be remembered, if you ask Asio. The disappointment on Otus’ face could have be seen from miles away. Well, today is another day, thought Otus before taking his watch over the floating Island of Vellie. It’s a big day for an Owlboy like him, especially after reports of pirate ships flying around the area! You know you can do it Owlboy, you know you can!Owlboy is a platformer / adventure game where you play a small owl, who, with the help of his friends, will have to save the capital Advent from a pirate invasion.You will be greeted by a fabulous piece of orchestral music as soon as you land on the main menu page; it truly gave me goose bumps! As you start a new game you will be introduced to the story, which will also include a short tutorial. Then your character will wake up on the floating city of Vellie, where you will receive your first orders. This chapter is pretty much an exploratory one and will give you a good feel of how to manoeuvre your owl, as well as what to look for in each level: coins and heath items.  Most of the coins are half-lodged into the ground - pull them up and coins will appear. You will also earn coins by flying through rings which are scattered all around the levels. There are a certain number of coins to be discovered per stage. If you find them all, you’ll earn a golden star and it will also contribute to accessing special devices from the buccanary’s shop. To restore health, just pick fruits from trees or pull vegetables from the ground.  As you progress through the story and meeting new characters, some of them will join. One point I forgot to mention - Otus doesn’t have weapons! Sure, he can fly, roll and twist his wings but he can’t shoot anything. He carries someone around who can shoot at enemies. Enemies are pretty fun, lion thingies that spit fire from their mouths, cavemen who throw rocks at you, pirates and their parachute explosives and one-eyed flying green balls, to cite a few. Boss fights are quite tricky here and has taken me several attempts to beat some of them so far.Nice puzzles, however quite obvious in my opinion. The pixel artwork is fabulous and I really like the fluidity of the animations. The soundtrack is splendid - it grabs you from the start. Control-wise, you can use the mouse and keyboard but I prefer to use a gamepad – it’s better, in my opinion. It is quite easy to go through the levels, apart from the boss fights, which are more challenging. Positives:~~~~~~~ -	Great graphics and animations-	Splendid soundtrack-	Responsive controls-	Good story and characters-	Achievements and trading cardsNegatives:~~~~~~~~ -	Needed to be more challengingOwlboy is a very well-designed game with splendid pixel artwork, great animations and marvellous music!9/10Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!EPIC “THE CPT FROGGY” REVIEWS UP NOW ON ZEEPOND, THE HOME OF THE ALMIGHTY FROG![www.zeepond.com]FOLLOW THE CPT FROGGY CURATOR PAGE HERE

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												Before anyone is going to rage at me here for this... I LOVE this game... and i wanted so so so so hard to give it a "YES"... But i just have many reasons why i didnt. I try to do this relatively Spoiler free!This is gooing to be a bit lengthy... so bare with me... i will put a tl:dr at the very bottom of this. 1. The BackgroundThe Background Idea for Owlboy was as it seems aspired by Kid Icarus, Super Mario 3 and has to me at least certain Zeldaesque Elements. The Game was in Development since 2007. Certain points clearly show this... others sadly dont. The Game was created by D-Pad Studio. I sadly never played anything they made before. 2. The StoryThe Story is a very basic "Save the World scenario", not to spoiler too much, There are Very Powerful Relics wich came from a very old Owl Civilisation, they stand in the Focus of Resoring the World, or Destroying it again. 3. The Main characterWe play as a small semi-anthromorphic Little boy named Otus. He seems to be born as a Mute, wich explains why he does not talk. He is shown as a weakling with no real Skills or anything. A Pure dissapointment  for his Mentor. He can walk, Fly, and Dash. Also his main Purpose is to carry around other characters, wich will aid him with firepower, or other gadgets, to make his way through the game possible. Sadly Otus is one of the most... interchangeable characters i have EVER seen in my life. He is a Mute, wich makes him unable to speak, this is perfectly fine and used very well as a story element. Yet Otus never seems to grow during the whole Story... nothing that happens really lets him shine in what he does. He is always scared and always weak. He never stands up for his friends and feels in a lot of cases just like the Taxi for his Party. "Hey Otus, pick me up so i can shoot this enemy there... please thank you! In Zeldaesque games, we at least have the Feel of the Main character growing with the Story. Getting Stronger, getting smarter about what is happening. Otus is just kept very small for the entirety of the Game, Everyone else knows ore, can do more, and is more important for the overall story. 4. The GameplayThe Gameplay is to put is simple... decent. I really liked it, the Controls were a bit wonky at times, switching out your Teammates to solve puzzles on the fly is quite fun. I think the game for what it is... Is a bit too Simple at times... and at other times insanely frustrating because certain enemys just annoy you to fight against (the Beebirds in the Darkness level) because of numbers. Mini Bossfights always follow the same Pattern: 1 Enemy, 2 Enemys, 3 Enemys... and so on up to 8 enemys. That was no fun and got frustrating very soon.  Another big letdown for me were the "final" bosses of each "dungeon" Memorize the very very simple patterns and you are Good to go. It is from WTF to "oh when i stay here, the enemy wont be able to hit me anymore... yay". 5. The GraphicsHere we come to the point where this game truly truly shines... the graphics are some of the most beautifully, lovely crafted Pixelarts you have and will ever see. Every detail is nice and crisp. Truly.. Lovely!6. The ControlsI played this on my Keyboard and the Controls felt very smooth. They do what they must, and they never really feel... "sloppy" or bad. 7. The LengthThe Game Clocks in at about 10 Hours. Very Few Dungeons, no real collectibles, nothing to really power up your character. The Dungeons are on a very easy to normal level of difficulty, and mostly you find the right solution to a Puzzle in a matter of seconds, because the Game shows you anything, and barely encourages you to think for yourself. Making it more of a rush. 8. The ConclusionOwlboy is such a great and lovely game, with so many loveable characters. I would just squeak and hug Solus (another cutie owl) all day and take care of him. Sadly his "plot" twist does absolutely not work with his overall character... but hey... plot twist... guess they can do anything they want in the end. The very short length of the game (for me at least), does not match up with the asking price of CHF 24 (Swiss Francs for me).The Overall character  Progression is for my playstyle very dissapointing and many of the Plot Twists just dont make any sense. To prevent any Spoilers, i sadly cant fully write out what i think of most passages and twists, but this is a review and giving out spoilers, would ruin the fun for many people. 9. TL:DRI would get the game when it is on a discount. As it Currently Stands.... it is too short for the Price Tag and does not offer too many outside possibilities for side Quests. The Game feels like a barebone skeleton to test mechanics, and certain ideas. It does not feel like a fleshed out game. Thanks for reading!

content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												Writing this review sort of breaks my heart.As I was getting close to completing this game, it was possibly one of the best games I had played so far this year, if not the best.Excellent art, controls, level design, story and atmosphere.Then I reached the last stage. And for whatever reason, developers thought it would be a brilliant idea to change the control scheme that worked so well so far (won't spoil how) and use this opportunity to throw a frustrating precision platforming section into player's face. After reading "Stay afloat, Otus!" for the 20th time while failing to reach the corresponding platform, my controller was well on the way to start learning how to fly.Eventually I got past it - no sense of achievement, only anger.Then I proceed to try and complete the one optional minigame. Again, a completely different control scheme from the rest of the game. One hour of fruitless attempts before eventually giving up. No less than half the achievements of this game are gated by completing this (not that I care much but it's really a bizarre decision to give so much weight to this ONE optional part of the game).I am sure I am going to get a lot of flak for this, and yes, I know, "git gut".But if you are amongst people who can't get good enough, you may want to give Owlboy a pass. You will love it for 95% of the adventure, but the remaining 5% will leave a sour aftertaste...It makes me really sad - a couple of design decisions that seem inconsistent with the rest of the game in general were enough to switch my opinion from "Highly recommended" to "Not recommended".

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												Owlboy upsets me because it should be a good game, but it isn't. It has nice graphics and decent controls, both important to a metroidvania, but it is a miss in every other aspect.The protagonist has unlimited flight, so platforming as a mechanic is effectively non-existent. The level design is boring, straightforward, go from point A to point B with a few puzzles scattered about to prevent you from blazing through the game at full sprint. There are very few secrets and no reason to explore. Enemies exist solely to present an obstacle and drop nothing, no money, no items, not even health or powerups. That could be forgiven if the enemies were interesting or tough, but the only difficulty any of them present is due to your limited options, not their cool powers. The gadgets you unlock with the coins you do find are mostly worthless: other than lifeups, it's just useless hats and an almost unnoticeable upgrade to each of your companions.If you're a metroidvania fan, Owlboy simply doesn't measure up. If you are new to the genre, start somewhere else.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												This is by far one of the best games I've played recently. BEAUTIFUL art, a lovely orchestral soundtrack, fun and well-designed gameplay, and clever level design. For folks who are into completionism and 100%ing, there's a strong collectathon element as well. There are also a few hidden secrets, reminiscent of classic 90s games; however, don't get me wrong, this is overall a modern game despite some classical elements. I'm a major sucker for nice pixel art, and Owlboy most certainly delivers on this score. Every bit of this game clearly had a lot of love put into it. Color choice, character design, just... unf. Love it, love it, love it. This game is what modern pixel art games should aspire to be. The soundtrack is just as lovely as the art; it gets a little extra appreciation from me given the amount of oboe featured! The characters and storyline are enjoyable and fun. Our main cast is made up of a mute owl, a friendly (but sometimes a little judgemental) engineer, a poetic pirate, and a wannabe spider; each has their own backstory and character growth. There are quite a few optional opportunities to learn more about each character, in addition to the main plotline. Each one is loveable and quirky in their own way. I also feel as though the somewhat ostentatious and gaudy shopkeeper, Buccanary, deserves an honorable mention in this category. Especially at the end, the game can hit you with a few nice, emotional punches as well. One moment at the very end comes to mind in particular, but unfortunately, it's extremely spoilery. The gameplay is a nice blend of puzzle-solving, platforming, and Tanooki-suit Mario. While the first dungeon has a fairly simple feel to it, it's clearly meant to be an introduction, as the future dungeons change things up in fun and sometimes novel ways. Everything from grappling puzzles to traditional platforming are featured. Even if it's not revolutionary, none of the gameplay feels "stale" or cliche. Everything is polished and fits well in the context of the game. I highly recommend this game, overall. Well worth the full price, to me!

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												It's no Shovel Knight, and it's PAINFULLY short for the asking price (7 Hours on my end, and I wasn't trying to speed run), but Owlboy tries, and more-or-less succeeds to overcome it's short-commings and gutted story with sheer love and dedication. But buyer beware; if the game's art style doesn't charm you immediately, you're in for an expensive diversion. Long Form: Keeping with the trend of 2016 video games, Owlboy's conclusion will leave a lot to be desired. The game plays well, though it's occasional obsession with having you navigate blind through pitch-black spike trap room is just bafflingly poor design. The game was in development hell, and it clearly shows, both in the bizzare pacing (The Primary Antagonist is never fought, despite having all of the spritwork done for an actual battle, there's an upgrade for a weapon that, by the time you can afford it, will only be useable once) and in an almost pointedly avoided Three-Magic-Items quest that seems to be happening for the villians more than for you. But Owlboy is a light game, with a surprisingly heavy asking price. It's conclusion does not leave a good taste in the mouth, and there's precious little to recommend beyond the eye candy and the lovingly realised characters who, if not exactly genre defining, are at least fun and inoffensive. Owlboy is inoffensive, which is the best I can say for it. It digests easily, passes quickly, and will be forgotten about within minutes of completing it. Let's hope 2017 shows us some games with actual, realised endings.

The game isn't plain bad, and that's why I'm still recommending it, but ...* The story is rather boring* The characters are annoyingly immature* The Dialogues are a pain and you'll find yourself trying to skip them most of the time* The gameplay just feels wrong, from the way you decide to fly in the middle of a jump to the way you bring your partners to shoot at your ennemies. Everything feels rather rough and clunky.I am still going to push to finish the game, because I still think it's worth it, but beware before picking up that title : it's far from a perfect ride.Edit : Now that I have finished it, I come back to it. The gameplay towards the end of the game is getting even worse by its inconsistence. Characters contradict what we've seen from them in-game even right at the end of the game. The game is quite a disappointment overall. I wanted to like it, but that is far too painful overall, I'm switching my recomendation from "yes" to "no".

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												Beautiful art, silky-smooth controls, and the charm of a Studio Ghibli film. Although cinematic sequences can feel over-long, they play out like little vignettes and rarely feel cheesy.Going into Owlboy, I was worried it might come off as cloying or twee, but the tone feels about on par with a Zelda game, and it's got a surprising emotional depth to it. D-Pad studio pushes each pixel to its storytelling maximum, and Otus' animations are stunning in their cartoonish authenticity.With Owlboy, D-Pad studio has created something that's practically beyond categorization, with elements of twin-stick shooters, shoot-em-ups, platformers, and Metroidvanias all rolled into one cohesive package. The level design never feels cookie-cutter, and each area provides a whole array of new challenges that defy comparison in the hi-bit indie genre.This game, to me, is a must-play, and one of the finest that 2016 has to offer.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												A competent platformer with amazing art.Considering the hype around the game, I may have gotten my hopes up a bit too high, because while I find Owlboy worth playing, it's just not up there with the best platformers to me.The art is fantastic and is by far the best thing it has to offer. If good pixel art is all you need to play a game, just stop reading now and buy it.The rest of the game is just "solid". The music sounds like a greatest hits collection from other games, but has no real identity of its own. The combat mechanics are fairly weak, but they take advantage of things when they can. The control scheme is just way too complicated, and the difficulty of combat comes from fighting against the controller, not the enemies on screen.Tehnically it runs fine for me, although for some reaon it totally chugs in windowed mode to about 20 fps. It has some very minor issues with my 21:9 monitor in full screen, where overlays don't extend far enough to the edges and slight sprite pop-in is present at the edges. There is no option to change the screen resolution, which would have let me fix it myself, which is annoying but ultimately the minor graphical problems aren't game breaking.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												What defines a good game?Storytelling?Level Design?Visuals?Well. you'll find a lot of that here in Owlboy.Let's start off simple, the Visuals. Owlboy is very Visually appealing. Every sprite looks crisp and clean. and fits into the world around it. The visals for the Floating Islands are just beautiful. Most importantly however, is that every character's design fits in with their personality. Overall, the Visuals are enough to pull in anyone who's a fan of the 16-bit Era of gaming. And maybe even some who aren't. Level Design, What makes a good level? Well. I tend to look at the 'Mega Man' Formula when it comes to level design. where you Introduce one gimmick at a time. and then expand upon it. And this game does it brilliantly. You never feel like you're thrust into situations unknowingly, without having prior experience with a GImmick to an area. (Although there are two exceptions - Which I won't get into here as they are late-game spoilers, All spoiler things will be at the bottom of the Review past 'Final Score') Enemy placement never feels unfair. If you take a hit, it's your own fault. and that's something I can get behind. Oh, and do you like Secrets? This game has plenty of little Secret rooms in which to find Collectibles. Another thing is that every room in the game's dungeons has some form of Puzzle to it. Be it simply dropping a block on a Pressure switch, or sneaking past enemies who would otherwise easily overpower you.Storytelling. That's the big thing, What's the story about? How does it reach it's end? Well, as the Spoilers are at an end I won't go too in depth. but the Story progresses like a novel. you have an Opening part where characters are established, then Conflict. then a solution. and then a bigger conflict pops up, then a solution, and a conflict. and then the climax in which the solution ties solely into the solutions for past conflicts. The storytelling is great - Although the game does suffer slightly from being an Open World. the story can say "You must rush to point A." And you can go off and find collectibles for two hours. and then stroll over to point A to continue the main plot. Also, be prepared for Feels, as this game will bring you on a small Rollercoaster of emotions. Not that that's ever a bad thing in a Story-driven game.Overall Scores.Visuals: 8/10 - I Personally adore the Sixteen Bit style of games, always have, always will. it's not for everyone.Storytelling: 9.5/10 - This game's storyline had me so interested, that I completed the game from start to finish in a single sitting.Level Design: 7/10 - The Level Design is overall good, however in some cases the 'Stealth Sections' you're introduced to can slightly irritate. Another slightly frustrating moment happens later on in the game - See 'Spoiler' Section below.I cannot recommend this game enough, It had me hooked enough to complete it in a single sitting. I recommend that anyone who loves this sort of thing do check this game out. It's one of the best games I've played since Dust: an Elysian Tail.~~Spoiler Section - Be Advised~~Level Design Complaint - Surfing the Robotic Dragon/Snake/Wyvern thing. Acting fast can be a problem for some, Especially when you can only move up and down in about five set places. this can cause you to scrape your head on the ceiling repeatedly. Which is painful, even at the Maximum Health Bar.Storytelling Spoilers: The protagonist is a mute who - despite all he does to try and help, messes up more often than not (Sometimes even just percieved as messing up by his teacher), So his teacher scolds him, Saying various things like "I am Very Dissapointed in you." "You're the worst student i've ever had" "Don't let me catch you coming back here." Also, the Ending. My god. the Ending, I'll keep spoilers low - Even if this is the Spoiler Section - But my god. that was such a Bittersweet sort of Ending. a very much "But at what cost" Type of ending.Also, Watching that Tin Soldier get vaporised when he's been built up as an unstoppable wall of Metal and Strength. so satisfying. Thanks devs. c:

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												I am not very far into this game so I can't say much about the over all story but what I can say is this;      Owlboy is a "platformer" that will go down in history, I think. The animation is superb. The emotion that these 2d sprites can evoke is phenomenal. The general atmosphere is truly something to get lost in. While at first, I was getting some Fez vibes which, say what you will, can be a good or a bad thing, but very quickly I started to notice that that would not end up being the case. Characters have motive and purpose, and the setting is purposely set quite differently to the tone of the games characters. It's written much more like a good film from Pixar than it is like a typical platformer. I can't say yet whether it's worth the price tag but with the time and effort put into it, I can't really say there's any going wrong with buying this game. There is a lot of love behind it and it's easy to see. It's absolutely not for everyone but everyone should try it, nonetheless. Maybe it'll make a convert out of you.    I'll update the review as I get further (probably)

												Owlboy is definitely a love story to old school platformer games, but it's also not entirely trying to be a retro throwback here. It very much has it's own unique style of gameplay, and it's fun!  The art style is beautiful. It's not just another pixel art game, it's up there with the cream of the crop in terms of visuals. I have so far only played through the very first part of the game, but I'm hooked, and definitely looking forward to more!You can see my playthrough of the beginning here:

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												Gorgeous game with fun characters and amazing music. A few issues with the gameplay here and there, namely a couple of repeated sections and wonky controls in a screen or two, but I still enjoyed it immensely. Difficulty-vise it's neither too hard or too easy, and almost all of the stealth sections can be completed without being stealthy at all. You get rewarded for collecting as much money as you can in form of powerups, which is much better than just getting an achievement. It also sports a lot of puzzles that wouldn't feel out of place in a Zelda game.The writing is probably what blew me away the most, and it has one of the strongest endings I've seen in a long while. It has its flaws, but I couldn't recommend this game enough. It has 9 years of work and care put into it and it really shows.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												Okay, so I clicked that I recommend the game because there's not 'recommend with caveats' button.Let's get the obvious things out of the way: Owlboy is gorgeous. The art is top-notch, the music is fantastic, the attention to detail in the smallest custom sprite animations, etc, is stunning. Moving around the rather unique game world feels fluid and natural. And over all, Owlboy is an okay game.Yeah, just okay. And just kind of... a game. It's vaguely a twin stick shooter. It's a bit of a metroidvania, a bit of a puzzler, sometimes a set-piece stealth game. It doesn't really have an identity. It doesn't have unified gameplay, and it suffers for it. It feels more like a sequence of things to do than it does a game. A few of the boss fights are solid, but over all, the gameplay is bland and the sequences wear out their welcome all too fast. It's an 8 hour game that could have been 4 hours long without losing anything.The characters are not especially evocative. A few side characters here and there are charming, and most of the characters have a shining moment or two, but they never come off as particular distinct or likeable, nor do they have fleshed out character arcs. The story has its ups - a very stunning moment or two - but like everything with Owlboy, it's too thin. It's mixed in with hours of little-to-no story but also little-to-no gameplay.The game has wacky difficulty balancing. Sometimes, it feels like a kid's game, almost insultingly easy, then a sequence will slam you with incredibly precise timing and instant death punishments. Sometimes, in the game's lack of identity, it becomes very, very unclear what exactly the game wants from you. And while the movement and jumping and flying are very smooth, you spend a lot of the game cycling between companions that you have to carry about to use their abilities, and switching between them/lifting and dropping them is a bit of a headache. It functions fine for the Lost Viking style puzzles, but when suddenly you have to switch between them and activate their abilities back and forth during a hectic boss fight, it gets unacceptably muddy, especially for a game of this production quality.So, do I recommend Owlboy? Well, I don't NOT recommend Owlboy, but it's not an art piece game that will leave you thinking, and it's not a story game that will leave you interested, and it's not an action game that will leave you adrenalized. It's just sort of a pretty thing to look at and experience and then go about your day, mostly unaffected.It isn't a bad game, but it's just sort of a game.Blind playthrough viewable here:

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												Owlboy is a beautiful, retro-inspired platformer that delivers fun and emotional story telling, a neat twist on platforming, and wonderful roster of characters. The gameplay is reminiscent of a more linear Metroid. This game does SO much right with just a few minor, albeit annoying, flaws slipping through the cracks. First off, this game is gorgeous. It totally captures the snes age, retro feel but with modern day pixels. Sprites are well designed and the landscapes are intuitive and fun to explore. The gameplay is very fun and pretty unique and discovering hidden areas feels very fulfilling. The buddy characters add a lot of dimension to exploration and combat and the teleportation mechanic is very well done. Iinitially, I was a little disappointed with the runtime. I beat this game from start to finish, while in no particular rush, in 7 hours. However, those 7 hours were so packed with content and fun I really can't complain. The pacing is top notch. There were multiple times where I intended to play for 30-45 minutes and ended up playing for 2 or more hours. The story really chugs along and gets you invested right off the bat. I highly recommend this game!!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												Owl boy is like that blonde cheerleader from high school: you wait ten years for your chance to be with her, but, when the time comes, she's nothing but a pretty face. Owl boy is absolutely gorgeous. I'd read reviews, watched youtube videos, etc., and was well aware going in how pretty it was supposed to be. Nothing prepared me for the first zoomed out shot of the overworld. Jaw literally dropped. Then I started playing. Then I started waiting for it to be good. Then I started praying it would evenutally become good. It never did. Just like the blonde cheerleader, owl boy is gorgeous and overflowing with charm, but it doesn't have a single inch of depth. 90% of the game is spamming 'roll' to get around the map and holding the left mouse button. That's it. It never advances beyond that. Even the intermittent stealth scenes are just spamming 'roll' to move from obstacle to obstacle. That's it. No strategy, no skill, no challenge. The occasional puzzle and loads of spam. The emotional payoff of having a mute, mostly unrelatable protagonist doesn't payoff until the last scene. It's not worth 7 hours of playtime for a one minute cutscene of emotion. I hate every word of this review because I wanted so badly to enjoy this game and be able to support the indie devs putting in the hard work to make games we crave. But, sadly, this is even more lifeless than AAA action FPS games. I would not call this adventuring, platforming, or even 'tactical twin stick' as I have seen it described. D-Pad studio obviously has talent and knows how to make a game look good. I think they just forgot gameplay along the way. I want to say they forgot to have their game beta-tested for the 'fun-factor' before committing to it, but I doubt that's the case.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19
												Owlboy was a game I honestly expected to be the big indie darling of the year. It looked fun, simple and beautiful. I was very ready to watch a brand new indie mascot emerge and hang with the likes of Meatboy, but sadly I feel Owlboy will be a soon forgotten character. It's visual art style is one of the few interesting parts of the game. Gameplay and overall game feel are terribly bland by comparison.Owlboy starts off in a lovely little town full of characters to talk to, houses to enter and small places to explore. This set a great tone for the game almost like that of a Zelda adventure, but it doesn't continue on this path. Although it continues to expand the lore and allow you to talk to a bigger cast of NPC's as you progress through the game, it starts to become a nuisance. I have a huge problem with the amount of exposition presented in the game. Most indie games with interesting lore (or even AAA games for that matter), give you the option to dive into the deep expository elements of the game. The key word is option. Owlboy chooses to make the story of the game unavoidable, with a false sense of importance. Especially for a game so short, I just don't care about the finer details of the 'owl lore'.The gameplay doesn't make up for this expostion overload. It lacks variety, despite seeming like it will have some with multiple companions. The game suffers mostly from a slow pace. The games flying mechanic is great at giving a sense of freedom, but the pace severly stunts this feeling. You'll be spending most of the game auto-targeting enemies and mashing the shoot button, with the occasional stealth section oddly enough. The game lacks any serious upgrade feature, and the shop acts mostly as a way to track your collectables. The few upgrades you do end up receiving happen later in the game, and judging by the difficulty of enemies and bosses, you wont really feel the difference. Most enemies are quite easy, and there's no real penalty for death.To end on a high note, I must stress how great the art style of this game is. The environments are always new and interesting, the characters are cool and well designed, and the game mixes a good variety of light and dark tones. I haven't seen an indie game in quite sometime that  has such a solid art design as this. It has no gimmicks and it serves no ultimate purpose to the gameplay. It's just beautiful.With all of this said, I hope to play future D-pad Studio games and enjoy them, taking the faults of Owlboy into consideration.
