content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												This game is a game that starts so well and I want to like it so badly but i just cannot. The graphics are really great they add so much to the game.The story starts really interestingly for first 30 minutes but it soon becomes really bad same with the characters at first you feel like this might be a platformer that has characters and story like monkey island but they soon lose their charm.I am on the last level of the game currently and I just want it to end and i have felt this way for most of my time in the gameThere are occasionally really great moment but they become more few and far between the more you play.Most of the game is ridiculously easy but there are some certain difficulty spikes at times that feel like they are there just to prolong the game. Some of the bosses get really annoying and certain platforming and puzzle sequences get frustrating. I dont play a lot of platform games so this might vary from person to person.I find the controls work well sometimes but when they dont work they really make you mad. They are quite clunky but there are parts where you need to jump, or do a prolonged jump or to jump and fly which all use the same button and it just doesnt work well often its hard to beat a platform difficulty spike area just because the controls are working against you.I think people review this game on how good it could have been rather than how good it actually is.Also in certain sections, usually around the difficulty spikes it makes you have to go through a cut scene type thing every time before u do the awkward bit. Yes you can mostly skip the cut scene but it takes time and it just prolongs the time it takes to get you back trying that part again.As well as that the cut scenes and dialoges often totally break the flow of the game.Overall I somewhat enjoyed some parts of the game but most of my play time I found either bored or frustrated.For me the price of this game is nonsensical. Steam price is 22.99 as of writhing this but it is in no way worth more than 4.99.I have played around 12 hours of this and probably enjoyed one or two of them. I do regret buying the game and i even more regret the time i put into it.Yes it could be great and yes at times it is great but for the most part in my opinion and experience it is not very good and way way way over priced. Dont believe the hype.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												I'm nearly 5 hours in and the graphics continue to wow me, the controls take a bit to get used to at first, especially at the start/intro.Regarding combat: You're practically thrown headfirst into dealing with some basic enemies, but you are treated to a gradual learning curve by your own admission... without any tutorials about it. I can't explain it, you just seem to slide right on in and your own intuition takes over.This is NOT a bad thing as it's not too easy or too difficult to work out on your own, you may be defeated a few times and you'll actually eventually learn from your follies, but you won't give up through difficulty-rage; neither will you feel disappointed because it feels like a cakewalk... it feels JUSSST right so far.The enemy confrontations play out like a 360° bullethell/shooter game like Megaman at times but with amusing and rewarding twists... don't get me wrong though; the game isn't all about shooty-fighty-boom-boom. It has moments on par with other great story based 2D platformers as I mentioned and referenced in my previous status... and dare I say -- it sometimes shares the same kinds of humour and intriguement as Monkey Island and Final Fantasy respectively when you least expect it.The storyline is gripping so far, the music is somewhat forgettable but the characters are definitely not.It's crazy that this game took 9 years to develop, starting from 2007 and only released since the start of November this year - because of that, there is some frame lagging/refreshing when it comes to traversing wider parts of the world but only when houses are involved on screen... it's hardly a problem and doesn't ruin the experience, I'm very sure they will fix that in patches with time to come.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												While the core gameplay can be fun, it suffers from the developers and testers being too good at their own game and ramping up the difficulty (although it only took me two attempts at most to get through any area I had trouble with).This, however, is something I can forgive, but what I can't get passed is the fact that 90% of the NPC dialogue spoken to or about the main character is nasty or belittling, often being outright lies. This nasty dialogue is often unskippable, and is often long winded. If you had some way of reprimanding these NPCs, that would be fine, but they are characters that you're fighting to protect, and you have no way of interacting with them other than to talk to them to receive their scathing disapproval.All in all, it's a really demoralising experience, and I have no motivation to pick up the game and continue, knowing there's just going to be another tirade of nasty remarks coming my way despite completing objectives and defeating boss monsters successfully. It's such a nasty contradiction; play the game well and you're rewarded with mean and nasty people telling you you're worthless and useless. Consequently, I've sought a refund for this nasty waste of time.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												I saw this game pop up on steam and youtube recently. It looked pretty good, but I never bothered to give it a go. Bored one day, I picked it up and gave it a whirl.And boy, what a whirl it was!Owlboy is a platforming/puzzle game with so much charm it hurts. I loved it from start to finish and I honestly can't think of any negitives about Owlboy.It has a nice story, a atmospheric and beautiful soundtrack, characters with boatloads of personality and a enviroment that looks so good, each screen is an absolute treat to the eyes. Controls are fluid and combat feels great.In terms of both it's structure and visuals, this reminds me a lot of Cave Story, a much loved game. If you like Cave Story, you'll like Owlboy too.While in Owlboy's story nothing particuarly blew me away, not even any reveals (that I won't spoil). There were some heartening scenes near the end which were lovely and I wish I could experience again, but I never really said "OH SNAP!". It was a pleasent ride regardless.Enough rambling. BUY IT ALREADY!

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												In the passing years since I’ve started writing about games, I have been loathe to refer to any of them as “charming”. It just feels like a cop-out adjective: something that could very easily be applied to any number of indie games that put a heavy focus on character, story, and a friendly or sometimes melancholy atmosphere. There have been a ton of clever, inviting indie games that have been released in the past decade, and an endless stream of them could use that forbidden adjective. Shovel Knight, Firewatch, Minecraft, Spelunky: the list goes on and on. “Charming” just sounds simultaneously lazy and condescending, and I’ve tried to avoid it.But here today, I am forced to use that word when it comes to Owlboy. Because no other word encapsulates the feeling I get from D-Pad Studios’ indie platformer better than that troublesome little moniker, so let’s just get right into it, shall we?Owlboy is charming.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
												This game looks very, very pretty.Pretty much every other aspect of it fails. The story is VERY weak, and pretty much drops the ball in trying to make the world around you feel fleshed out and interesting. The game plays a lot like a simplistic Zelda, and ends roughly at the story point in which Zelda games go to their second half. The gameplay is very superficial, and mostly involves spamming your dash a whole lot to make the game move faster, along with shooting unsatisfying weapons. The game also loves to wrestle control away from the player in order to force him to go through ♥♥♥♥♥♥ dialogues and cutscenes.I finished this game and was shocked at just how little there was to it. That 6 hour completion time is misleading, as I had to restart around halfway through, having lost my save the first time around.I do not recommend this game, as it's extremely overrated.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
												TLDR; pretty, frustrating, bland and inoffensive.This is a game where every platformer trope has been taken wholesale and cobbled together in an inoffensive and cliched manner with the single exception that the main character can fly. There was never a question of "should we put boss fights in the game?", the question for Owlboy was "how many can we cram in there?". A boss fight has never been fun in a video game it wasn't fun doing the same fight 20 times in the 90s it's still not fun now.Also: collect all the coins to unlock all of the upgrades? Hunting for coins behind secret walls is not a suitable replacement for content. I did not get all of the upgrades because the game was already frustrating, and the game was made all the more frustrating for not having the unlocks they provided.The controls are frustrating at times, the dodge button cannot be pressed at the same time as aiming, leading to a lot of frustrating clusterf**ks with many trivial (and they are almost always trivial) enemies on screen and you having to devote your thumbs to either killing them, getting hit a lot in the process, or dodging their attacks. The inability to do both left the game feeling clumsy and poorly thought out.Another bugbear with controls is that there is a dash button that makes travelling through the spacious game MUCH faster. So I played this game constantly mashing B just so I could get through it quicker. There's no excuse for this, it's just dumb game design.There's also the matter of the few scenes where the game requires a lot of precision for platforming sections where your flying ability has been hampered. These sections would benefit greatly from having fine control and precise input, alas if you have a controller plugged into your computer at all you cannot use the keyboard because for some reason it disables the jump key. Bizarre.There's also no fine control. So you are better off using the DPad rather than a joystick most of the time. If the joystick is a little left, it's the same as pushing it all the way to the left. Stupid.The story is middling. Standard "bad guy wants to end the world because reasons" tropes abound. The characters are distinctly individual but I found very little reason to actually care about them.The protagonist is mute because all protagonists are mute. Nothing new to see here apart from the bullying the main character gets for it.At many points in the story I got very lost, owing mostly to previously completed level sections being explorable again without any warning that you've been there before. By the time I realised I had already explored that section days before (and forgotten because it all looks the same) it was another 10 minutes of mashing the dash button just to get back to where I started.The art style is absolutely lovely and it's obvious a lot of man-hours went into it; if the devs had spent as much time on having a vision for their game and sticking to it rather than making concessions for every man and his dog then they might have created something really special.As it is, I can't recommend Owlboy as anything other than a very pretty, thoroughly samey platformer that will appeal to no-one and offend no-one.

Posted: November 28, 2016
												This game was 10 years in the making and it looks gorgeous. The pixel artwork is fantastic and they took great pains in animating all the stuff. Absolutely phenomenal artwork. But sadly artwork does not simply sell a game. This game has done nothing innovative in terms of gameplay. The gimmick here is that it is a platformer but you can fly. The main character can fly and has a spin attack and a dash attack which I think was only useful to break some walls. You can carry your pals one who has a shotgun and can burn things,the other who has a gun which shoots pellets and the third who has kind of a websling. You get these pals are various stages of this 8-10 hour game. So they basically shoot for you and the controls use the mouse to shoot,WSAD for movement and double pressing W makes you fly. The level design is average at the most with you mostly shooting enemies and solving very trivial puzzles which involve button pushing for the most and nothing else. This is the most uninspiring gameplay I have ever seen. It is not fluid at all and the main character moves so slowly. It becomes a pain navigating the levels with such a slow character. The levels are also dungeon like so there are celings to stop you and there is not much use of the vertical flexibility that could have been achieved. The boss fights are very simple with very easy to figure out patterns. The last    boss gave me some trouble but I finished that in 3 tries after figuring the pattern. I generally do not care about a game story and completely ignored that one but you can talk to folks and figure out whats happening. I found the cutscenes very annoying and they sometimes popped up randomly which was very annoying. Also there is a level the last one which is very annoying as they do not ley you fly and it is absolutely the worst level designed and is completely against the flow of the game. I would not recommend this game. it was an absolutely chore to play with nothing innovative in the gameplay and a very slow moving character. Also the character switching is clunky where you can get the pal you want to use teleported to you. Absolutely boring gameplay.

												Horrible endgame. Player spent the whole game playing a flying platformer, but the ability of flight is taken away during endgame, during which the game is a gimped jump platformer. Since the UP key is used to transition from jump to flight during regular game, if somehow game detects player press UP during endgame jump, the jump is cut short. Player is required to use the same ally to do damange for most of the game, as the other ally's attack is cooldown based. Boss does get harder, however due to lack of abilities, the harder bosses plays like a crappy fighting game, where invulnable frames matter. No map travel, making doing achievements/collections a pain.

Posted: January 7
												I really wanted to like this one - the visuals, music, and quirky characters are all done fantastically well, and D-pad absolutely deserves a ton of credit for creating them with their limited resources. Unfortunately, while I'd say this game's 9 years of development were well-spent on those aspects, the gameplay desperately needed more attention. It's great for about the first quarter of the game, but starts relying on weaker mechanics after that for the sake of variety. I'd still have recommended it if not for the last stage of the game, which robs you of both flight and your friend's abilities in order to force some god-awful platforming sections on you. Owlboy's controls weren't meant for platforming, and this section makes that painfully clear. It killed the game for me.

Posted: November 1, 2016
												i had immediate crashes immediately after leaving owlboy's house but re-enabling windows media player via programs and features > turn windows options on and off > media features > windows media player solved it.to the commenters complaining about me not sending a bug report: if the bug reporting in the game actually worked i would've sent one---the bug report thing in the game seems to have lots of pertinent information for debugging but unfortunately i couldn't interact with it due to another bug occurring from having a controller plugged in.  issues that prevent you from being able to progress more than 5 minutes into the game are worth being brought up to people thinking of buying a game when it just came out.  you'd be irritated preordering a game and having it not work at all on a brand new computer you just bought.  i'm glad the devs are working on it and i am absolutely not the only person who disables unwanted services and programs on their computer.it's a fantastic game.  the artwork/animation is incredible.  i've heard people complain about the writing being childish for whatever reason and i don't understand it----it has a ton of charm and hits quite close to home for me.  the music is phenomenal.  the gameplay is a little bit weird to get into but i warmed up to it by the time i made it up to the owl temple.  i'm sure the design and difficulty of the "dungeons" and whatnot will improve as the game progresses.  it's different for sure and is worth checking out and i will definitely update this review once i have time to progress further.i definitely hope the patches will improve the stability of the game because from what i've played so far it's pretty great.

number of helpful: 5 of 16 people (31%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 28
												Owlboy is the worst kind of bad game- a game I had high hopes for; a game which had so much potential that it shines through even the crud that is its final form.Let's go back a step though- what does Owlboy do right? From the very first trailer I and almost everyone else who saw it was enchanted by the visuals, art style, and music. That part still holds. Retro art is ironically old now, but it's done well here unlike in some indie games, and the music is strong enough that I bought a few tracks from the OST on the composer's website. The thing is, Owlboy never really goes beyond that.The Combat is incredibly barebones. Owlboy lifts up to 3 partners, which basically means 3 different guns you can freely switch between unless the partner is missing for story reasons. These get 1 minor upgrade each over the course of the game, and are otherwise unchanged. Enemy selection is very limited, with 1-2 types in each area. Thankfully, the boss fights at the end of each area are a bit imaginative and mix things up, but that's just not enough variety and challenge. You do not gain any extra movement abilities or powers beyond the guns (which unlock slowly over the course of the story).Let's talk about the Rings. I hope I wasn't the only one getting serious Superman 64 vibes from that part of the trailer. Owlboy can fly around opening chests to get coins, or fly through rings to get coins. This isn't currency, though. Think of them more like Feathers in Assassin's Creed. They're collectibles and they unlock things in a "shop". The quotation marks are because you can't choose what to unlock, they simply unlock automatically at certain coin thresholds, in a linear order. These are mostly cosmetic changes for Owlboy (content padding) with the 3 minor upgrades for your weapons mixed in. The whole thing reeks of unfinished features and playtime padding, which is kind of sad for a game that took 10 years to develop, regardless of the dev team size.The worst part of the game is the Level Design. The devs simply went full retro with these. Owlboy levels rival the worst of nonsensical NES level designs with nonsensical layouts that aren't very interesting to play through. I cannot describe the disappointment I felt when I entered the second major dungeon area- apparently a bunch of samey looking steel girder grafted to literal clouds, which formed a maze on the way to a major bad guy airship. The idea that some reviewers have described Owlboy as a Metroivania is a joke. There's no exploration here; routes are 90% linear and the only thing that can be missed are small hidden alcoves with extra chests and floating rings.In summary, just stay away. Watch the trailer again to experience a quick sense of wonder, without having it spoiled by actually playing the game.

number of helpful: 10 of 29 people (34%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												Owlboy is a game with wonderful visuals and music that took a long time to make that is utterly mediocre and not really worth your time. (Note: this review does contain slight spoilers)Let’s talk about the positives. The visuals are fantastic. Some real top notch pixel art. Save for some questionable art direction (ie the red flash from the shotgun attack, lack of some button UI), the art is some of the best modern pixel art you’ll ever see. Characters are detailed and full of expression. Background are beautiful and have a real sense of depth.The music is wonderful. It’s pretty typical video game-y adventure music, but it’s well orchestrated and there wasn’t a single track that felt was overly repetitive or annoying. The writing; aka the plot, dialogue, flavor text, is all serviceable and generally inoffensive. There are some genuinely touching moments and a decent little plot twist. However the ending feels like a non-ending that essentially amounts to generic time-travel related trope that we’ve seen done better in games. The character’s motivation towards the end of the game are forced and it, excuse the pun, it doesn’t land on its feet. Unfortunately the gameplay is the weakest part of this game. This game is riddled with a lack of polish that prevents it from having a good feel to it. You cannot remap the buttons for either gamepad or keyboard/mouse (I highly recommend you never attempt to play this game using keyboard/mouse as those controls are inexcusably awful.) The level design often demands a level of precision that the controls do not allow for. Example: You roll with the B (Circle), but aim with the Right Stick. Sometimes you’ll need to roll to avoid an attack while aiming, but can’t remove your thumb from the right stick fast enough. There are stealth sections that are either tedious or outright terrible. These are often poor with sensible checkpoints and any small screw up results in near instant failure. There are at least 3 of these throughout the game with the last one being essentially a whole dungeon. At least you can fly in that last one. The main gimmick of this game is that the player can fly. It’s not an original idea by any means. Games like Aquaria, Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet, and others have done similar things, but it’s still uncommon enough to be novel. However there are multiple points in this game where they take away the one unique thing about it and the results vary. The waterfall sections feel fine. In them you can only jump. The jump is super floaty unlike most other games and takes while to get used to, but those sections are usually very short. A single room or a bit more. You can’t attack other than the little spin attack that does no damage, but combat is usually avoidable or nonexistent in those sections. They’re actually nicely done. It’s the other times that are extremely questionable. There’s an early stealth section that’s pretty bad but the worst offender is the last area. There you can only fly for a little bit during it. Doing so will cancel all vertical momentum and slow you considerable. This would be fine if flying wasn’t so easy to trigger accidentally. By simply tapping up or jump again while in the air you’ll start flying. For most of the game this is great. You can just hold up and fly around. It feels expected, especially when using the analog stick. However, in that last section, if you start flying when you don’t expect to you’ll likely fall into an instant death trap. This causes you to countlessly restart what should be an fairly straightforward platforming section not because of your own inability, but due to unexpected control issues. It felt like an awful Mario Maker level.This sort of one-off mechanic that doesn’t quite feel right or is straight up bad is very common throughout the game. There’s a dungeon where everything is dark and you only have a very small radius of light. You have to navigate tight tunnels edged with spikes, but the controls are floaty and the spikes too easy to clip into. Often it doesn’t look like you should have hit them. Later on you’re riding a giant lava snake and moving it up and down to avoid obstacles, but the screen is constantly rotating and it just feels wonky and awful instead of super cool like it should have. There’s not a single area of this game where I could say “Man! That was a really well done and fun!”Combat in this game is, like so much else, lackluster. It’s boring, slow, and often times unavoidable since enemies will chase you until you’re dead. Boss battles are much the same (expect for the final boss which is actually pretty well done! Though they do make you do it three times). Typical bosses have either a safe area (generally towards the top of the screen) or a simple strategy that makes them a complete non-issue.Ultimately, I feel like the developers would have better spent their time making a bunch of small games instead of trying to prefect this game. They did not succeed. So much of its issues scream inexperience and stubbornness. Had this game come out a year or two after they had started working on it, it would have been a flawed but alright game that they could have built from. As it stands now, it’s a flawed game that does not live up to expectations. If you want to play game with beautiful pixel art that took 8+ years to make then go play AM2R instead. Owlboy is just not worth your time.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												Pros: Very nice graphics, animations fluid and a lot of care was taken to give personality to NPCs and player characters. Music is fantastic. Little penguin guys are funny. The story is a bit sentimental at times, especially the ending. You want Otus to win!Cons: Not a lot of content, especially considering the price. They could have done a lot with character progression, or even secret doors placed throughout the world - why are there so few? Not at all challenging - you can easily finish in 8 hours. Controls can be wonky sometimes if you are trying to drop a teammate and pickup something off the ground. Upgrades almost meaningless, so not a lot of incentive to collect coins.In sum, I wanted to like this game but ended up disappointed. Games like Momodora, Axiom Verge, or Salt and Sanctuary are of the similar Metroidvania style but offer twice the gameplay with creative mechanics and deeper plots (at half the price). I don't think Owlboy was a very memorable expereince (besides the graphics and sound) and I wouldn't play it again.

												This game is good if you are expecting a ridiculously low amount of gametime for a decent chunk of cash. 9 Years fooled me into thinking the game would have a decent amount of content but alas, even going slow it took me just 8 hours to complete the story - and I was afk for about 1 hour. I did want this game to be good and I would probably would have liked it a whole lot more if... well if the was a whole lot more. TL;DR ; Dont buy this game for outstanding gameplay or a lot of content - just buy it if you want an OK story.

number of helpful: 29 of 83 people (35%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												TL; DR: Good game, but the pricetag is a way too high. Steam won't let me post without giving it a thumbs up/down, so thumbs down because I didn't really enjoy the game, the price is too high, and the average score is too high.Virtually everything about Owlboy is good. The art, music, gameplay, presentation, and writing are all well done. It's clear that a ton of love and effort has gone into the game. Like anything, there are a few rough spots here and there (the platforming in one of the final areas was particularly frustrating) but overall, each part of the game is great. That said, I can't really say that I loved the game. For whatever reason, the whole never really came together as something greater than the sum of its parts (despite those parts all being individually decent). The gameplay is decent enough, but it wasn't quite mechanically engaging enough to pull me along. The checkpoint system is incredibly forgiving, so there isn't really any challenge. The whole idea of having companions never really plays out to be more than just having different weapons equipped, which feels like a bit of a missed opportunity. On top of that, the puzzles aren't very mind-bending nor the gameplay particularly exciting. Likewise with the story and characters. They were interesting enough, but I usually didn't really feel super interested in what was around the next corner. The music was uniformly well composed and performed, but often felt out of place. The world is very pretty and well-connected, but there isn't really enough going on to encourage a ton of exploration. Ultimately, it feels like you end up with the worst parts of a Metroidvania game (excessive backtracking through areas) without the good ones (the feeling of excitement to use a new skill/ability to open new areas and find secrets). I realize the game isn't necessarily meant to be a Metroidvania, but the style of the world is reminiscent of one.All that said, the quality of the individual components of the game gives it a bit of charm that settled in by the end of the 8-10 hours I spent with it. I can't give it an outright recommendation because of the price and the lack of cohesive greatness, but it is by no means bad.Edit: The more I've been thinking about it, I just didn't really find the game to be fun. Plain and simple. And because none of the other elements really stuck out to me as being really exceptional, I wasn't left with a great impression overall. If you find the game fun, I think it will feel really, really great but I didn't because the gameplay didn't really grab me.Edit 2: Fixed TLDR for people who can't read good.

No map, and ambigous signs, greeeeat, hey you got a shotgun, that should be cool, oh it reloads so slowly that it has no value in actual combat, perfect. They give you knew mechanics, do they explain any of it, noooope. There are relics you can find all over the map, do they give you a map or a fast-travel to 1. Know where they are at, or 2. Not get lost in butt ♥♥♥♥ city while you are there nope. So yeeeeeaaaah, I was literally 2 bosses away from the end said: "♥♥♥♥ IT!" and I put it into a steam category that I have titled: "Go ♥♥♥♥ yourself" I hope this review helps, anyone save moeny and ....PS: It does look pretty and have great music.

number of helpful: 18 of 61 people (30%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												I'm probably going to get blasted for this, but this is perhaps the most boring game I have played in 2016 and many years before. Gone Home is equivalent to how bored I was in Owlboy. In fact I went to bed the night after I played it, woke up, then went the ENTIRE NEXT DAY before I remembered "oh yeah I played Owlboy didn't I, I should refund it." It was that forgettable. I have never played a game I literally forgot the next morning; they're either too good or too bad. This one was just too mediocre."But you only played for 47 minutes!" True! To which I defend myself by saying I went to a friend's house for the weekend and observed as he played it there, since he told me to buy it. At no point did I think "I should buy the game again." The gameplay is generic, the levels are generic, the story tries and fails to be meaningful, and the only redeeming quality are the graphics. It pains me that such cool graphics are in a game so utterly boring as this one.I'm also annoyed at some reviews claiming this is the best platformer of 2016. You spend a majority of your time FLYING, which means you CAN'T PLATFORM. Child of Light had this issue. This game is not a platformer, and it barely qualifies as a puzzle game since the puzzles are laughable.I don't want to say I didn't stay for the ending... Instead I'll say I couldn't stay around for the ending.

number of helpful: 13 of 50 people (26%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												Absolutely loved the first half of this game, but in its second half it becomes a painful reminder that there just isn't a lot of love for the casual gamer by the gaming industry.  The difficulty/tedium level increases exponentially, to the point where I finally gave up for good after probably 40+ attempts at completing one of the last segments of the game.  I know I'm in a minority wanting games to be easier, but some of us don't have the time or patience for games that feel more like work than play, and it would not be difficult for developers to include a "story mode" that lets us wimpy gamers bypass the tough scenes if we want to.  I enjoy the story, characters and artwork of this game, but don't enjoy the type of gaming that has you repeating segments ad nauseum to learn the choreography of precision timing scenes.

number of helpful: 22 of 74 people (30%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. I remember loving The Legend of Zelda and Metroid and I hoped it would be a similar experience, but it’s not. In my opinion, Owlboy barely qualifies as a game. It feels more like an interactive story that leads you around by the nose through various set pieces. I’m about half-way through and there's been no more than one or two fun scenes. It’s too easy –as an example, it’s almost impossible to take a wrong turn. When you’re finished with an area the game often literally closes a door behind you as if to say there's nothing you missed, just keep moving – way to kill the mystery. The puzzles are simple and the clues to solving them are telegraphed. The retro Art and Music are great but the gameplay is boring.

Posted: November 6, 2016
												Good PLATFORMER. Really good: all 2-D progression, interesting but kind of obvious puzzles, smash-your-fingers bosses. But the fact that is  a platformer has been subtly disguised or is at all absent in the game description. If you are  looking for a game that requires you to perfect-time pressing 5 keys in a second, this game is for you. If you are looking to "live a sweet and tender adventure" that the game description proclaims without getting your nails to hurt, then you should probably look somewhere else.

number of helpful: 23 of 296 people (8%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												The story was lackluster and poorly written. Molstrom just dies without you ever fighting him, despite being the ultimate war machine built by the Owls, and Solus never confides into Otus his reasoning for using the relics, despite saying that he considered Otus to be his only friend. There were too many unnecessary, irrelevant things to the story that were communicated while tons of other more pertinent questions to the story were left unanswered. For example, what does the engraved stone with the Roman numerals on it mean? Why are there plants overgrowing in some areas, and how did no one realize that they broke the wind machine in the Owl Temple? Who wrote the Book of Nocteus, and why was it prophetic?There may be more to the end of the universe, but this story did not do a good job of convincing me that there is.I could go on about the oversight in game mechanics, but I feel as though they pale in comparison to the lack of effort put into the story.However, I will say that this game is beautiful. There were many times that I was just awestruck by the detail put into it. I can't reasonably put my enamorment into words, but the art alone made this game worth it to me.I would not recommend this game, though, because I believe great games have great stories. This, sadly, was not one of them.(EDIT FOR CLARITY—11/5/2016):I have taken the spoiler tag off not to spite anyone here, but to more easily make it understood how incomplete the story is.The authors attempted to create many twists within the story, only to neuter it by creating major flaws in the character arcs of Solus, Molstrom, and the unknown Book of Nocteus author. Taste is subjective, but the story is not written well on an objective level, and I had to create an argument with apropos evidence by stating such a thing.A game with a good story should allow you to get immersed and lost within it. This game does everything within its power to prevent this, from the complete and utter destruction of Advent after Anne says to come by her house in Advent to learn more about her, to the lack of historical explanation of the Owl race. This game goes out of its way to make the story undigestible.This will be my last update, as the story of this game is not worth discussing further.https://support.steampowered.com/kb_article.php?ref=4045-USHJ-3810My review is not against steam rules, and you are not required to read reviews before purchasing this game.Should you find anger after reading my review, then I suggest you reevaluate why you sought out reviews in the first place.

content:
Posted: March 20
												Owlboy was a fun, highly enjoyable game.  The graphics and music were well made and a perfect throw back to the 16 bit era.  The characters were fun and interesting, and provided depth to the world.  Gameplay was fun and enjoyable.  The game was overall average difficulty and can be completed in about 4-6 hours depending on how fast you want to rush through.  It's a pretty linear game, with extra trinkets to find, but not necessary to complete the game.  For those complaining about the price, I'd say either wait for a sale or it's not the game for you.  If this was an older time, this game would have been a full retail priced game on the snes or genesis, and people still would have enjoyed it.

Posted: March 19
												It could be said that this game is short. Another could find that that the collecting is somewhat tough to go through. A lot of people also were having a hard time grasping exactly what story the creator was going for at the very end.At the moment I began to explore the world, every second I spent going through every inch of this game begging for another reason to stay just a little longer to discover more, and even many hours after 100% the entirety of the game, I wish that I could spread my love for this game with every breath I take. I gladly spent those beloved hours captivated by how this game felt and how it made me feel. That feeling is something rare and precious. It is not perfect as just a game, but I pray there is more content to look forward to.If anyone reads this looking for a reason to play it, I want you to just take my word and buy it. You'll wish you could pay more for it. It also, like many thing, is a personal experience you want to go into with as little exposure as you can.

Posted: March 23
												Was very conflicted about this one, because I played the worst part of the game right before ending it.Good:* Awesome soundtrack.* Fun dungeons.* Godly artstyle.* Interesting story.* Huge overworld + endless flying (seriously, I get more enjoyement just out of flying around it than I get from entirety of some other games).Bad:* BOGUIN CHALLENGE (It's so bad I wrote a script that completes it for me. Why put a reflex challenge THAT HARD in a game that has oherwise fairly balanced difficulty?)* No fast travel (The world is huge, so It would be great to be able to travel from some places to the others. It's not that big of a deal, as it allows to feel the hugeness of the world, but still...)* Boguin challenge. * Tone shifts (sometimes the game goes from cute to grimdark in 10 seconds and it's disturbing).* Boguin challenge.Technically Boguin Challenge takes 30 sec. to complete (although I spent about 4h on it), so 99.9% of the game if awesome and 0.1% is my personal hell.

content:
Posted: March 23
												It's a lovely game with wonderful pixel art and a touching story with some good humour as well. I enjoyed it a lot but would have been grateful for some in-game map and the ability to "teleport" to areas directly - at least after finishing the story (for collecting all coins). It's a pretty large world and searching stuff after the main story got a bit tedious. The controls (I played with a X-Box controller) are good but not perfect. The levels are quite diverse with some rather difficult parts but they are well thought out and never so long as to get frustrating (even when needing several attempts). Overall I think difficulty is very well balanced. I spent 12 hours with Owlboy and can heartily recommend it. It's a game made with a lot of care and love and it shows.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												This review was written by a friend who finished the game on another account:It's been quite some time since I've come across a game with the sheer charm and personality Owlboy has achieved. The Backstory of Otus the main character has depth and gives them relatability and meaning. Otus isn't infallible and relys on the support of his friends. Being mute did not stop me from connecting to Otus, since we get a sense of his feelings and traits through the eyes of the other well fleshed out characters, his well animated gestures and animations (particularly his facial expresions). I could connect to the story though the atmospheric music, ambience and well animated reactions of the characters to the events going on around them. That connection made me care when lives were lost and characters I got to know were hurt or betrayed throughout the progression of the story. The 10 hours (approximately) story keep me engrossed and through the varied artwork, characters/character animation, made it well like I was playing through an interactive movie. Well worth considering the time and money to invest in this well concieved adventure.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												What seemed to be just a little indie game with over 9 years of development, Owlboy is an adventure to behold. I finished this game two days after the game had released. Why? I absolutely fell in love with the game. There's a lot of things that really hold this game and make you just want more. While there are many MANY good things about this game. There are, however some spots I really was disappointed in. Now I won't be spoiling the whole ordeal on what I am talking about, but I will make reference to it so this review does HAVE SPOILERS AT THE END OF THE REVIEW ON ITS OWN SECTION BUT IT WILL BE SPOILER FREE!!!Owlboy is an Indie adventure game where you control Otus, a mute Owl who apparently has a lot on his shoulders when things don't really go his way. He and his friend Geddy are tasked with watch over their village when a huge group of bandits known as the Pirates invade, taking an Owl relic that is stored in the village. And off we go on our adventure to get that back and stop the Pirates and their plans. One of the first things I've noticed in game is the presentation along with the soundtrack. Holy crap this game has detail in its animations. Props to the devs and animators for a very polished game. The scenery looks beautiful and it sets the mood in the beginning as a light-hearted adventure. Otus himself is a mute, but the amount of detail in his responses, whether he is twiddling his thumbs when he's nervous, he covers himself with his cloak when he's sad, its all there and I wasn't expecting how I would feel for the poor guy. One effect though I had with the looks of the game were at some points, textures didn't spawn (which were resolved by resetting the game) and there are some weird bugs like if you eat a healing item and get hurt at the same time, it produces some weird result. Nothing gamebreaking, but I think that needs to be addressed.Speaking of feeling, this game can really tug on your heartstrings. You can get attached to these characters and then suddenly the feel train will hit you. I remembered that I at least teared up or even flat out cried at some sections because what was happening and how I didn't want bonds or spirits to break from the main cast. This story is very well done and the pace is very fluent. There weren't times I wanted to put down the game because I was just done. No, like I said before, I wanted more. When it finally ended, I was pleased with what I got. The game's difficulty isn't that bad either. It's very easy to get into and the game will test your knowledge of when to use certain partners, There are some hard spots, but it isn't too bad.Now lets talk about that gameplay huh? So Otus, as a mute owl, he really can't attack. He can stun people with is little spin, but thats all he can really do other than his little dash (which I'll get to in a minute). So the game pairs you up at first with your best friend Geddy, Geddy has a gun, which Otus can carry him and he can fire at enemies. This is an interesting mechanic as you need to manage having your partner on you while also dodging enemies, solving puzzles. The whole game would be a boring cake walk if Otus can attack. Because of this, there are special sections were Otus is alone and he has to sneak past enemies. There are a number of stealth sections in this game and they are handled pretty well. I never got bored of them as they went by pretty fast. Not to mention you have a great source of movement. Oh my god the movement. I mentioned Otus can dash either in the air or on the ground. As a speedrunner, I absolutely love games with amazing movement, and Owlboy is no exception. Sure there are a lot of times I spammed the dash to get point A to point B in a timely manner, but I never felt rushed. The regular flight speed that Otus has is very optimal. At no times when I was exploring a dungeon that I needed to move around by dashing, only when I needed to backtrack or dodge incoming fire. There is even an upgrade you get that makes your movement even better so that in the later parts in the game when you have more freedom to backtrack and collect any of the game's currency to buy the extra goodies. Overall, the game is a gem. It was worth the wait of 9 years of development and polish. I didn't hear about this game until youtuber VideoGameDunkey where he had said he had a really good feeling about this game. I looked into it, and gave a lot of hope. Owlboy is a must play if you like adventureous games with a story that really likes to hit your soft spots. I absolutely loved it and am looking forward to speedrun this game!Owlboy gets a 9.5 out of 10 for me. ~LuckPercentSRL---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------SPOILER SECTION! SPOILER SECTION! SPOILER SECTION! READ IF YOU WANTSo with all the praise I just gave this game. Why did I give it a 9.5? There are two small disappointments I had with the game's story.So at the end, it appears that Otus had fallen because he activated the anti-hex to save the world. In the end, we get this little section of him talking to all his village friends and they appear to be happy, saying bye sort of feeling, like a memory sequence. We find his teacher at the end who explains some things and where he is. Then it ends and we see him falling from space to.....his death? Is he alive? I'm not sure. It looked like he was dead initally, but his master say the realm he is in gives him a section chance? And then we see him falling from space so is he still alive? Arrrg! I just wanted to know and it just ends off right there! So yes, the ending is a bit disappointing. Don't get me wrong, there are still a couple of things that make it great.Also, Captain Molstrum seemed like an interesting antagonist. He was hyped up to be this unstoppable baddie who, with a relic, absolutely obliterates Advent with one blow. We all wanted to get back at him and I was so ready to fight him in like the 3 sections you have contact with him, and you don't get to at all. He gets killed by the plot and I was sad about that. Now this isn't to say the final boss was boring or a wasted potential because I did enjoy fighting him. I'm just sad that we get this hyped baddie and we don't even get to fight him.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												I am not a nice person. I judge things by their faults, not by their strengths. It is a system of subtraction. For everything that displeases me the game needs to have something equal or greater in order for me to enjoy it. Games that are "flawed but good" do not get my recommendation. I am hard, I am critical and I find little pleasure in things anymore. I have prejudged them all and found them wanting. I tell you this so that you might understand the weight of what I say next. Owlboy is a masterpiece unlike any I have seen for a long time. It is not only a joy to behold, but to experience. I am not one for graphics making the game, but the screenshots and whatever video you have seen of this game does it no justice. It is stunning from start to finish. The characterizations, the movement, the attention to detail, the colors and the vivid landscapes. Everything is uniquely designed and is so amazing you won't be able to take it all in through a single playthrough. As you play, keep your eyes open and attentive and you will be endlessly rewarded.The music is a marvel. I am going to go and buy the soundtrack. Its really just that great. There's flow and character and mood and melody. Everything is weird and different but it all fits together. Character themes and areas and even the sound effects just flow seemlessly to set the tone of the adventure. If you love old soundtracks for the classic game of bygone then you will not be disappointed.Story and writing are not what I would expect out of this game nor did I anticipate it to be such a high point. It has epic adventure without feeling forced. The characterization is excellent. There's comedy, which is genuinely funny and light hearted, but its only a pause from the rising gravity of a situation gone extremely wrong. There's intrigue and development and those who are careful to watch it unfold can notice some very interesting things early on that will pique your curiosity.Its a fun game to play. The controls on keyboard and mouse are simple enough that you don't struggle against a steep learning curve but certain segments will have you hammering away at keys in order to switch up moves and having you scramble during some of the faster paced segments... but the game is very forgiving. It will throw you into a situation, but its not guaranteed instant failure if you mess up. You get multiple chances and if you've worked on what the game has taught you then you will easily fall into the reflex of knowing what to do. The areas feel good, feel smart. They're crisp and never requiring pixel perfect jumps or for you to count frames in order to succeed. Its fun. There's a few minor bugs to the game. I've had to deal with one, but honestly I can't blame the developers; its a problem with XNA and I daresay anyone developing a title like this one would have been bit by the same thing. They're working on it, and I've had no issue with performance outside having to reinstall WMP. Its worth the money new. And that's high praise.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												Fell in love at the title screen. This game is not super difficult, nor does it have increadibly complex mechanics but its not really trying to be. What it does have is a very great lore, an absolutely beautiful artstyle and a hell of a lot of charm. I love the sheer amount of polish in this game. From the Night-Day cycle, to the very detailed sprite animations you can tell instantly that this was a labor of love from the devs. I find myself exploring every nook of each screen just to take in the gorgeous background art and environments. This is really something that the devs should be proud of. 10/10 would hoot again.

Because of this, there are special sections were Otus is alone and he has to sneak past enemies. There are a number of stealth sections in this game and they are handled pretty well. I never got bored of them as they went by pretty fast. Not to mention you have a great source of movement. Oh my god the movement. I mentioned Otus can dash either in the air or on the ground. As a speedrunner, I absolutely love games with amazing movement, and Owlboy is no exception. Sure there are a lot of times I spammed the dash to get point A to point B in a timely manner, but I never felt rushed. The regular flight speed that Otus has is very optimal. At no times when I was exploring a dungeon that I needed to move around by dashing, only when I needed to backtrack or dodge incoming fire. There is even an upgrade you get that makes your movement even better so that in the later parts in the game when you have more freedom to backtrack and collect any of the game's currency to buy the extra goodies. Overall, the game is a gem. It was worth the wait of 9 years of development and polish. I didn't hear about this game until youtuber VideoGameDunkey where he had said he had a really good feeling about this game. I looked into it, and gave a lot of hope. Owlboy is a must play if you like adventureous games with a story that really likes to hit your soft spots. I absolutely loved it and am looking forward to speedrun this game!Owlboy gets a 9.5 out of 10 for me. ~LuckPercentSRL---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------SPOILER SECTION! SPOILER SECTION! SPOILER SECTION! READ IF YOU WANTSo with all the praise I just gave this game. Why did I give it a 9.5? There are two small disappointments I had with the game's story.So at the end, it appears that Otus had fallen because he activated the anti-hex to save the world. In the end, we get this little section of him talking to all his village friends and they appear to be happy, saying bye sort of feeling, like a memory sequence. We find his teacher at the end who explains some things and where he is. Then it ends and we see him falling from space to.....his death? Is he alive? I'm not sure. It looked like he was dead initally, but his master say the realm he is in gives him a section chance? And then we see him falling from space so is he still alive? Arrrg! I just wanted to know and it just ends off right there! So yes, the ending is a bit disappointing. Don't get me wrong, there are still a couple of things that make it great.Also, Captain Molstrum seemed like an interesting antagonist. He was hyped up to be this unstoppable baddie who, with a relic, absolutely obliterates Advent with one blow. We all wanted to get back at him and I was so ready to fight him in like the 3 sections you have contact with him, and you don't get to at all. He gets killed by the plot and I was sad about that. Now this isn't to say the final boss was boring or a wasted potential because I did enjoy fighting him. I'm just sad that we get this hyped baddie and we don't even get to fight him.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
												A labor of love from the best pixel artist alive right now.Owlboy is not a game for everyone. It's rough around the edges as far as gameplay goes. The controls are pretty tight, but not super tight. The puzzles are very clever, but not incredibly clever. The game is mostly bug free, but not completely bug free.Overall I felt I got my money's worth, and I'd surmise that most people alive to experience the SNES era of action platformers will also appreciate the game. Younger gamers most likely won't, as the lack of polish in a number of areas won't make up for the stunning imagery and supurb sound design.The game also has a number of fun and interesting set pieces, but they tend to be over before you can really appreciate them. In addition, there are a number of clever platforming puzzles that don't get the full treatment. Once you get the hang of a new puzzle concept the game pushes you into the next. There are also several sections where you can sort of bumble your way through. The game can feel challenging in some places, but more often than not it's a matter of figuring out the preferred way of solving the problem in front of you, rather than mechanically getting good.That said, the very last level of the game does away with this and demands platform jumping precision in an environment you are not familiar with. It's not too hard as, mentioned previously, once you get the hang of one concept the game shunts you on to the next, but it was an odd choice.There are numerous small details that ultimately brings down the experience. The reloading time for the musket is one. The lava level has a number of puzzles in the dark that can be muddled through without understanding them. The game is in desparate need of a map system as, while the maps in dungeons are linear, they can be confusing to navigate. In addition, the game borrows elements from Zelda, but without a map or easy way to mark which locations require more searching to get that vaunted 100%, it kills a lot of the desire to fully explore and re-treat previous areas for the last few coins.On the subject of collectibles, there seem to be three side-quests in the whole game. One involves rescuing a number of adorable penguin-like animals, who unlock an interesting if daunting mini-game. The second involves a secret in the first dungeon which doesn't seem to ever get fully explained. The third is collecting each and every coin in the game, which is kind of a hassle since, unlike many metroidvania titles, there are no clues as to what constitutes a hidden wall or passage. Or if killing every enemy in a location will unlock a chest. The lack of clues and helpful tools to get around the map or explore kill off the metroidvania vibe.In addition, the maps for dungeons are virtually 100% linear, so in essence it's less like playing Metroid, Zelda or Castlevania classics, and more like playing the more modern Zelda titles where you hardly ever backtrack and simply solve each puzzle and dungeon in sequence.With the complaints out of the way, the story is pretty on point. The characters are endearing enough, not charming enough to be remembered for a long time, but not hateful or annoying either. There are also a number of strong, darker moments in the game that would really amp up the emotion if the characters were a little bit more fleshed out.I think, the greatest crime of Owlboy, is that aside from the stellar visuals, the game is the most solid B+ title I've ever experienced. No doubt the long development time was devoted to the visuals and animation, I feel as though the small team could've used that time to iterate on the design and polish the game up even more. I wonder if 6 extra months of development time would've vaulted Owlboy from an interesting game for pixel art enthusiasts and nostalgic fans, into a true indie game darling and platforming classic.No doubt, enough love and care was put into the title, and there is definately a feeling that Owlboy be placed among other titles such as Cave Story, Noitu Love, Undertale, et al. But it's that lack of finish that ultimately squashes it's aspirations.I recommend it, and I think it's worth the price. But if you're expecting the next Undertale, perhaps wait for a sale?

												Given the game's 9-year development cycle, Owlboy is clearly a labour of love on the part of the developers, and this absolutely shines through in the final product. Between the game's heartfelt story, its absolutely stunning visuals and music, its fun Metroidvania gameplay, and its irresistable Super Nintendo-esque charm, it all combines to form one of the most memorable and satisfying adventures I've had the pleasure to play in quite some time. While it's not without its flaws, they are trivial compared to the sheer amount of polish that has gone into the final product, and ultimately, this is a game that despite having completed it, I can easily see myself returning to it time and again. Absolutely stellar game, D-Pad Studio should pat themselves on the back for this.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												Last year we got a little indie title that blew us away and now we get one that also manages to look awesome as heck.At very first let me tell you one thing. THIS IS NOT A METROIDVANIA!Sure, today its cool to slap this tag on EVERY FLIPPING INDIEGAME, but this is not a metroidvania, its more like a Zelda plattformer... an Action adventure. If you want to see what a Metroidvania is, then go on and play Axiom Verge, Metroid, Shantae and the Pirates Curse or Castlevania. If you aren't braindead you'll see the difference.Owlboy awaits you with it's stunning visuals, interesting characters, solid gameplay and soothing soundtrack.Yeah, soothing, I mean the background music for the action packed sections of the game was cool too, but its nothing that I would remember for a long time... nevertheless, it gets ya pumped for what is happening and thats all I want.The Visuals are, as I said, incredible. You really feel the passion that went into the animations and every little rock.The games story and characters are something that i would rather leave without any big spoilers... especially since the game has just been released. All you have to know is that its pretty good and gives the adorable characters a solid worldbuild to exist in.The game will take roundabout 5 hours to beat and 7-8 to absolutely complete it the first time.its not too hard but surely will wipe the floor with your sorry behinds if you're not getting the hang of the situations you are in.Overall, I absolutely have to recommend this game.Its a really nice axperience, even tho I highly doubt it will leave the same impact as Undertale did a year ago, since Owlboy really explains every little thing whilst Undertale gave the player tons of content to specualte about... there will surely be no clickbaity Game theory about this game... which is bad, since Owlboy deserves all the attention it could possibly get.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												TL;DR : This game is astounding, 9.5/10._________________________Owlboy is a breath of fresh air in the gaming industry, something different from the casual FPS or other cash-grabs with no real game. And allow me to explaing why. In this game you play as Otus, a young owl living in the town of Villie along with his bestfriend and partner: Geddy. While you go on your adventure you will find out that as Otus you are unable to kill an enemy yourself, for you can only stun them or knock armor off of them. This is where the innovation begins, as you must pick up Geddy to kill an enemy, for Geddy (and other teammates you will get later on) will be the only ones able to kill an enemy.  As you fly along through the story, you may also notice that you can trail off from the given path to adventure else where, to find secrets of the land and stories untold...and maybe a few more coins laying around. I find that this type of level design in super exciting, because I love to explore, and while on the topic of levels, the many levels of this game all feel different making each and everyone a different journey to be had. Now, to the juicy stuff...pros and cons.Pros: - The music is phenomenal. - The art is gorgeous. - The enemies are different. - Levels are designed well to keep the game interesting. - Characters are lovable. - The story is in-depth, while being a rollercoaster of emotions. - Sprites and animations are wonderful. - Exploration is fun.*- Boss-fights are also fun and different.With all these pros you'd think there'd be no cons, right? Nah there's like 2.Cons:  - The game isn't too difficult, I only died a couple times, but that was from me being stupid.*- Along with the first con, the boss-fights are not too difficult.The game is fun and innovative and competely worth your time and money, I just wish they had a difficult slider or something, because I found myself going through levels with ease.Oh well, a game doens't need to be difficult to be a masterpiece. I give this game a 9.5/10 just because it was pretty easy and it felt like I was "flying" (heheheh) through the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												The game looks and sounds great, and plays pretty well until they require you to juggle abilities. Perhaps it's much easier with a keyboard. The most difficult parts in the game, so far (I believe I'm very near the end), are fighting the controls, which is a shame because I'm otherwise really enjoying the game. Every time I find myself getting frustrated with the controls, I have to turn the game off for another day. But it keeps luring me back in with its old-school charm and top notch production. Also, the exploration seems extremely limited. I kept expecting to reach new areas when I got a new companion, and that's partially true, but for the most part, backtracking has been mostly a waste of time. Bottom line: I'm enjoying this game, but I'm not as impressed with it as a lot of the reviews seem to be, mainly because of the frustrating controls. The price is a bit steep for the amount of content. $15 would've been more appropriate. These Indie developers need to consider the amount of manpower that goes into their games. There are $25 games out there that are better than this that hundreds of people worked on. No Man's Sky is probably the biggest perpetrator of this mistake.Warning: just because certain abilities interact with certain things doesn't mean you should use that ability. I spent a lot of time trying to do certain things because I would almost accomplish it a certain way to eventually break down and watch a youtube video bash it's head against it and find the solution for me.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												I often call Owlboy the "Undertale of action platformers", and that's exactly what it is! Owlboy is a beautiful 2D adventure set in a world floating in the sky. You'll explore ancient ruins, fight monsters, aquire friends with unique abilities, and battle challenging bosses. Everything here is so carefully crafted, from the balanced difficulty to the design of the levels. You'll never be truly lost in any dungeon, and you'll always end up going in the right direction anyway. The art itself is so beautiful, even if I got lost somehow, that I was in disbelief. The sheer effort that went into the animation and pixel art is ASTOUNDING! The story alone is incredible and compelling. There is nothing better than a group of friends going up against overwhelming odds! What a classic tale full of tension and hope! For this review, I am not going to do my usual summary of the positives or negatives. Because there really isn't a single negative to say about Owlboy. Maybe the odd stealth sections are a minor flaw, because they do a good job breaking up the usual gameplay, but everything else is so well made. In fact, if you don't care about collecting everything or finding all the secrets, the collectable coins are designed exactly to give you the upgrades you need just by playing normally. That is polish and care on a higher level! Owlboy is another "indie darling" that deserves to sit next to Shovel Knight and Undertale!

content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												This is a remarkably well made retro platformer. The music is outstanding. Reminding me of Final Fantasy. The gameplay is really solid with a light metroidvania feel that had me feeling mildly confused about where I was going most of the time. You just fly around, but use the power of your friends to combat and traverse portions of the environment. They're easy to use and control and have clearly defined roles. Problem is that you have little time where you are using all three at once. There are a couple sections that felt out of place like the cannon flight, but they're few and far between. My only other gripe is that the game really gives you zero context for how an enemy is defeated or a section traversed. It's all trial and error. Visuals are peak retro. They use the term hi-bit and I like it for this genre of graphics. I really liked the character animations. Otus's surprised face gave me a giggle every time. Well worth the asking price.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												Okay I love this game. Highly recommended. I've got about 4 hours logged in the game and this is the first game in a long time that I want to continually revist. So here's what I like about the game sprinkled with some opportunities I think the developers might consider:Music - the musical score in this game is absolutely wonderful. It can be delightful, brooding, somber, exciting, uplifting, everything. It's so wonderful, I don't know how else to describe it. I can't really go into depth about it since I'm no audiophile, but lemme say it really greatly adds to the mood and setting of the game at any given point.Graphics - this is a 2D game of course, but as far as 2D games go, this game looks absolutely gorgeous. I will say here that sometimes the environments feel somewhat empty, and the lack of a map or map hotkey makes navigating somewhat difficult but it's not unbearable and never really feels like it's a huge hinderance. I think it may make collecting all the extra stuff a little hard but I think not spoonfeeding stuff to players isn't a HUGE problem. Gameplay - the game is really responsive, I never find myself doing something I didn't want to do, same with the aiming and all. The whole concept of carrying different gunners to do and accomplish different things is really cool and it's a clever gameplay mechanic. The puzzles are pretty fun, not too difficult though, but again, no hand holding here and it's great. Story - I leave this one up to you guys. I really enjoy the story line, I know some of you out there will say it's a tried and true story, done plenty of times before. But that doesn't stop me from really enjoying the story. My only wish is that the game doesn't end quickly. I'm only 4hours into it, I hope theres a lot more of the story left. I'm not going to assign a number value but I'm going to say this game is great. I really love it. I hope the game lasts quite a bit longer, but I'll append this Review when I'm done to give a good idea of how long it takes. Highly recommended, if you need a new story driven game that doesn't hand hold you through every single piece of it, look no further, speak no more.Edit: I finished the game, I have 9 hours logged and I could've finished it a lot faster honestly. I really love this game, the ending is memorable and I look forward to what the creators have next in store. I wish the game was longer though, that's probably my only gripe.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												On the surface, this is a fun little platformer game with aspects of twin-stick shooter. Like others have remarked, it has impressive art design. Unlike others, I didn't find myself very compelled by the story and overall game design. Does it have a message? Yes, you can definitely see the parallels it draws between its characters and the hardships that we, as inhabitants of earth, face economically, environmentally and socially.But, was it fun? Kind of. Will it leave a lasting impression on me? Probably not. Is it worth the $20+US? No...I would say about $15 relative to other games I've played that are similar indie platformers. I understand this was an indie title that took 9 years in the making - don't really understand why so long - possibly finances? In all honesty, I've played other indie games that were far more enjoyable to play and left a lasting impression - I'm talking about you Environmental Station Alpha, Cave Story and Valdis Story. Opposed to these others, I can't honestly say that I'd come back to play this one. It's very linear. Controls are just ok. There's a section near the end that requires some experimentation with platform jumping. I'll give a hint...if you've been using the analog stick in the flying portions preceding this, you definitely want to switch to the D-Pad during said jumping section near end of game. Something weird convolutes the analog left movement stick with the jumping mechanism, intermittently wonking out and prompting premature flight, loss of hang-time, etc. You'll see. Maybe the devs will fix this.Anyway, bottom line, it is a fairly enjoyable game that I would recommend...with one caveat. If you don't mind spending the $20+, go ahead and purchase; otherwise, wait for a sale at around $15 or so.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												After dealing with Owlboy for a full video series where I played it, it left a good impression on me as a game itself. Uncertain if I can link that, so here's just the review!In all honesty, it's hard to rate Owlboy as anything less than 'Amazing' in almost every aspect it tries to touch upon. Gameplay is solid, the map is solid, the characters are great, the art is pretty and stylish, and the story overall is told well... But there are still flaws. In the story itself, there are a lot of things that are hamfisted or simply not explained well enough and most characters come off as negative because of that. Now, a majority of them are still fine and that's why I said they were great, but there are definitely a few I feel have fatal flaws that simply aren't explored in the gameplay. That is my major complaint.Another major complaint is a build up that never receives a payoff. Something that may hint for things to come now that the foundation has been set, but... It could have been handled better. This game was amazing, there's no doubting that, and I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who likes action platformers like this that are very story driven. There's also a lot of hidden things that just aren't really focused on unless you really want to 100% the game, which is a plus. It's nice when a game likes to show you its story through actual work instead of just an hour long cutscene, though there are plenty of small cutscenes through this game as well.Regardless, this game has flaws and a few major ones too, but it's not a bad game. Gameplay was simple, clean, and overall fun, but ultimately ended up becoming repetitive or just annoying, particuarlly in certain situations. The music was always on point, though, and there were only a few points where the art was an issue, particuarlly when dealing with enemies that have arkward hit boxxes or move a lot. That being said..... The information I have states the game took over 10 years to come out. In these 10 years, it got a lot of support and a lot of people were looking forward to it. In no way do I think anyone who did wish for it is disappointed and I am definitely not disappointed either in buying it... But it could have been better and I feel like 10 years was more than enough time to make it better. There's a lot of small things that really make this game just barely reach 'Amazing', but it's still amazing nontheless. I'm looking forward to more from this group and hopefully this game will allow them to see flaws they otherwise missed because of either lack of experience, or simply not trying to focus on fixing them. Hopefully it'll take less than 10 years next time, possibly for a sequel. Story: 7/10Art: 9/10Gameplay: 8/10Music: 10/10Characters: 7.5/10 (One specific character has a good moment, but overall is pretty meh.)Overall: 8/10. Could use work, but it's still an amazing game that people should pick up if they enjoy this genre.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game is the product of nine years of development, and it really shows that the developers crafted every detail of the game with love. Owlboy isn't perfect, but it's definitely a standout title.PresentationOwlboy's strongest attribute by far. The "Hi-Bit" pixel graphics are gorgeous and set a high bar for any future games using a pixelated art style. The soundtrack by Jonathan Geer is beautiful and emotive, making the soundtrack a worthy upgrade if you're the type to listen to video game soundtracks when you're not playing. Animations for the characters are absolutely on point. The characters' expressions and reactions during dialogue are very charming and expressive.GameplayWhile I had a lot of fun with this game, it's not as polished in the gameplay department as in presentation. The game is often far too easy, with some spikes in difficulty in certain sections. I found myself breezing through the levels, with puzzles, boss fights, and other obstacles doing little to slow my progress. Occasionally, I would get lost in some of the levels if I decided to go hunting for collectibles as there's no minimap, though not much backtracking is required to progress in the game.StoryI loved the story and spent time talking to every NPC. However, I know the story is hit or miss for some. Owlboy's story pacing is pretty standard, breaking up the action in-between dungeons for narrative development and character dialogue. The characters are likable and distinct, and the story has some unexpectedly emotional turns. If you're not interested in the story, however, you're probably going to get annoyed at the interruptions.Final ThoughtsOverall I'd recommend Owlboy to anyone looking for an aesthetically-pleasing game that's light on difficulty but high on charm. If you're an action platformer veteran looking for a challenge, this game will disappoint you. Owlboy is at its best when you just relax and let it pull you in with its story and presentation. I wish the game was longer or more challenging, but I came away from the game without regrets in my purchase, even going back to 100% it and see everything there is to see
