number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												Owlboy is a 2D puzzle-platformer about an anthropomorphic owl named Otus who finds himself unknowingly in the midst of a cataclysmic disaster millenia in the making. With the assistance of friends he makes along the way, Otus solves puzzles, shoots enemies, defeats monstrous bosses, and unearths dark secrets about the world he lives in.  In terms of gameplay, the only thing that sets it apart from other platformers is Otus' ability to carry one of his companions while in flight. Over the course of the game, you encounter 3 friends who accompany you on your adventure, each of which has a unique ability that can be used to gain access to previously inaccessible areas, solve puzzles, eliminate enemies, and avoid or circumvent obstacles. Although a novel mechanic, it is utilized in generally uninteresting ways, resulting in a gameplay experience that falls a bit flat. The puzzles presented in the game aren't difficult in the slightest, and your companions' abilities are only used in the most surface-level puzzle-solving. Oftentimes, the puzzles come down to: use a companion's ability at this point to progress. Had more of the game's puzzle-solving revolved around switching between companions or combining their abilities in unique ways, the gameplay would have been much more enjoyable. However, this would have required fundamental changes to the story beats and progression as the first two companions are introduced in the first couple hours of the game. The third (and final companion) isn't unlocked until you are in the throes of the game's climax. To make matters worse, over the course of the game you periodically lose a companion, meaning that you only have a full party for what seems like the last hour or so. Despite the narrative justifications for this, it's frustrating that  one of the defining mechanics of Owlboy can only be fully utilized for the last hour or two of the game. The story itself is filled with the charm and whimsy that you would expect from a game like Owlboy. The game's narrative follows Otus as he attempts to save his people from a cataclysmic event which gets increasingly dire as the game progresses. There are some unexpected turns in the story that kept it from being completely predictable, but at the end of the game it was a pretty standard "save the world from X because ancient people did Y" narrative you might expect from an animated children's movie. Although it falls victim to some fairly common narrative tropes, the story was compelling enough to keep me engaged and interested for its entirety. Artistically, Owlboy is a masterpiece, and I struggle to think of a more perfect example of pixel-art done right. Whether soaring through the sky towards a floating continent, or dashing through lava-filled caves, every frame is a beautiful pixel-art painting. The environments teem with life as birds fly off into the distance, stars twinkle in the night sky, and the background and foreground slide along in some of the best examples of parallax scrolling I've ever seen. The character sprites and monsters are beautifully animated and brimming with personality that would make even Nintendo green with envy. The entire game is filled with screen-shot worthy moments that were composed with almost absurd attention to detail. Although the artwork in Owlboy is second to none, the soundtrack itself is a wonderful composition of scores that perfectly complement every scene. Lilting clarinets, violins, and cellos accompany Otus on his journey to save the world, instilling a sense of mysticism and serenity that is not often found in games. Unless you're one for scouring every inch of a game in order to collect every single coin imaginable, once you're done with Owlboy there's no reason to come back. There is no "New Game+", unlockable content, or multiplayer. That isn't to say that it would need any of that. The journey is a short one at roughly 6-8 hours, but considering the overall shallowness of the gameplay, any longer and it would have been a slog. There's no question as to when the game will come to a close as the story ends in a textbook climactic fashion. With most of the narrative threads being wrapped up in the game's bittersweet conclusion, the ending of Owlboy feels nothing short of satisfying. It's not disappointing, nor is it powerfully moving. Instead it feels absolutely appropriate, a perfectly competent bookend to what was overall a thoroughly enjoyable experience. Despite the lackluster gameplay and the occasionally frustrating traversal segment, Owlboy has stuck with me. From time to time I'll find myself whistling the main menu music or imagining the blue skies and gently swaying foliage of the introductory area, and I'm immediately reminded of the games from my childhood. 16-bit vibrant landscapes, colorful characters, and comical villain archetypes. Owlboy serves as a rose-tinted lens through which I retrospectively view the games of my childhood. It's nostalgic, charming, and beautiful. (http://www.shatteredjoystick.com/single-post/2016/11/30/Owlboy-PC--Review)

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												This game suffers from mediocre combat and in some parts frustrating level design.  The movement system isn't as much fun as I thought it would be for a game where you can fly from the get-go.  There's very little backtracking and a lack of puzzles for a game of its metroidvania flavor.  Owlboy, however turns out to be more than the sum of its parts.  None of these individual gripes end up being a deal-breaker, and the ups in my opinion far outweigh the downs.  Containing fun characters, a decent story, and easily the best pixel art I've ever seen in a game,  Owlboy is well worth your time.It's perhaps a bit short for $25, but it's a must buy if you can't get enough of the atmosphere of games like Fez and Hyper Light Drifter.  (I didn't mention the music holy ♥♥♥♥ the music)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Owlboy.The game is an action platformer.You play as "Owlboy", a mute fledgling owl that is forced to spread his wings and thrust into an adventure like no other. The art style: Is wonderful, with its vibrant and colourful display, its locations are wonderful; you can really see that this was a labour of love, rather than a rushed game.The Music: The music is truly fantastic, it really helps to create emotion, whether that being melancholy or wonder, it has a track for that; I couldn’t help but find the soundtrack and listen to it again. The fact that it is fully orchestrated helps wonders too. The Story:I felt that the story captivated me and kept me well engrossed, making me want to come back to play the rest almost every night. The story took me about 6-7 hours to complete, but I did not get all of the collectibles that are on offer. I was not disappointed. The Combat: The combat is something that I enjoyed; you pick up and carry one of three different characters to act as your weapon each with a unique still set that will be useful in your travels. There are a large variety of enemies that you will face and a good amount of boss fights that will engage you. I only wish the boss fights were a little more difficult.I honestly loved this game and I recommend it to you whole-heartedly.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												It's weird for a "Metroidvania platformer" to have the entire game make you essentially ignore platforms, but this game has two good arguments for playing it: the environments and the music.Now let me be clear: a lot of games get praised for their score and I've played a number of games that are famous for their scores, but this is probably the first in a long time that I felt encouraged to put the controller down for a little while and just listen.The backgrounds and artwork are very detailed in a very subtle way: I didn't actually notice it at first (I was exploring and a bit lost) but for a game with that old-school X-bit look, there's a lot more attention to detail than I expected.The controls are simple (I always mess them up in boss fights though) but I'm not sure how I feel about so explicit a plot in a Metroidvania game.  It's new to me and I'm unsure if it helps or hurts the game.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												The game looks and sounds great, and plays pretty well until they require you to juggle abilities. Perhaps it's much easier with a keyboard. The most difficult parts in the game, so far (I believe I'm very near the end), are fighting the controls, which is a shame because I'm otherwise really enjoying the game. Every time I find myself getting frustrated with the controls, I have to turn the game off for another day. But it keeps luring me back in with its old-school charm and top notch production. Also, the exploration seems extremely limited. I kept expecting to reach new areas when I got a new companion, and that's partially true, but for the most part, backtracking has been mostly a waste of time. Bottom line: I'm enjoying this game, but I'm not as impressed with it as a lot of the reviews seem to be, mainly because of the frustrating controls. The price is a bit steep for the amount of content. $15 would've been more appropriate. These Indie developers need to consider the amount of manpower that goes into their games. There are $25 games out there that are better than this that hundreds of people worked on. No Man's Sky is probably the biggest perpetrator of this mistake.Warning: just because certain abilities interact with certain things doesn't mean you should use that ability. I spent a lot of time trying to do certain things because I would almost accomplish it a certain way to eventually break down and watch a youtube video bash it's head against it and find the solution for me.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												TL;DR : This game is astounding, 9.5/10._________________________Owlboy is a breath of fresh air in the gaming industry, something different from the casual FPS or other cash-grabs with no real game. And allow me to explaing why. In this game you play as Otus, a young owl living in the town of Villie along with his bestfriend and partner: Geddy. While you go on your adventure you will find out that as Otus you are unable to kill an enemy yourself, for you can only stun them or knock armor off of them. This is where the innovation begins, as you must pick up Geddy to kill an enemy, for Geddy (and other teammates you will get later on) will be the only ones able to kill an enemy.  As you fly along through the story, you may also notice that you can trail off from the given path to adventure else where, to find secrets of the land and stories untold...and maybe a few more coins laying around. I find that this type of level design in super exciting, because I love to explore, and while on the topic of levels, the many levels of this game all feel different making each and everyone a different journey to be had. Now, to the juicy stuff...pros and cons.Pros: - The music is phenomenal. - The art is gorgeous. - The enemies are different. - Levels are designed well to keep the game interesting. - Characters are lovable. - The story is in-depth, while being a rollercoaster of emotions. - Sprites and animations are wonderful. - Exploration is fun.*- Boss-fights are also fun and different.With all these pros you'd think there'd be no cons, right? Nah there's like 2.Cons:  - The game isn't too difficult, I only died a couple times, but that was from me being stupid.*- Along with the first con, the boss-fights are not too difficult.The game is fun and innovative and competely worth your time and money, I just wish they had a difficult slider or something, because I found myself going through levels with ease.Oh well, a game doens't need to be difficult to be a masterpiece. I give this game a 9.5/10 just because it was pretty easy and it felt like I was "flying" (heheheh) through the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game is the product of nine years of development, and it really shows that the developers crafted every detail of the game with love. Owlboy isn't perfect, but it's definitely a standout title.PresentationOwlboy's strongest attribute by far. The "Hi-Bit" pixel graphics are gorgeous and set a high bar for any future games using a pixelated art style. The soundtrack by Jonathan Geer is beautiful and emotive, making the soundtrack a worthy upgrade if you're the type to listen to video game soundtracks when you're not playing. Animations for the characters are absolutely on point. The characters' expressions and reactions during dialogue are very charming and expressive.GameplayWhile I had a lot of fun with this game, it's not as polished in the gameplay department as in presentation. The game is often far too easy, with some spikes in difficulty in certain sections. I found myself breezing through the levels, with puzzles, boss fights, and other obstacles doing little to slow my progress. Occasionally, I would get lost in some of the levels if I decided to go hunting for collectibles as there's no minimap, though not much backtracking is required to progress in the game.StoryI loved the story and spent time talking to every NPC. However, I know the story is hit or miss for some. Owlboy's story pacing is pretty standard, breaking up the action in-between dungeons for narrative development and character dialogue. The characters are likable and distinct, and the story has some unexpectedly emotional turns. If you're not interested in the story, however, you're probably going to get annoyed at the interruptions.Final ThoughtsOverall I'd recommend Owlboy to anyone looking for an aesthetically-pleasing game that's light on difficulty but high on charm. If you're an action platformer veteran looking for a challenge, this game will disappoint you. Owlboy is at its best when you just relax and let it pull you in with its story and presentation. I wish the game was longer or more challenging, but I came away from the game without regrets in my purchase, even going back to 100% it and see everything there is to see

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												After dealing with Owlboy for a full video series where I played it, it left a good impression on me as a game itself. Uncertain if I can link that, so here's just the review!In all honesty, it's hard to rate Owlboy as anything less than 'Amazing' in almost every aspect it tries to touch upon. Gameplay is solid, the map is solid, the characters are great, the art is pretty and stylish, and the story overall is told well... But there are still flaws. In the story itself, there are a lot of things that are hamfisted or simply not explained well enough and most characters come off as negative because of that. Now, a majority of them are still fine and that's why I said they were great, but there are definitely a few I feel have fatal flaws that simply aren't explored in the gameplay. That is my major complaint.Another major complaint is a build up that never receives a payoff. Something that may hint for things to come now that the foundation has been set, but... It could have been handled better. This game was amazing, there's no doubting that, and I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who likes action platformers like this that are very story driven. There's also a lot of hidden things that just aren't really focused on unless you really want to 100% the game, which is a plus. It's nice when a game likes to show you its story through actual work instead of just an hour long cutscene, though there are plenty of small cutscenes through this game as well.Regardless, this game has flaws and a few major ones too, but it's not a bad game. Gameplay was simple, clean, and overall fun, but ultimately ended up becoming repetitive or just annoying, particuarlly in certain situations. The music was always on point, though, and there were only a few points where the art was an issue, particuarlly when dealing with enemies that have arkward hit boxxes or move a lot. That being said..... The information I have states the game took over 10 years to come out. In these 10 years, it got a lot of support and a lot of people were looking forward to it. In no way do I think anyone who did wish for it is disappointed and I am definitely not disappointed either in buying it... But it could have been better and I feel like 10 years was more than enough time to make it better. There's a lot of small things that really make this game just barely reach 'Amazing', but it's still amazing nontheless. I'm looking forward to more from this group and hopefully this game will allow them to see flaws they otherwise missed because of either lack of experience, or simply not trying to focus on fixing them. Hopefully it'll take less than 10 years next time, possibly for a sequel. Story: 7/10Art: 9/10Gameplay: 8/10Music: 10/10Characters: 7.5/10 (One specific character has a good moment, but overall is pretty meh.)Overall: 8/10. Could use work, but it's still an amazing game that people should pick up if they enjoy this genre.

												A piece of beauty, that's all I have to say about this game. The art is amazing, the soundtrack is awesome and fitting (but don't look at the song titles because spoilers), the story is great and the characters are lovable and memorable.They spent nine years working on this game and it shows!That being said, the game does have its share of glitches, although those I encountered were fairly minor. But there is one complaint I have about this game, namely the bosses, the game sometimes takes a huge difficulty spike at some of its bossfights, which could be pretty frustrating and sometimes made the controls feel a little unresponsive...(that being said, I'm not exactly great at reflex based activities in general, so this probably doesn't apply to everyone)I have nothing but love for Owlboy, give it a shot, it'll be worth it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												Fun, cute game, but suffers from slow pacing and wonky controls, especially with switching around teammates. Additionally, there's this NPC in the game who basically physically and emotionally abuses her coworkers (well, let's be honest: slaves), but it's portrayed as being funny because she's, well, she's a girl - and girls, I guess, aren't "supposed" to be physically/emotionally abusing. But, for someone like me - who, uh, has a history with this sort of thing - this hit a little too close to home, and made me feel extremely uncomfortable to see it portrayed in such a lighthearted manner. Despite all this, I'm assuming that most people don't really care or aren't as affected by it as I am, so I really recommend the game, so long as you're one of these people. Of course, just be aware that the game does start off rather slowly and that the controls are a little loose. Both are relatively mild concerns, I think, so they're easily outweighed by the game's charm, music, and general enjoyability. Pros:- Charming pixelated graphics and animations- Fitting music- Personable and memorable charactersCons: - Slow pace- Loose controls- That one questionable NPC (to me, at least)

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												I had fun playing this game. Its strange to feel that it isn't the norm when I play a lot of games, but normally there is some kind of goal or achievement involved to test my skill or my patience. This game was... it was just fun! It made me genuinely laugh at some parts, and at others I felt sad for the characters in the story. Yes I know people say the story is cliché and could have more and has loose ends (not everything has to be explained) but who cares. Owlboy game me that same experience playing Dust: An Elysian Tail where I was just completely absorbed into the world and wanted to see this adventure through Emotions and overall feel aside, mechanically the game was solid. I only encountered ONE bug the entire time and that was a boss not progressing as he should have at a certain time. This was easily fixed by just reloading from checkpoint and fighting him again. Nearing the end the game became increasingly difficult and it felt rewarding once I succeeded. 10/10 in my book and a 100% recommendation to anyone that just... loves video games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												TL;DR : This game is astounding, 9.5/10._________________________Owlboy is a breath of fresh air in the gaming industry, something different from the casual FPS or other cash-grabs with no real game. And allow me to explaing why. In this game you play as Otus, a young owl living in the town of Villie along with his bestfriend and partner: Geddy. While you go on your adventure you will find out that as Otus you are unable to kill an enemy yourself, for you can only stun them or knock armor off of them. This is where the innovation begins, as you must pick up Geddy to kill an enemy, for Geddy (and other teammates you will get later on) will be the only ones able to kill an enemy.  As you fly along through the story, you may also notice that you can trail off from the given path to adventure else where, to find secrets of the land and stories untold...and maybe a few more coins laying around. I find that this type of level design in super exciting, because I love to explore, and while on the topic of levels, the many levels of this game all feel different making each and everyone a different journey to be had. Now, to the juicy stuff...pros and cons.Pros: - The music is phenomenal. - The art is gorgeous. - The enemies are different. - Levels are designed well to keep the game interesting. - Characters are lovable. - The story is in-depth, while being a rollercoaster of emotions. - Sprites and animations are wonderful. - Exploration is fun.*- Boss-fights are also fun and different.With all these pros you'd think there'd be no cons, right? Nah there's like 2.Cons:  - The game isn't too difficult, I only died a couple times, but that was from me being stupid.*- Along with the first con, the boss-fights are not too difficult.The game is fun and innovative and competely worth your time and money, I just wish they had a difficult slider or something, because I found myself going through levels with ease.Oh well, a game doens't need to be difficult to be a masterpiece. I give this game a 9.5/10 just because it was pretty easy and it felt like I was "flying" (heheheh) through the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												I would like to start this review by saying that this game took 9 years to make.  9 years that were totally worth waiting for.  This is what game developers should aspire to.Owlboy is a short, metroidvania-style game made by D-Pad Studio.  I stumbled upon this game shortly before its release, because Savant: Ascent (A previous title by the same studio) was such a fun game, I wanted to try it out again.  When I reinstalled Savant, I noticed a small news article on the game page talking about Owlboy's upcoming release.D-Pad Studio has, in my opinion, the best pixel art style out there.  And Owlboy is no exception.  Througout the entirety of the game, I was amazed simply by how beautiful every area was.  This game has no map, but it's not needed, because the great art style lends itself to some gorgeous landmarks, to help you find your way.  Sadly, there is no form of fast-travel, but it isn't necessary, due to the speed at which you can traverse to a new area.Savant: Ascent really had done gameplay well.  Owlboy kept to these tight controls and fun gameplay, while adding a short, but powerful story.  While sometimes difficult, no part of the game ever felt frustrating, and I always kept coming back.  This was mostly due to the varied cast, all of whom had well written dialouge.  As such, many of the game's characters were some of the most relatable characters I've come across in recent years.Owlboy may be a short game, but there are a decent amount of collectables, and I could definitely play through the game again, to experience some of the emotions this game will bring out.This is one of the best games I've played in years.  Do NOT let this one pass you by.

Posted: November 6, 2016
												This is basically a super gorgeous Shantae game.  Which is great, because those are fantastic platformers, they just don't spend 10 years on each one meticulously doing amazing little one-shot animations.  Now you get the best of both!If you haven't owned a Nintendo console it's hard to imagine the magic of this type of game.  Shovel Knight is another good comparison. If you've got minimal twitch reflexes (It's easier than Aquaria and Shovel Knight, nowhere near as sadistically evil as Ori and the Blind Forest, and again about the same as Shantae games) you should give it a shot. It's gorgeous, bittersweet, very funny at times, and a very satisfying ending. Worth full price for me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												Art: 9/10 Basically the best pixel art I've ever seen. However, some animations felt slightly under par, particularly on some party members.Music: 9/10 Actually really really good.Gameplay: 6/10 My two biggest issues with the game as a whole are the enemies and movement mechanics. The bosses are way too easy, I only died to the final boss once and most other bosses I did not die at all on. There are no enemies outside of bosses that were a real threat, outside of "trap" enemies, and the static obstacle Pirates. The greatest depth in movement is tapping B every half second, or much later on (for basically a single level), using a grappling hook thing.  This game I feel would be greatly improved by adding extra abilities to the player throughout the game, and having more varied and difficult enemies, as well as making the bosses more difficult.However, this is coming from a person with 3000 hours in the Dark Souls series, so take some of that with a grain of salt. In addition to those issues, the levels often seem very simple. All of them are entirely linear, with weak puzzles that feel more like chores than anything.Story: 7/10 The story at times is rather generic, however at other points it is extemely engaging. Kind of a mixed bag here.Overall: 7/10 Needs more depth, and difficulty.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												Owlboy is among the most fascinating games I've ever played. I can't put my finger on the exact reason, but something about it captivates me in a surreal way. I can't determine whether it's the well-realized art style, amazing music & sound design, responsive gameplay, or engrossing story. I think it's truly a combination of all of these things; but, whatever the reason, I couldn't put Owlboy down. Yes, there were a few moments of frustration (controls being a little inconsistent in some later-level platforming, a few boss encounters) but, overall, my complaints about Owlboy are easily drowned out by my gushing praise for the remainder. If you enjoy platformers, or games with wonderful stories, I urge you to play Owlboy. It is worth every cent, and every minute. Congratulations to the team for finally putting it out, you created something truly special here.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												•	Storyo	The game revolves around Otus, a young mute Owlboy who is lackluster at all things his mentor deems as important to being a proper being an owl. In this game an owl is the protector of the denizens of the floating islands that make up the world. Throughout the game Otus meets new companions who serve as his weapons on his journey to save the floating islands from sky pirateso	The story told is a familiar take on the Hero’s journey, however it’s done well. Dialogue is well written and character development is well paced. The game is sparse with its NPCs and makes the ones who are in the game pretty significant, if not to the main story then to the side quests that are placed throughout the game.o	However, even with the side quests mentioned prior, this game is short. I made sure to talk and return to most npcs after each pivotal moment of the game (for anyone interested most of their dialogue changes frequently) and completed all but 2 of the side quests, aand reached the end screen in 7 hours.•	Technicalo	As Otus is an owl, a majority of the game is navigated via flying. This gives the game a unique feel to its platforming. The levels are designed well around this form of movement and makes exploring the game rewarding.o	Otus can’t attack on his own, but instead carries his allies around as weapons. His allies hang under him as he flies them around. While this is a cool concept, I found my allies getting snagged on terrain at tense moments as the ally pretty much doubles the size of your controlled sprite. This results in some situations where the controls feel clunky.o	Every level has its own theme that are visually stunning and every room in the levels are distinct, which assists in preventing the player from getting lost.o	However, the game lacks a mini map makes it difficult to back track through completed levels. While going through a level the first time is easy and intuitive, the shortcuts opened as you progress make it easy to overlook rooms when returning to collect missed coins. A mini map would fix this.•	Final Thoughtso	While there are certain parts of the game that become frustrating due to control issues and the game runs a bit short for the price tag, I would still wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of 2d adventure games and games with touching stories.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												Even 16-bit-era fans that are experiencing "pixel art fatigue" owe it to themselves to feast their eyes and ears on Owlboy. The art direction and animation are on a whole other level of polish that will remind you of countless games without ever feeling like style for nostalgia's sake, and the feel of the controls hold up masterfully on a gamepad OR mouse and keyboard.There's so many disparate elements coming together that Owlboy SHOULD feel like the gaming equivalent of a high concept album; twin stick shooting, ballistics, grappling, platforming, storytelling, and exploration... The fact that it DOESN'T is a testament to how polished and focused this feels compared to many ambitious indie games.Part of me wishes the mechanics dove deeper and demanded more challening combinations of your abilities, but the length is just about right for a narrative adventure of this scope.I loved Owlboy, and it left me wanting more without wearing thin.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												On the surface, this is a fun little platformer game with aspects of twin-stick shooter. Like others have remarked, it has impressive art design. Unlike others, I didn't find myself very compelled by the story and overall game design. Does it have a message? Yes, you can definitely see the parallels it draws between its characters and the hardships that we, as inhabitants of earth, face economically, environmentally and socially.But, was it fun? Kind of. Will it leave a lasting impression on me? Probably not. Is it worth the $20+US? No...I would say about $15 relative to other games I've played that are similar indie platformers. I understand this was an indie title that took 9 years in the making - don't really understand why so long - possibly finances? In all honesty, I've played other indie games that were far more enjoyable to play and left a lasting impression - I'm talking about you Environmental Station Alpha, Cave Story and Valdis Story. Opposed to these others, I can't honestly say that I'd come back to play this one. It's very linear. Controls are just ok. There's a section near the end that requires some experimentation with platform jumping. I'll give a hint...if you've been using the analog stick in the flying portions preceding this, you definitely want to switch to the D-Pad during said jumping section near end of game. Something weird convolutes the analog left movement stick with the jumping mechanism, intermittently wonking out and prompting premature flight, loss of hang-time, etc. You'll see. Maybe the devs will fix this.Anyway, bottom line, it is a fairly enjoyable game that I would recommend...with one caveat. If you don't mind spending the $20+, go ahead and purchase; otherwise, wait for a sale at around $15 or so.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												PROS:-Simple yet challenging mixture of 'platforming'/bullet-hell/twin-stick shooter-Gorgeously realized world-Characters with depth and growth - a character I'd seen as an absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥made a surprising turn towards the end.-Very well-told story-Epic soundtrack-I like that upgrades aren't so much 'bought' as 'earned', where you get them by collecting coins, but the coins aren't actually spent on them.CONS:-Some frustrating set pieces. An actual platforming bit towards the end is rather frustrating and made me aware of a certain over-sensitivity in between jumping and actually flying-I'm sort of in two minds about the ending-You don't have much health, and opportunities for healing can be few in dungeons-Some checkpoint placement can range from irksome to downright sadistic-Some graphical effects (such as firing a character's musket) can be somewhat disorienting - but I've found myself to be somewhat sensitive to that kind of thing.All in all, this game's a real hoot. (I regret nothing.)

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												This is a really good game, but there's a few little things that I just can't quite ignore.The game, for the most part, is fairly easy with a few rather unforgiving and difficult sections torward the end. Luckily, these are far between enough that it doesn't make the experience a slog to get through, but it did hamper my enjoyment  a bit.The story really isn't anything to write home about in terms of originality. The bad guys are bad for the sake of being bad, the good guys are plucky underdogs, and there will be plenty of hunting for ancient artifacts. Where this story shines is in the character interactions, which are all very well animated and fun to watch... And surprisingly, you will want to see all these characters' story play out.And that leads me to my biggest bugbear; the ending. To put it simply, there just isn't enough of it, and it leaves on a rather unsatisfying conclusion. It wasn't so terrible that I wanted to curse my purchase, but it was bad enough for me feel very disappointed. Maybe there is another ending buried behind the various collectibles, but I've never been good at hunting all that stuff down, so my best bet is to wait for someone to post a youtube video of it.End of the day though, I'd say this game is worth is picking up, but if you need a satisfying ending...? You may wanna wait for it to go on sale first.TL;DR version: Great game, disappointing ending. If you're fine with that, buy it. If not? Wait for the sale.

												This game suffers from mediocre combat and in some parts frustrating level design.  The movement system isn't as much fun as I thought it would be for a game where you can fly from the get-go.  There's very little backtracking and a lack of puzzles for a game of its metroidvania flavor.  Owlboy, however turns out to be more than the sum of its parts.  None of these individual gripes end up being a deal-breaker, and the ups in my opinion far outweigh the downs.  Containing fun characters, a decent story, and easily the best pixel art I've ever seen in a game,  Owlboy is well worth your time.It's perhaps a bit short for $25, but it's a must buy if you can't get enough of the atmosphere of games like Fez and Hyper Light Drifter. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												Owlboy is a 2D puzzle-platformer about an anthropomorphic owl named Otus who finds himself unknowingly in the midst of a cataclysmic disaster millenia in the making. With the assistance of friends he makes along the way, Otus solves puzzles, shoots enemies, defeats monstrous bosses, and unearths dark secrets about the world he lives in.  In terms of gameplay, the only thing that sets it apart from other platformers is Otus' ability to carry one of his companions while in flight. Over the course of the game, you encounter 3 friends who accompany you on your adventure, each of which has a unique ability that can be used to gain access to previously inaccessible areas, solve puzzles, eliminate enemies, and avoid or circumvent obstacles. Although a novel mechanic, it is utilized in generally uninteresting ways, resulting in a gameplay experience that falls a bit flat. The puzzles presented in the game aren't difficult in the slightest, and your companions' abilities are only used in the most surface-level puzzle-solving. Oftentimes, the puzzles come down to: use a companion's ability at this point to progress. Had more of the game's puzzle-solving revolved around switching between companions or combining their abilities in unique ways, the gameplay would have been much more enjoyable. However, this would have required fundamental changes to the story beats and progression as the first two companions are introduced in the first couple hours of the game. The third (and final companion) isn't unlocked until you are in the throes of the game's climax. To make matters worse, over the course of the game you periodically lose a companion, meaning that you only have a full party for what seems like the last hour or so. Despite the narrative justifications for this, it's frustrating that  one of the defining mechanics of Owlboy can only be fully utilized for the last hour or two of the game. The story itself is filled with the charm and whimsy that you would expect from a game like Owlboy. The game's narrative follows Otus as he attempts to save his people from a cataclysmic event which gets increasingly dire as the game progresses. There are some unexpected turns in the story that kept it from being completely predictable, but at the end of the game it was a pretty standard "save the world from X because ancient people did Y" narrative you might expect from an animated children's movie. Although it falls victim to some fairly common narrative tropes, the story was compelling enough to keep me engaged and interested for its entirety. Artistically, Owlboy is a masterpiece, and I struggle to think of a more perfect example of pixel-art done right. Whether soaring through the sky towards a floating continent, or dashing through lava-filled caves, every frame is a beautiful pixel-art painting. The environments teem with life as birds fly off into the distance, stars twinkle in the night sky, and the background and foreground slide along in some of the best examples of parallax scrolling I've ever seen. The character sprites and monsters are beautifully animated and brimming with personality that would make even Nintendo green with envy. The entire game is filled with screen-shot worthy moments that were composed with almost absurd attention to detail. Although the artwork in Owlboy is second to none, the soundtrack itself is a wonderful composition of scores that perfectly complement every scene. Lilting clarinets, violins, and cellos accompany Otus on his journey to save the world, instilling a sense of mysticism and serenity that is not often found in games. Unless you're one for scouring every inch of a game in order to collect every single coin imaginable, once you're done with Owlboy there's no reason to come back. There is no "New Game+", unlockable content, or multiplayer. That isn't to say that it would need any of that. The journey is a short one at roughly 6-8 hours, but considering the overall shallowness of the gameplay, any longer and it would have been a slog. There's no question as to when the game will come to a close as the story ends in a textbook climactic fashion. With most of the narrative threads being wrapped up in the game's bittersweet conclusion, the ending of Owlboy feels nothing short of satisfying. It's not disappointing, nor is it powerfully moving. Instead it feels absolutely appropriate, a perfectly competent bookend to what was overall a thoroughly enjoyable experience. Despite the lackluster gameplay and the occasionally frustrating traversal segment, Owlboy has stuck with me. From time to time I'll find myself whistling the main menu music or imagining the blue skies and gently swaying foliage of the introductory area, and I'm immediately reminded of the games from my childhood. 16-bit vibrant landscapes, colorful characters, and comical villain archetypes. Owlboy serves as a rose-tinted lens through which I retrospectively view the games of my childhood. It's nostalgic, charming, and beautiful. (http://www.shatteredjoystick.com/single-post/2016/11/30/Owlboy-PC--Review)

Posted: December 3, 2016
												Overall the game was great.  Good nostalgia, beautiful pixel art, good music, enjoyable story, and for the most part the gameplay was good.  However, there were a few gameplay/design choices that I thought were gimmicky and unnecessary only to try and add some difficulty to the game and just came off as stupid/annoying. You're an owl, there shouldn't be levels that try to use darkness as a way to add difficulty to a level.  You should be able to see. I thought that was a little silly.  Also, there is one boss battle where the map is constantly rotating as is your gamepad direction.  There are a few more design choices like the two I mentioned that just seem pointless and could have been better designed.  Other than that, the game was very enjoyable.

												Pros-Fantastic pixel art-Great soundtrack that's very memorable-Solid level design (for the most part)-Great, ikeable characters-A surprisingly good storyCons-Most of the "puzzles" are just finding a certain switch that opens a certain door-I didn't enjoy a single boss fight in this game. They're way too easy and throw out the same attacks over and over and over again. I found that most of the mini-bosses (which are just huge hordes of normal enemies) were harder than the actual bosses-Enemies get pretty boring to fight as circle strafing just completely destroys each and every single one with only a few exceptions-Some enemies/enemy attacks blend right into the background, which gets pretty frustrating really fastOverall, I would give this game a 7.5/10 and would recommend it, despite its flaws.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 16
												This game is simply put: beautiful. From the orchestral soundtrack punctuating every environment and story beat to the gorgeous display of 'hi-bit' pixel art craftsmanship Owlboy is a feast for the senses. It tells a simple story of an owl boy in his village but manages to infuse that story with surprisingly potent emotional arcs with characters who's motivations can change from fun NPC character in a platformer to a cuttingly real motivation of loss and despair, or shame, or unforgiving anger. The game feels tailormade to me in the sense of its artistry and fun platforming mechanics. It's the kind of game I would love to be a part of in the making. If you're anything like me, or even if you just enjoy solid platformers, then you should definitely pick this game up.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 17
												This was a fantastic game, and a lot more satisfying to play than I expected.Owlboy has a beautiful pixelated aesthetic that left me just sitting there staring at the background at times.  The animations are spot on, with expressive characters and enemies.   The music was beautiful and the sound design... well it was okay.The game plays well and I was expecting to find the "always flying" gameplay to be dry but the enemy designs kept things interesting.  I found that I struggled with the controls at times, but that was my own issues I'm sure.  I had to play with the right stick settings of my steam controller quite a bit to get a setting that felt right to aim with.The difficulty curve was a bit on the wonky side.  It provided a little challenge for most of the game but then about 2/3 of the way through it goes through the roof for about an hourish and then gets far too easy.  The boss design was nice, and most were fair but challenging.  Once you figured out the patterns it just becomes a problem of execution... which causes some of them to drag on awhile.Overall I like it and will be rejoining the game to find the rest of the coins and investigate a few things I couldn't figure out on my first playthrough.

												I rarely write reviews for games; I think i only did one to get the steam badge, but this game is worth writing a review for. I bought this game because it looked beautiful, and not a single landscape in the game disappointed me. Its very apparent that the programmers put love and detail into this game. Admittedly the controls took a while getting used to; throughout the entire game I found myself trying to press the spacebar to jump instead of pressing W. That along with the lack of a proper sprint button are my only cons for the game. To contrast to that, however, you get hours worth of beautiful places to explore, lovable characters to befriend, and a touching story that will nag at you until you finally beat the game. I can only hope D-Pad Studios next game holds up to the high standard they've set for themselves with this game
